n a prospective study of 58 adults—including 27 long-COVID patients roughly 18 months post-infection—high-resolution sublingual videomicroscopy showed a 41% reduction in capillary density restricted to the smallest vessels (D5–D7 classes: −45%, −36%, −23%). Despite normalized glycocalyx dimensions, the Microvascular Health Score was significantly worse in long-COVID (2.72 vs 3.87 in controls; p = 0.002), and capillary recruitment was blunted (29% vs 70%), indicating a fixed, poorly adaptable microvascular bed. These abnormalities did not improve over time across ~1.5 years and were linked to neurocognitive complaints (lower density; p = 0.049).

The Omicron variant of SARS-CoV-2 has diversified into major sub-lineages (BA.1, BA.1.1, BA.2 and BA.3), and this study directly compares their resistance to neutralising antibodies from vaccination (inactivated whole-virus) and monoclonal antibodies (mAbs). Two doses of inactivated vaccine produced very weak or undetectable neutralisation of all four sub-lineages. Booster immunisation (either homologous or heterologous) restored measurable neutralising titres, but still showed around 7- to 23-fold lower titres against Omicron sub-lineages compared to wild-type virus (for example, GMT ~537 for WT vs ~42 for BA.2 in one cohort). In parallel, evaluation of ~20 different mAbs revealed that most lost substantial neutralising activity against the Omicron sub-lineages; only a few retained broad potency (e.g., LY-CoV1404). Importantly, BA.1.1, BA.2 and BA.3 exhibited equal or even greater resistance than BA.1, suggesting that immune escape continues to evolve within the Omicron family.

🐁Mild respiratory SARS-CoV-2 infection in mice, even without neuroinvasion, triggers persistent white-matter–selective microglial activation, reduced hippocampal neurogenesis, oligodendrocyte loss, and myelin degradation well after viral clearance. Elevated levels of the chemokine CCL11 are found in cerebrospinal fluid/serum of infected mice, and systemic CCL11 treatment in naïve mice reproduces microglial reactivity and blunted neurogenesis. In human post-COVID cases with lingering cognitive (“brain fog”) symptoms, plasma CCL11 levels are higher than in those without such symptoms, and postmortem brain tissue shows increased microglial reactivity in white matter compared to controls. By comparing with mild influenza infection, the authors show that while some neural changes are shared, the persistence of white-matter microglial activation and oligodendroglial/myelin loss appears more sustained in the SARS-CoV-2 setting. These findings suggest mechanisms linking even mild COVID infection to enduring cognitive deficits via neuroinflammation, white-matter injury, and chemokine-mediated microglial dysregulation. However, limitations include small human sample sizes, correlative human findings, lack of stratification by age/variant/vaccination, and reliance on a specific mouse model that may not capture the full spectrum of human disease.

🐁 Neuroinvasion and anosmia are independent phenomena upon infection with SARS-CoV-2 and its variants. All strains and variants tested (Wuhan, Gamma, Delta, Omicron/BA.1, and the ORF7ab‐deleted mutant) showed ability to infect (or at least presence of virus) in the olfactory bulbs. Viral titers and RNA loads in olfactory bulbs were above detection for all groups. Evidence supports the olfactory pathway (sensory neurons in nose → olfactory epithelium → olfactory bulb neurons) as a route for brain invasion. No strong evidence was found for infection spreading via blood vessels or widespread brain infection beyond olfactory bulbs in this model. Retrograde and anterograde movement along axons was observed in in vitro neuron-epithelial systems. The original Wuhan strain caused the most severe clinical signs (e.g. weight loss), followed by Gamma, then Delta, and Omicron/BA.1 caused the mildest signs. Wuhan strain: high rate of full anosmia (complete loss) in many animals. Gamma: fewer full anosmia, but many animals had impaired smell. Delta & Omicron/BA.1: no detectable olfactory deficits in the behavioral test used – they did not lose smell. Removing ORF7ab from the Wuhan strain reduced incidence of anosmia: only ~25% of animals with ORF7-deleted virus showed anosmia vs ~62.5% with wild-type Wuhan. However, deletion of ORF7ab did not reduce neuroinvasion: virus still reached olfactory bulbs, etc.

In this study, the authors used large-scale genomic surveillance data from the UK (Office for National Statistics COVID Infection Survey, ONS-CIS) covering November 2020 to August 2022, to estimate how often SARS-CoV-2 infections persist beyond typical durations. They identified 381 people whose viral RNA levels remained at high titre for at least 30 days, and among those 54 had persistence of at least 60 days. They estimate that about 0.7-3.5% of infections persist ≥ 30 days, and about 0.1-0.5% persist ≥ 60 days. People with persistent infections were ~55% more likely to self-report Long COVID (i.e. post-acute COVID-19 symptoms) than people whose infections cleared more quickly, however, only 9% of people with persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection reported having Long COVID

Long COVID manifests with T cell dysregulation, inflammation, and an uncoordinated adaptive immune response to SARS-CoV-2. Individuals with LC harbored increased frequencies of CD4+ T cells poised to migrate to inflamed tissues, and exhausted SARS-CoV-2-specific CD8+ T cells. They also harbored significantly higher levels of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies, and in contrast to non-LC individuals, exhibited a mis-coordination between their SARS-CoV-2-specific T and B cell responses.

A low count of CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes is a hallmark laboratory finding in the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Using flow cytometry, significantly higher CD95 (Fas) and PD-1 expression on both CD4+ T and CD8+ T cells were observed in 42 COVID-19 patients when compared to controls. Higher CD95 expression in CD4+ cells correlated with lower CD4+ counts. A higher expression of CD95 in CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes correlated with a lower percentage of naive events. This suggests a shift to antigen-activated T cells, expressing molecules increasing their propensity to apoptosis and exhaustion during COVID-19 infection.

Both early and late apoptotic cells in B and T lymphocytes were increased in all patients with COVID-19 (p < .05). Early apoptotic (EA) B and T lymphocytes were also higher in severe cases compared to mild cases (p = .026). There was no significant difference between lymphopenia and apoptosis in patients with COVID-19. However, patients with lymphopenia (n = 14) and severe COVID-19 (p = .013) had increased EA T lymphocytes. This study's results show that B and T lymphocytes' apoptosis increases in patients with COVID-19. In addition, enhanced T lymphocyte apoptosis is associated with disease severity in lymphopenic patients with COVID-19.

The risks were evident in people who were not hospitalized during the acute phase of COVID-19 and increased in a graded fashion across the severity spectrum of the acute phase of COVID-19 (non-hospitalized, hospitalized, and admitted to intensive care).

The results of 94,812 SARS-CoV-2 PCR tests collected longitudinally from >3,000 players, staff, and affiliates of the NBA over the course of the pandemic were analysed. Of 1323 randomized trial participants, 1125 consented for long-term follow up, and 95.1% completed >9 months of follow up. The median age was 45 years (IQR, 37 to 54), and 56% were female (7% pregnant). The median BMI was 30 kg/m2 (IQR, 27 to 34). Overall, 8.4% reported a medical provider diagnosed them with Long COVID; cumulative incidence: 6.3% with metformin and 10.6% with matched placebo. The hazard ratio (HR) for metformin preventing Long COVID was 0.58 (95%CI, 0.38 to 0.88; P=0·009) versus placebo. The metformin effect was consistent across subgroups, including viral variants. When metformin was started within <4 days of symptom onset, the HR for Long COVID was 0.37 (95%CI, 0.15 to 0.95).  No statistical difference in Long COVID occurred in those randomized to either ivermectin (HR=0.99; 95%CI, 0.59 to 1.64) or fluvoxamine (HR=1.36; 95%CI, 0.78 to 2.34).

Of 194,191 adults with COVID-19 infection, 6.3% were hospitalized, 3.1% experienced a deterioration event, and 2.8% died within 90 days. Dose‒response effects were strong; for example, patients in the some activity category had higher odds of hospitalization (OR=1.43; 95% CI=1.26, 1.63), deterioration (OR=1.83; 95% CI=1.49, 2.25), and death (OR=1.92; 95% CI=1.48, 2.49) than those in the always active category. Results were generally consistent across sex, race and ethnicity, age, and BMI categories and for patients with cardiovascular disease or hypertension.

Prior to the widespread implementation of the COVID-19 vaccine, the incidence of newly diagnosed erectile dysfunction is higher in men with prior COVID-19 infection compared to age-matched controls. Prior COVID-19 infection was associated with a 27% increased likelihood of developing new-onset erectile dysfunction when compared to those without prior infection. 42,406 men experienced a COVID-19 infection between January 2020 and January 2021 of which 601 (1.42%) developed new onset erectile dysfunction within 6.5 months follow up. On multivariable analysis while controlling for diabetes, cardiovascular disease, smoking, obesity, hypogonadism, thromboembolism, and malignancy, prior COVID-19 infection was associated with increased risk of new onset erectile dysfunction (HR 1.27; 95% CI 1.1–1.5; P = 0.002).

183 studies were included, reporting data from 64,876 patients with COVID-19 worldwide. The overall prevalence of taste disorders was 38% (95% CI = 22% to 56%, I2 = 98%). Taste disorders were associated with a positive COVID-19 test (odds ratio [OR] = 7.54, 95% CI = 5.24 to 10.86, I2 = 93%, P < 0.00001), showing high certainty of evidence. A total of 154 COVID-19–positive patients with STEMI were included in the present analysis and were compared with 1,115 COVID-19–negative patients. Early during the pandemic (wave 1), STEMI patients presenting with concurrent COVID-19 infection had high rates of cardiac arrest, evidence of increased thrombus burden, bigger infarcts, and worse outcomes. However, by wave 3, no differences existed in outcomes between COVID-19–positive and –negative patients, with significant differences compared with earlier COVID-19–positive patients. Poor outcomes later in the study period were predominantly in unvaccinated individuals.
Data suggests that long COVID and persistent immune activation may correlate independently with severe disease.

COVID-19 causes severe neurological complications in people with dementia. COVID-19 appears to accelerate disease progression in all types of dementia. Specifically, the worsening was seen in attention (p = 0.019), memory (p < 0.001), fluency (p = 0.006), language (p < 0.001), and visuospatial (p < 0.001) domains. Executive functions assessed by the Clock-Drawing test (p = 0.021) and the Trail-Making Test Part B (p = 0.016) also deteriorated significantly. There were a significant increase of periventricular white matter (p = 0.002) and deep white matter hyperintensities (p = 0.001), and global cortical atrophy (p = 0.025) on neuroimaging following COVID-19 infection in the follow-up period.

Persons showing both antibody and T-cell responses had the lowest risk of mortality or ICU admission suggesting that dual contribution of humoral and cellular immunity is important to prevent against disease progression.

The SARS-CoV-2-specific T cell response's magnitude and breadth were correlated inversely with the time that had elapsed from disease onset and age. The mean magnitude of SARS-CoV-2-specific CD4 and CD8 T cell responses decreased about 82% and 76%, respectively, over the time period of ten months after infection. SARS-CoV-2-specific T cell responses waned significantly in 75% of convalescent individuals during the follow-up.
Ocular fluids from SARS-CoV-2-infected patients may contain infectious virus, and hence may be a potential source of infection.

Compared with COVID-19-recovered and uninfected controls, respectively, subjects with long COVID were more likely to show thickening and hyperechogenic vagus nerve in neck ultrasounds (mean ± SD left vagus nerve cross-sectional area: 2.4 ± 0.97mm2 vs. 2 ± 0.52mm2 vs. 1.9 ± 0.73 mm2, p=0.080), flattened diaphragmatic curve (47% vs 6% vs 14%, p=0.007), reduced esophageal peristalsis (34% vs 0% vs 21%, p=0.020), gastroesophageal reflux (34% vs 19% vs 7%, p=0.130), hiatal hernia (25% vs 0% vs 7%, p=0.050) and reduced maximal inspiratory pressure in functional respiratory tests (62% vs. 6% vs. 17%, p ≤0.001).
Improvement of immune dysregulation and health-related quality of life in individuals with long COVID at 24-months following SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Brain blood clots in small study were full of amyloids. Harmful amyloids are various misfolded proteins with certain chemical & structural characteristics that also make them tough & prone to tangle together. Prions are also among amyloids.
The risk of an arterial thrombotic event, e.g. heart attack or stroke, on day zero of COVID infection was; 73x higher for vaccinated people, and 255x higher for unvaccinated.

SARS-CoV-2 infection can inhibit the growth and spread of certain solid tumors, including colon and kidney cancers. The key mechanism involves the SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid (N) protein, which can interact with a protein called YBX1.
Having a prior Post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC) increases the chances of having more PASC in subsequent infections.
Maternal COVID-19 infection is associated with offspring neurodevelopmental disorders

Long COVID can come with neuroinvasiveness, neurotropism and neurovirulence; persistent systemic inflammation and cytokine storm; prolonged neuroinflammation; blood-brain barrier disruption; generation of autoantibodies; microvasculitis; prolonged endothelial dysfunction, platelet activation, and enhanced thrombin generation; silent hypoxia and associated issues; dysregulated levels of neurotransmitters like serotonin and dopamine; amyloid aggregation; tau phosphorylation; protein misfolding; neuronal death; changes in grey matter volume; prolonged immunological dysfunction; dysregulation of the cholinergic system; chronic alteration of the extended autonomic system including neuroendocrine and neuroimmune systems; altered gut-brain axis functioning; and post-traumatic stress disorder, increased amygdala and hippocampal activity.

Hepatitis is a known complication of multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children following COVID-19, and SARS-CoV-2 has been linked to increased susceptibility to infection post-COVID-19, which may suggest complex causal pathways including a possible interaction with adeno-associated virus 2 (AAV-2) infection/reactivation in hosts that are genetically susceptible or sensitised to infection. Based on the Bradford Hill criteria and modelling, human adenovirus (HAdv) alone is unlikely to be the cause of the recent increase in hepatitis in children. The causal link between SARS-CoV-2, and to a lesser degree AAV-2, appears substantially stronger but remains unproven.
Findings suggest the pancreatic adenocarcinoma as the most possible malignancy occurring after sever infection with SARS-CoV family.

Using single-cell genomics it is shown that T cells in myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME) cases are epigenetically predisposed toward terminal exhaustion and that exhaustion markers are upregulated following exercise challenge.

SARS-CoV-2 spike protein persists in the skull, meninges, and even brain cortex of COVID-19 patients long after viral RNA is cleared, with spike detected in 13/16 skull, 9/12 meninges, and 8/16 brain cortex specimens, whereas viral RNA was absent in cortex. Proteomic signatures in these tissues implicate inflammatory, neutrophil/NET, IL-18, PI3K/AKT, and neurodegeneration-related pathways, suggesting chronic perturbation of the brain border environment. In mice, exogenous spike injection (in absence of full virus) induces neuroinflammation, increases markers of apoptosis (caspase-3) and APP, and worsens outcomes in stroke and TBI models. Vaccination reduces but does not fully prevent spike accumulation. The authors argue that persistent spike at brain border regions may underlie long-COVID neurological sequelae by sustaining low-grade inflammation and sensitizing the brain to additional insults.
This study identifies a region in the SARS-CoV-2 S2 spike protein with sequence homology to bacterial super-antigens (termed P3).
Risk of long COVID reaches 37% after three infections, according to INSPQ. The risk of long COVID is estimated at: 13% after infection; 23% during a second infection; 37% during a third infection.
Receptors like ACE2 and neuropilin-1 allow the virus to enter cells. Differences in these receptors due to genetics, age can impact infection risk

Long COVID patients reported persistent cognitive symptoms such as memory problems and brain fog, with higher levels of fatigue and reduced quality of life compared to controls. Despite subjective cognitive complaints, cognitive tests did not reveal significant differences between groups, except for the TMT-A (p = 0.05). MRI analysis revealed decreased volume in the cerebellum (p = 0.03), lingual gyrus (p = 0.04), and inferior parietal regions (p = 0.03), and reduced cortical thickness in several areas, including the left and right postcentral gyri (p = 0.02, p = 0.03) and precuneus (p = 0.01, p = 0.02).

Ivermectin doesn't kill the virus. It doesn't even kill the adult parasite it targets. It only paralyzes the larvae so its a protracted treatment. And because its a neurologic, IVM can cause brain damage. In as little as 15mg dose, IVM can cause stroke-like symptoms.

SARS-CoV-2 causes hyperglycemia directly, regardless of corticoid use, stress due to hospitalization, body weight and diabetes. SARS-CoV-2 infection was independently associated with hyperglycemia, regardless of diabetic history and beta cell function. SARS-CoV-2 infects and replicates in hepatocytes. Infected hepatocytes increase glucose production and this is associated with induction of phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase activity (a rate-limiting enzyme for hepatic glucose production through gluconeogenesis).

The 31 studies included 15,000 children, and researchers recorded more than 20 persistent symptoms. 16.2% (95% confidence interval [CI], 8.5% to 28.6%) of the pediatric participants experienced 1 or more persistent symptoms at least 3 months post COVID-19. Symptoms included fatigue, depression, sleep disturbance, cough, throat pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms. The three most common persistent symptoms seen in the studies were sore throat with a pooled estimate of 14.8% (95% CI, 4.8% to 37.5%); persistent fever, with an estimate of 10.9 (95% CI, 2.4% to 38.2%); and sleep disturbance, with an estimate of 10.3% (95% CI, 4.9% to 20.4%).

Individuals who had been infected with COVID-19 and had symptoms lasting ≥ 12 weeks showed lower accuracy on cognitive tasks compared to uninfected individuals. Those with shorter symptom duration (<12 weeks) or who had recovered to their own satisfaction did not show significant deficits compared to uninfected groups. The deficit in accuracy for those with ≥12 weeks of symptoms was not trivial: it's comparable to the cognitive effect of being hospitalized during COVID, or having moderate psychological distress, or being ~10 years older in age. Reaction time (speed) was not significantly affected overall. In longitudinal follow-up (≈ 9-month follow-up after initial testing), those with long symptom duration or ongoing symptoms generally showed little recovery in cognitive accuracy deficits. The deficits persisted at almost two years after infection in some individuals. Among participants who reported that they had recovered / felt back to normal after their COVID illness, no detectable deficits in cognitive accuracy were observed compared to uninfected people.

The prevalence of hospitalization tended to be higher during the first infection than the second infection. But transfer to the ICU tended to be lower during the first infection (0.71%, 7/984) than the second infection (1.52%, 15/984). No clear evidence of different clinical patterns between primary and second infection were found.

Long COVID with cognitive impairment is associated with abnormal cortical thickening in cognition-related brain areas and elevated inflammatory markers (IL-10, IFNγ, sTREM2), suggesting neuroinflammation-driven brain changes that may underpin cognitive symptoms. Long COVID patients had lower MoCA scores than both control groups (mean 25.9 vs 27.2–28.0). Elevated IL-10, IFNγ, and sTREM2 in long-COVID with cognitive impairment, no consistent increases in classical pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNFα). sTREM2 increase suggests microglial activation and neuronal injury, similar to early Alzheimer’s disease.

There is evidence that viral RNA may persist in certain tissues for a long time after COVID-19 infection (up to nearly two years in some cases). This is associated with ongoing immune activation (particularly T cells) in various body regions. T cell activation doesn’t only occur in people with Long COVID symptoms. Certain tissues (gut wall, spinal cord) show stronger association with symptoms. That suggests some, but not all, of the immune activation may contribute to symptom persistence. The study investigated long-term tissue-level immune activation and viral persistence in people after SARS-CoV-2 infection, including in those with Long COVID symptoms. It uses imaging and tissue biopsies to look for evidence that virus or immune activation might linger long after acute infection. 24 people who had had COVID-19, imaged at times ranging 27 to 910 days after acute infection. Some had Long COVID symptoms, some didn’t. PET imaging using a tracer called [^18F]F-AraG, which specifically marks activated T lymphocytes. That allows anatomical quantification of T cell activation in various tissues. For a subset of Long COVID participants, colorectal tissue biopsies (rectosigmoid) were examined for presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA via in situ hybridization, and via immunohistochemistry. Blood plasma protein profiling showed that people with more Long COVID symptoms (>5) and higher tissue uptake had elevated markers of immune activation/inflammation. In biopsied colorectal (rectosigmoid) tissue from a subset of Long COVID participants, SARS-CoV-2 RNA (spike gene) was detected in lamina propria cells. The period after infection ranged from ~158 to ~676 days. In spinal cord and gut wall in particular, the degree of T cell activation was associated with presence of Long COVID symptoms. Elevated activation in a variety of tissues, even long after infection (up to ~2.5 years). T cell activation (measured by PET tracer uptake) was higher in the post-acute COVID group compared to controls in many anatomical sites: brainstem, spinal cord, gut wall, bone marrow, hilar lymphoid tissue, cardiopulmonary tissue, nasopharyngeal tissue, etc.

Sample: 13 COVID-positive cases and 27 control participants; mean age ~24 years, age range 13-25. All participants had baseline (pre-COVID) MRI (structural + resting-state functional MRI) and cognitive testing, and then follow-up after some got infected. Cognitive test used: spatial working memory from the CANTAB battery. Analyses: Volumetric_Δ: change in cortical/subcortical volumes pre→post COVID vs controls. Eigenvector Centrality_Δ (ECΔ): change in centrality in various brain regions (a measure from functional connectivity / network analysis) pre→post COVID vs controls. Decline in volume of the left hippocampus in COVID-positive group vs controls (Volumetric_Δ significantly different; p ≈ 0.041). In particular, reduced EC_Δ in the left amygdala was observed in the COVID+ group. COVID+ participants showed reduced performance in spatial working memory compared to controls post-infection. Importantly, the reduction in connectivity (EC_Δ) in the left amygdala mediated the relationship between having had COVID-19 and poorer spatial working memory. These effects were observed even though infections were mild and in young people; suggesting that even mild COVID-19 may lead to lasting structural/functional brain changes and modest cognitive changes.

SARS-CoV-2 RNA (including antisense strand, indicating active replication) was detected in CD4⁺ T cells that had been exposed ex vivo. Also, in samples from COVID-19 patients, CD4⁺ T cells (but not CD8⁺ T cells) from peripheral blood carried viral RNA; similarly, in bronchoalveolar lavage (lung fluid) of severe patients, a small percentage of CD4⁺ T cells had SARS-CoV-2 RNA. Molecular modeling (docking + molecular dynamics simulations) suggested that the Spike RBD of SARS-CoV-2 can bind to the N-terminal domain (NTD) of CD4, in a region that overlaps the ACE2 binding domain. The interaction was confirmed by co-immunoprecipitation: Spike protein and CD4 physically bind in assays. Infection of CD4⁺ T cells altered their function: some effects on gene expression (immune response genes) and possibly exhaustion or changes that could affect helper T cell function. (E.g. suppression of cytokine production, modulation of immune activation.). Proportion of CD4⁺ T cells infected in vivo appears small; it’s not yet clear how much direct infection contributes vs other causes of T cell depletion or dysfunction.

Discuss findings from autopsy, biopsy, surgical specimens, and studies of children with acute infection, multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C), long COVID, etc. Children can have SARS-CoV-2 RNA or antigens remaining in various tissues (not only in the respiratory tract) for weeks to months after infection. This occurs independent of disease severity, meaning even kids with mild illness sometimes show evidence of persistence. There are reports of systemic spread in children (i.e., presence in organs/tissues beyond the nose/throat) in some autopsy / biopsy cases.

Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from Long COVID patients show elevated expression and activity of indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase-2 (IDO2) (vs infected non-Long COVID and controls). In brain tissue (from the two autopsy cases), IDO2 is also expressed long after infection. Long COVID PBMCs show reduced mitochondrial function (lower respiration / spare capacity). Lower intracellular amino acids, and lower levels of metabolites of the Krebs (TCA) cycle. Increased signs of autophagy, and signs of apoptosis in some cases. The degradation products of tryptophan (kynurenine metabolites) are altered: specific patterns correlate with severity/symptomology. The enzyme IDO2 seems to be a driver of these changes. Ex vivo, using an AHR (aryl hydrocarbon receptor) antagonist reduces IDO2 expression and reduces autophagy in PBMCs. Brain tissue sample is very limited (only two Long COVID autopsy cases), so generalizability for brain findings is uncertain.

After mRNA vaccination, germinal centre (GC) B cells specific to SARS-CoV-2 spike persist for many months. The lymph node (LN) aspirates showed robust spike-specific GC activity even weeks after vaccination. This supports durable maturation of the antibody response. Antibodies elicited by vaccination do neutralize multiple variants, but (unsurprisingly) neutralization is lower for more antigenically divergent variants. Prior infection + vaccination (“hybrid” immunity) generally gives broader and stronger neutralization compared to vaccination alone. Evidence of “immune imprinting” (sometimes called “original antigenic sin” in other viral systems) was observed.

Having had a prior Omicron infection (BA.1/BA.2) was associated with higher risk of reinfection with Omicron (likely BA.5) during this period, especially in the 9–29 days after the first Omicron infection. The hazard ratio for reinfection was very high in that early window. Those who got reinfected had lower neutralizing antibody titres (for both ancestral strain and Omicron BA.1), and lower anti-RBD IgG and IgA antibodies after their initial Omicron infection, compared to those who did not get reinfected. Time since last vaccine dose, age, sex, frailty, and number of facility outbreaks were not significantly associated with reinfection risk in the group already with prior Omicron infection. Some different vaccine brand combinations (mRNA-1273 vs BNT162b2) showed small signals of different risk, but overall hybrid immunity in this older cohort was quite heterogeneous. The study investigated 750 older adults (residents of long-term care and retirement homes) who were highly vaccinated (four doses of monovalent mRNA vaccine) to see how well hybrid immunity (vaccine + infection) protects against reinfection, particularly with Omicron subvariants. In a subset of 318 of these residents, immunologic assays were done (antibody levels, neutralization, T cell memory) in the three months before that observation period.

Researchers analyzed biopsies of fungiform papillae—the taste structures on the tongue in 16 individuals with long-term taste loss compared to pre-pandemic and never-infected controls. Using microscopy, immunofluorescence, and RNA in situ hybridization, they found SARS-CoV-2 proteins (spike and nucleocapsid) in the epithelial layers and lamina propria of the papillae. In several cases, negative-strand RNA was also detected, indicating active viral replication in taste tissue up to 40 weeks after infection. The infected papillae showed disrupted taste bud architecture, with missing or misshapen buds and a loss of neurite fibers that normally connect to sensory nerves. Patients with partial recovery over time displayed regrowth of nerve fibers and restoration of papilla structure, while viral protein clearance appeared patchy across the tongue. These findings provide strong evidence that long-term taste dysfunction in COVID-19 is linked to local viral persistence and structural damage rather than solely systemic inflammation. The results underscore that some Long COVID symptoms may stem from direct viral reservoirs in sensory tissues, highlighting the importance of exploring antiviral and regenerative strategies for treatment.

Over two years, most of the 341 people who developed long COVID in a cohort of 548 COVID-19 survivors did not fully recover: only ~8% recovered in the first 24 months. Risk of developing long COVID was higher in females, those with lower education, and those who experienced symptoms like fatigue, headache, tachycardia, respiratory issues, or neurocognitive complaints during acute infection. Certain factors (ICU stay, smell/taste loss, cardiovascular problems) increased odds of recovery, while muscle pain, attention impairment, and breathing or heart rate problems reduced it. Long COVID is not uniform but clusters into subtypes: patients in the “less complex” fatigue-dominated cluster had much better recovery odds than those with more symptoms.

Multiple studies reviewed by Proal et al. identify SARS-CoV-2 RNA or proteins in gut mucosa, skin, olfactory tissues, and other organs from months up to over a year post-infection—even when PCR tests from the respiratory tract are negative. Immune system readouts in these patients often show signs of ongoing activation: broadened or elevated T cell responses, presence of viral protein in plasma or extracellular vesicles, sometimes immune exhaustion markers.

SARS-CoV-2 spike protein triggers infected cells (especially in lung tissue) to fuse into syncytia, which may worsen disease by damaging tissue structure and function. By screening over 3,000 already approved drugs, they found 83 compounds that block spike-driven cell fusion, many of which also reduce viral replication and protect cells in culture. Among these, niclosamide stood out as effective by dampening calcium oscillations and interfering with TMEM16F activity. TMEM16 (ion channel / scramblase) proteins play a central role in syncytium formation by facilitating exposure of phosphatidylserine on cell surfaces.

SARS-CoV-2 infection typically induces strong IgG1 and IgG3 antibody responses, which are good at neutralization, activating complement, and stimulating inflammation. However, in some severe COVID-19 cases, elevated levels of IgG4 have been observed—a subclass of antibodies known for reduced inflammatory activity and poor complement activation. Rubio-Casillas et al. propose that the virus may induce IgG4 synthesis as a strategy to reduce immune pressure and promote immune tolerance, perhaps allowing residual viral antigen or infection to persist.

Children who recover from SARS-CoV-2 infection generate strong and lasting immune responses focused on the viral Spike protein. These responses do not just disappear: over months, many maintain both antibodies and T cell reactivity. Crucially, the antibodies and T cells are not only specific to the infecting strain, but often cross-react with newer variants’ spike proteins—though with reduced strength for more divergent variants.

After SARS-CoV-2 infection, circulating immune cells (T, B, NK cells, monocytes) show altered gene expression that persists well into the post-acute period. Many genes involved in inflammation (especially NF-κB, AP-1, TNF pathways) are upregulated, including genes that are normally regulated in an anti-inflammatory direction under low-dose IL-2 therapy. These pro-inflammatory shifts are detectable for at least 2 months after symptom onset, and in some cases up to 3-4 months. The pattern is distinct from what is seen in influenza or sepsis, suggesting a COVID-specific immune perturbation.

Many individuals who recover from COVID-19 experience persistent neurological symptoms well beyond the acute phase, according to this survey study. Symptoms such as headaches, dizziness, memory or concentration difficulties (“brain fog”), and sensory disturbances are common, and can persist for many months. The study finds that even those with initially mild COVID-19, or who are relatively young, report such long-term neurological sequelae, though risks are higher among those who had more severe acute illness.

In a largely triple-vaccinated adult population infected with the SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant in Western Australia, approximately 18% reported new or ongoing symptoms consistent with Long COVID three months after infection. Fatigue and problems with concentration were the most commonly reported symptoms in this study by the Western Australia Department of Health. Individuals at higher risk included women, middle-aged adults (50-69), those with pre-existing health conditions, people living in rural/remote areas, and those with fewer vaccine doses. Nearly one in five people who had been working or studying before their infection cut back or stopped these activities.

Severe SARS-CoV-2 infection leads to lasting epigenetic reprogramming in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs), detectable up to a year after acute illness. These changes include altered chromatin accessibility favoring inflammatory gene programs and increased myelopoiesis. The amplified epigenetic “memory” gets transmitted to downstream innate immune cells (e.g., monocytes), which display hyper-responsive inflammatory behavior even months later. early high levels of IL-6 during infection contribute to establishing this epigenetic memory, and blocking IL-6 signaling in a mouse model mitigates some of the persistent immune reprogramming. These findings suggest that long-term immune alterations after COVID-19 aren’t just in mature immune cells but are rooted at the stem/progenitor level.

In a group of patients evaluated on average 5.5 months after SARS-CoV-2 infection, researchers found biopsy-proven chronic myocarditis in the heart tissue, including persistent viral RNA (virus presence), ongoing inflammation, and elevated levels of anti-heart autoantibodies. Endomyocardial biopsies confirmed inflammation and viral persistence well beyond the acute phase, even in patients without prior cardiac disease.

In a predominantly Latino, low-education, farmworker population in California, nearly 62% of those who had had a SARS-CoV-2 infection (suspected or confirmed) reported at least one symptom persisting beyond 28 days—meeting a standard operational definition of long COVID. These lingering symptoms (fatigue, dyspnea, smell/taste disturbance) were associated with markers of inflammation (higher CRP), higher BMI, and poorer mental & physical health metrics compared to non-infected or short-symptom individuals.

A prospective cohort study monitoring 136 SARS-CoV-2-infected individuals from within days of diagnosis found that those who later reported persistent symptoms at 4 months (i.e., PASC/Long COVID) had higher early viral loads in nasal swabs, more prolonged infectious virus shedding, and higher plasma nucleocapsid antigen during acute infection than those who fully recovered. Also, they mounted a delayed Spike IgG antibody response compared to non-PASC participants in the early days of illness. Cytokine/inflammatory markers during acute infection did not clearly distinguish future PASC from recovery, suggesting that it’s the viral burden and the ability to mount early humoral responses that may drive long COVID risk.

Investigators analyzed sudden, unexplained deaths during the COVID-19 era by performing post-mortem molecular testing of tissue to detect SARS-CoV-2 RNA. They found that in some cases classified as unexplained, viral RNA was detectable, indicating that COVID-19 might have contributed to mortality in cases where it was not clinically identified.

The SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid (N) protein suppresses apoptosis (cell death) by stabilizing the host anti-apoptotic protein MCL-1, via interaction with USP15 that removes K63-linked ubiquitin from MCL-1. This leads to protection of infected cells from the mitochondrial pro-apoptotic protein Bak, allowing infected cells to survive longer and enabling better viral replication. The effect is demonstrated in multiple cell types, lung organoids, and in mouse models. This anti-apoptotic mechanism isn’t unique to SARS-CoV-2: N protein expression enhances replication of other viral pathogens (IAV, DENV, ZIKV) in co-infection settings, while pharmacologic inhibition of MCL-1 diminishes this effect.

About five months after hospitalisation for moderate to severe COVID-19, a majority (≈61%) of patients exhibit MRI evidence of abnormalities in at least two organs (lung, brain, kidney) compared to non-COVID controls (≈27%). The most notable findings include parenchymal lung damage, white matter lesions and regional brain volume loss, and kidney changes such as altered MRI T1 and impaired corticomedullary differentiation. Heart and liver imaging did not show substantially increased abnormalities in COVID versus control groups. Patients more likely to have multiorgan MRI abnormalities tended to be older, with more comorbidities, and had more severe acute disease (e.g., elevated CRP).

After the rollout of molnupiravir in 2022, SARS-CoV-2 genome sequence databases show distinct mutational signatures (notably elevated G→A and C→T transitions) in certain long phylogenetic branches. These mutational patterns are highly consistent with those seen in clinical cases treated with molnupiravir, especially in specific nucleotide sequence contexts. The study links these long branches to molnupiravir usage by geography, patient age groups, and through matching the mutation spectra of treated vs untreated viruses.

COVID-19 can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo, and balance problems (“audiovestibular symptoms”) in some patients. This study shows that the inner ear’s hair cells and Schwann cells are biologically capable of SARS-CoV-2 infection: they express the receptor ACE2 and proteases (TMPRSS2, FURIN), and in tissue explants, organoids, and OPC models the virus infects hair cells.

This autopsy study created specific PCR tests to track where COVID-19 mRNA vaccines go in the body and for how long after injection. In people who died of other causes, vaccine mRNA was routinely detectable for up to 30 days in several tissues. In a subset, myocardial tissue also contained vaccine mRNA during that window; these samples more often showed healing injury and more macrophages than hearts without detectable vaccine mRNA.

Researchers analyzed autopsy samples from COVID-19 patients and used advanced imaging and RNA assays (RNAscope, including antisense strand detection) to locate viral RNA in coronary plaques. They found SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA, including replicative (antisense) strands, in macrophages within coronary plaques in all examined cases. Plaques with foam cell macrophages (i.e. cholesterol-loaded macrophages) were especially prone to infection. Blocking the entry cofactor NRP-1 reduces infection, suggesting one mechanistic pathway. Infected macrophages and ex vivo plaque tissues mount a strong inflammatory response with release of key cytokines implicated in plaque instability and cardiovascular events.

A previously healthy 62-year-old man developed rapidly progressive neurologic decline—dementia, movement abnormalities, myoclonus—concurrent with COVID-19 infection, with CSF positivity for 14-3-3 protein and no alternative explanations found. Clinical, imaging, and lab findings fulfilled criteria for probable prion disease, though MRI and EEG results were nonspecific. He deteriorated quickly and died within weeks.

Two host proteases, TMPRSS2 and ADAM17, both cleave the ACE2 receptor, but only TMPRSS2’s action increases Spike-mediated viral entry in cell culture. TMPRSS2 cleaves ACE2 in a way that augments virus uptake, while ADAM17's cleavage results in shedding of soluble ACE2, which doesn’t facilitate entry.

In an immunocompromised individual with prolonged Omicron BA.1 infection, SARS-CoV-2 evolved into a novel sub-lineage (BA.1.23) over several weeks, accumulating key spike mutations associated with immune escape. This evolved variant was subsequently transmitted to at least three other patients, some of whom also developed persistent infection, demonstrating that evolution in one host can produce a transmissible, immune-evasive lineage. The study also documents minority viral variants (miSNVs) that later become fixed or appear in onward-transmitted cases, showing intrahost variation as a pool for adaptation. BA.1.23 exhibits substantially reduced neutralization by sera from boosted vaccination or previous BA.1 infection, more so than BA.1 itself.

Eighteen years after surviving SARS, many of the former patients still experience lasting health problems: persistent fatigue, reduced lung function, bone issues (osteoporosis, hip necrosis), and structural lung lesions on CT imaging. While emotional and mental health appear largely recovered, physical and social functioning lag behind that of matched controls. Functional measures, such as respiratory capacity and hip joint performance, remain impaired though somewhat improved compared to earlier follow-ups. At the molecular level, the SARS survivors show long-term abnormalities in metabolism (amino acids, lipids), increased activity of immune pathways (especially B cells, cytotoxic CD8+ T cells), and decreased function in antigen presentation by CD4+ T cells.

Infants infected with SARS-CoV-2 (Omicron or earlier variants) develop robust and long-lived antibody immunity, with (unlike in many adult studies) antibody levels showing no decay for nearly a year (≈300 days) after infection. Their immune reactions in nasal mucosa activate antiviral and interferon pathways early, while systemic inflammation is muted. These findings contrast with adult immune dynamics, where antibodies often wane more quickly and systemic cytokine responses are larger.

SARS-CoV-2 infection can disrupt the blood–brain barrier (BBB). Mechanisms include inflammation, endothelial injury, and cytokine-driven permeability increases that allow viral particles, immune cells, and inflammatory molecules to cross into the brain.

A pilot study in Central India compared young athletes aged 20–30 who had recovered from COVID-19 with those never infected. The post-COVID group had significantly lower VO₂ max and higher resting heart and respiratory rates, indicating reduced cardiorespiratory fitness despite clinical recovery.

In this study of symptomatic adults during the Omicron era, researchers found that SARS-CoV-2 viral loads typically peak 4–5 days after symptom onset, rather than at onset as observed early in the pandemic. As a result, rapid antigen tests are much less sensitive in the first two days of symptoms (30–60%) but reach over 80% sensitivity by day 4. In comparison, influenza A viral loads peaked earlier, on day 2, matching pre-pandemic expectations.

Three previously healthy adults with severe long COVID, suffering from disabling fatigue, cognitive impairment, and exercise intolerance for months after infection each received the casirivimab/imdevimab monoclonal antibody cocktail (against spike protein SARS-CoV-2), leading to rapid, complete remission of all symptoms within one week. The recovery was confirmed by family members and sustained for at least two years.

This cohort study of 248 hospitalized COVID-19 patients found that a subset developed autoantibodies, particularly anti-phospholipid antibodies (16.5%) and, less frequently, antinuclear antibodies (2%). Many of these antibodies persisted for months (e.g., 69% of IgM anti-β2-GPI remained positive), suggesting a durable autoimmune response triggered by SARS-CoV-2 infection. While most autoantibody-positive patients did not experience worse outcomes, IgG anticardiolipin positivity was associated with more severe clinical trajectories.

🧫Using human pancreatic tissue and cell models, researchers show that SARS-CoV-2 infects and replicates in both endocrine and exocrine pancreatic cells. In β cells, infection correlates with fewer insulin secretory granules and blunted insulin release in response to glucose, while exocrine cell infection points to wider pancreatic involvement. Infectious virus was recoverable, confirming productive replication in the pancreas.

Severe COVID-19 patients often exhibit gut fungal dysbiosis, particularly overgrowth of Candida albicans. This is associated with elevated antifungal antibodies, systemic neutrophilia, and lasting transcriptional changes in granulocyte progenitors, indicating durable immune reprogramming. These immune changes persisted for up to a year after recovery, suggesting that gut fungi act as long-term drivers of systemic inflammation.🐁In mouse models, Candida colonization exacerbated lung inflammation during SARS-CoV-2 infection, while antifungal therapy or IL-6 receptor blockade/tocilizumab mitigated these effects. Patients treated with tocilizumab also showed reduced antifungal antibodies and immune reprogramming.

In a large cohort of U.S. Medicare patients aged 65+, early outpatient treatment for COVID-19 with nirmatrelvir-ritonavir (Paxlovid) was associated with a modest but statistically significant reduction in the risk of developing post-COVID-19 condition (Long COVID) symptoms at 4-12 weeks after infection. The untreated group had a ~14.5% incidence of PCC; treatment with nirmatrelvir lowered that to ~11.8%, for an absolute risk reduction of ~2.7%. Molnupiravir also showed some benefit but smaller, with an absolute risk reduction of ~0.8%. Overall, among 3 975 690 outpatients with COVID-19, 57% remained in the study after exclusion. Among them, 19.5% received nirmatrelvir and 2.6% received molnupiravir.

This methodological critique shows that mask trials/meta-analyses conflate infections occurring inside the study’s controlled setting with those acquired outside it, mathematically biasing effect estimates toward the null and yielding over-narrow confidence intervals. A simple correction using the fraction of outside infections (b) reveals that many “no difference” conclusions are uninformative: a wide range of true effects could produce observed risk ratios near 1 when b is large. Re-examining key datasets (including Loeb 2022) and the Cochrane review under this framework, the authors argue that N95s likely provide substantially greater protection than surgical masks, and that accounting for source control and two-way masking magnifies benefits. They also note that reported “adverse events” are mostly mild (discomfort, skin irritation, headaches).

This study shows that SARS-CoV can persistently replicate in human renal tubular epithelial cells, maintaining productive infection with limited cell damage. Over serial passages, the virus evolved, repeatedly selecting M-protein mutations that conferred a fitness advantage in kidney cells—evidence that intrahost/tissue microenvironments can shape coronavirus evolution.

🐁In macaques, replication-competent SARS-CoV-2 was found in alveolar macrophages up to 18 months post-infection, revealing the lung as a long-term viral reservoir. Viral replication was controlled by interferon-γ (IFN-γ), mainly produced by NK cells and CD8+ T cells. However, in cases of viral persistence, NK cells displayed impaired IFN-γ secretion, weakening viral clearance. IFN-γ simultaneously limited viral replication but increased MHC-E expression on macrophages, which blocked NK cell-mediated killing, creating a double-edged effect. Some macaques overcame persistence by generating adaptive NK cells able to bypass MHC-E inhibition.

Pregnant individuals infected with SARS-CoV-2 (6012 of them) have significantly higher risks of serious illness (hospitalization, ICU admission) compared to non-pregnant women of reproductive age also infected, especially for older mothers, those with hypertension or higher BMI, and when infection occurs later in gestation. The study found that preterm birth is markedly more common among SARS-CoV-2 positive pregnancies than among uninfected pregnancies, even if the infection was mild and not hospitalised. However, for other outcomes such as stillbirth, preeclampsia, and cesarean delivery, the differences were less pronounced or not statistically significant. Also, the data precede the Omicron wave, and almost all affected individuals were unvaccinated; vaccination (at least two doses) appeared protective, as none in that subgroup had adverse maternal outcomes in this cohort.

Over the first six months following SARS-CoV-2 infection, the levels of circulating antibodies (especially IgM, IgG) and plasma neutralizing titers drop substantially. However, the immune system retains robust memory via RBD-specific memory B cells, which do not diminish in number and in fact evolve: they acquire more somatic hypermutation and greater neutralizing breadth and potency, even against some RBD mutations. This suggests that although antibody levels fall, the quality of the memory response improves over time. Additionally, antigen persistence in the gut appears to be present in 7 out of 14 individuals up to ~4 months post-infection. Such persistent antigen may help sustain germinal centre activity, driving the ongoing evolution of memory B cells.

Pilot human study using ^89Zr-labelled minibody tracers targeting CD8 to perform total-body PET imaging, coupled with kinetic modelling, to map where CD8⁺ T cells reside and move in both healthy individuals and convalescent COVID-19 patients. Imaging at about 2 months after infection shows elevated tracer uptake in the bone marrow of convalescent patients compared to controls, and follow-up at 4 months suggests this elevated bone marrow uptake remains or even increases. These imaging findings are mirrored by blood assays showing increased CD8+ T cell counts, more activation, and greater memory cell prevalence in the convalescent group.

Using data from 276 essential workers who had cognitive testing both before and after SARS-CoV-2 infection, the researchers found that COVID-19 is associated with a decline in processing speed (cognitive throughput) exceeding what was observed among 217 uninfected individuals. This decline is substantial enough to be equivalent to a decade of aging in that domain. Those with persistent symptoms (Long COVID/PASC) or more severe initial illness show greater decline, indicating a dose-response or severity effect. Other cognitive domains (memory, executive function etc.) showed fewer strong or consistent changes. The findings imply that COVID-19 may have lasting cognitive effects even among individuals not hospitalized, especially if symptoms continue. Monitoring of cognitive health post-COVID may be important, especially for those with lingering symptoms.

Long COVID (PACS) in non-hospitalized individuals around 18 months post-infection is associated with widespread dysregulation of molecular systems, spanning coagulation (hemostasis), metabolic processes, immune/inflammatory signalling, and vascular / angiogenic pathways. The degree of dysregulation is large: about 200 proteins out of 700 analysed were differentially expressed, most (over 90 %) upregulated, many altered cytokines, and significant perturbations in lipid mediators like sphingolipids. These changes suggest lingering disturbances in cardiovascular homeostasis, immune activation, microvascular / endothelial function, and metabolic balance. Although POTS (an autonomic dysfunction marked by orthostatic tachycardia) is commonly observed in some PACS patients and is clinically prominent, this study did not find a distinct molecular profile that separates PACS + POTS from PACS without POTS.

🧫Brain aging involves an accumulation of senescent cells that drive inflammation and transcriptomic “ageing” in human brain organoids. Applying senolytic drugs (dasatinib+quercetin, navitoclax/ABT-737) selectively clears senescent cells, dampens neuroinflammation, and shifts molecular aging clocks toward a younger profile.

Using very large cohorts (over 850,000 first COVID-19 cases, 72,000+ reinfections, and more than 3 million negative-test controls) from Spain and the UK, this study finds that about one in five COVID-19 cases have at least one symptom lasting at least 3 months after infection. However, many people without COVID also have similarly persistent symptoms, meaning distinguishing Long COVID from background symptomatology in the general population is challenging. The study identifies altered smell/taste as the most specific symptom associated with COVID-19, consistently more common among COVID patients than matched negative controls. The risk of persistent symptoms is higher after reinfection than after first infection, and the overall burden of post-acute symptoms declined over time during the study period.

Early, proactive nasal and oral interventions during acute COVID-19 can prevent new-onset smell and taste loss. In this double-blind RCT (n=379), both a saline-only regimen and a regimen with budesonide nasal spray + chlorhexidine mouthwash cut the prevalence of olfactory/gustatory dysfunction by ~3–5× compared with no intervention and also reduced symptom severity.

Klein et al. conducted a cross-sectional immune phenotyping study of ~275 individuals divided into three groups: those with Long COVID (LC) (persistent symptoms), convalescent COVID (recoveries without persistent symptoms, CC), and healthy controls without known infection. Individuals with Long COVID had higher antibody responses against SARS-CoV-2 antigens (especially Spike, S1, RBD) compared with convalescent people without persistent symptoms, even after accounting for vaccination status. They also showed elevated antibody reactivity against other viral pathogens, particularly Epstein-Barr virus antigens. Immune cell subset differences: LC group had higher levels of non-conventional monocytes (CD14^lowCD16^hi), lower levels of certain dendritic cell subsets (cDC1), elevated activated and double-negative B cell subsets. T-cell cytokine production upon stimulation (e.g., IL-2, IL-4, IL-6 from CD4+; some increase also in CD8+) was higher in LC vs controls. Lower cortisol levels also characterize the LC cohort. Autoantibody profiling found many private autoantigen (and GPCR) reactivities but no large difference in number of autoantibody types vs controls; no strong correlation with severity/symptom clusters.

A new monovalent mRNA booster targeting the XBB.1.5 spike protein induces strong neutralizing antibody responses in previously vaccinated individuals, including against a spectrum of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron subvariants. The booster increases both the potency and breadth of neutralization compared to pre-booster levels, demonstrating that updating vaccine antigen to match emerging variants can meaningfully improve cross-variant protection.

Severe COVID-19 patients often show immune dysregulation not explained solely by ACE2-mediated infection. This study demonstrates that receptor for advanced glycation end products (RAGE) acts as an alternative receptor for SARS-CoV-2, enabling viral entry into monocytes, which normally lack ACE2. Single-cell analyses revealed that RAGE pathway activation is a robust marker of disease severity at admission, declining as patients recover. Direct binding of SARS-CoV-2 Spike RBD to RAGE was confirmed experimentally, and inhibition with small-molecule antagonists blocked monocyte infection. The authors also identify candidate therapeutics, including baricitinib and simvastatin, that may dampen RAGE-mediated immune responses.

Comparing sRAGE levels in healthy controls, asymptomatic COVID-19 patients, and those with lung involvement, the study finds that asymptomatic individuals have elevated sRAGE relative to controls, while those with lung involvement have significantly reduced sRAGE, especially in older age. Inflammatory markers like CRP, ferritin, and fibrinogen are higher in lung-involved cases, reinforcing the link between inflammation, lung pathology, and disease severity. These results suggest that the soluble RAGE receptor may act in part as a protective “decoy” against maladaptive RAGE pathway activation in COVID-19, and that reductions in its level associate with worse lung disease.

This study assessed whether people with Post-COVID Condition (PCC, aka Long COVID) exhibit generalized cognitive slowing, compared to people who had COVID but do not have long COVID symptoms (No-PCC), and people who never had COVID (No-COVID). The authors recruited ~270 PCC patients from two clinics in the UK and Germany, and used two web-based cognitive tasks: a Simple Reaction Time (SRT) task, and a more sustained attention task Number Vigilance Test (NVT). They also collected self-report measures of fatigue, depression, sleep quality. They found that PCC patients had substantially slowed reaction times even on the simple task: large delays vs both control groups, consistent across both clinic sites. In SRT, many PCC patients fell multiple standard deviations behind controls. On NVT (more demanding), PCC patients showed slower responses (~150–200 ms slower than both No-COVID and No-PCC controls) and less vigilance. The cognitive slowing was not strongly associated with depression or sleep disturbance (though those were elevated), suggesting that slowing is not entirely explained by mood or sleep problems.

In men infected with the Omicron variant, early post-infection brain imaging reveals detectable structural changes: decreased gray matter thickness in the precuneus and lateral occipital cortex, along with reduced hippocampal volume ratio, relative to pre-infection baselines. A group of 98 male participants had brain MRIs and neuropsychiatric assessments before Omicron wave (“pre-Omicron baseline”), and 61 of them were re-evaluated in the acute/post-Omicron period (mean ~ a few weeks after infection). Some (~17) also had 3-month follow-ups. These neuroanatomical changes occur even though most participants had mild infection and were relatively young (mean age ~43), and follow-up at ~3 months indicates many systemic symptoms improve, but the brain structural differences persist. Clinically, these imaging changes are associated with detectable neuropsychiatric effects: heightened anxiety correlates with cortical thinning in the precuneus; cognitive tests like word fluency link with hippocampal volume. Left precuneus thickness: decreased by about 0.14 mm post-infection compared with pre-Omicron baseline. Right lateral occipital thickness: decreased by ~0.12 mm. Right hippocampus volume ratio (to total intracranial volume): decreased by ~0.02%. Correlations: thinner left precuneus correlated with higher anxiety scores (r ≈ –0.29); smaller right hippocampal ratio correlated with lower word fluency (r ≈ 0.25).

HIV-1 and SARS-CoV-2 differ in how they damage stem-progenitor cells but may share common downstream effects. HIV-1 infects CD4⁺ T cells and indirectly suppresses differentiation of CD34⁺ hematopoietic stem-progenitor cells (HSPCs), in part via altered secretion of miRNAs from infected T cells; this leads to impaired hematopoiesis. By contrast, SARS-CoV-2 directly infects CD133⁺ endothelial stem-progenitor cells (ESPCs) via ACE2, which then likely release miRNAs that dysregulate immune cells (e.g. CD4⁺ T lymphocytes) that themselves do not express ACE2, contributing to cytokine storms and immune dysfunction.

From 1,547 records screened, 25 studies (total 29,213 participants) were included (search to 12 Feb 2023). The pooled incidence of any Long-COVID symptom was 48.6% (95% CI 37.4–59.8). Psychiatric conditions were most frequent, with PTSD ≈ 25% (95% CI 21.1–30.4). Older age (p = 0.027) and hospitalization during acute infection (p = 0.05) were associated with higher Long-COVID frequency.

In a cross-sectional OCT study of 56 people recovered from COVID-19 vs 40 controls, Poças et al. found thinning of ganglion-cell/retinal nerve fiber layers and thickening of the subfoveal choroid, indicating a non-glaucomatous neuropathy-like pattern plus vascular changes in the eye after infection.

Vaccination added on top of previous COVID-19 infection meaningfully improves both the number and quality of spike-specific CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T cells. The enhanced functionality includes increased cytokine production, polyfunctionality, and effector gene expression. Although markers commonly associated with inhibition or exhaustion (PD-1, TIM-3) are upregulated following vaccination, these do not appear to impair functionality, suggesting that hybrid immunity maintains robust effector potential rather than pushing T cells into dysfunction. In contrast, T cells targeting non-spike viral proteins do not receive a comparable boost from vaccination and instead tend to wane or stay the same over time.

This study investigated skeletal muscle pathology in long COVID patients suffering from persistent fatigue, muscle weakness, and exercise intolerance. Biopsies revealed structural vascular changes, including fewer capillaries and thickened basement membranes, alongside immune alterations such as increased CD169⁺ macrophages and complement system activation. Viral RNA was absent, suggesting that symptoms are driven by immune-mediated and vascular sequelae rather than viral persistence. Transcriptomic profiling confirmed upregulation of immune and angiogenesis genes and downregulation of metabolic and mitochondrial pathways, while serum proteomics showed increased complement proteins.

🧫Healthy human neutrophils exposed to SARS-CoV-2 or to supernatant from infected epithelial cells show dysfunctional degranulation: the release of the primary granule enzyme myeloperoxidase is reduced, while elastase release is variably affected, and there is increased shedding of the neutrophil surface CD16 receptor. These changes indicate that SARS-CoV-2 can directly—or through infected epithelia—modulate neutrophil function in ways that may compromise their capacity to respond appropriately. Furthermore, these modified neutrophils negatively affect lymphocyte populations when co-cultured or via their secreted products: there is measurable reduction in B cell, CD4+ T cell, and CD8+ T cell numbers.

🧫A time‐resolved, large‐scale view of how SARS-CoV-2 infection reshapes host cell signaling by measuring phosphorylation and protein abundance changes in infected cells showed activation of CK2 and p38 MAPK signaling, suppression of mitotic kinases (which leads to cell cycle arrest), and cytoskeletal changes such as the formation of filopodia bearing viral particles. The infection also induced cytokine responses, suggesting the virus triggers innate immune signaling along with hijacking of host cell machinery. By integrating the phosphoproteomics data with drug‐kinase interaction maps, the authors identified several kinases whose inhibition (e.g. of CK2, p38, CDKs, AXL, PIKFYVE) reduced virus replication in vitro

🧫SARS-CoV-2 remodels the cytoskeleton of infected cells to possibly facilitate spread between cells. The authors used high-resolution microscopy to show that infected cells produce more and longer filopodia, that filopodia from different cells form bridges, and that tunneling nanotubes may provide routes for intercellular viral transfer. Viral particles are observed bound to filopodia, within vesicles, and in regions of cell contact, suggesting multiple means by which the virus may move from cell to cell beyond just release into the extracellular space. These structural changes include rearrangements in actin, microtubules, and intermediate filaments, as well as increased ribosomal activity and mitochondrial alterations in infected cells. The 3D reconstructions permitted visualization of “viral extrusion” zones and clusters of filopodial connections at sites of high viral load.

🧫This study uses helium-ion microscopy to uncover alternative intra-cytoplasmic transmission routes for SARS-CoV-2 in infected Vero E6 cells, highlighting tunneling nanotubes (TNT), cell fusion (syncytia), and extracellular vesicles (EV) as key mechanisms. TNT, extending over 40 microns, connect infected cells for direct cytoplasmic exchange, while syncytia form multinucleated clusters via spike protein-induced fusion, and EVs bud from membranes to potentially shuttle viral RNA. By proposing drugs like colchicine, niclosamide, and chloroquine as targeted interventions, the research offers pathophysiological insights and therapeutic avenues, though it notes limitations such as the need for human cell validation and specific viral markers.

🧫SARS-CoV-2 typically infects cells by binding to the ACE2 receptor, which is expressed in many epithelial tissues but is scarcely present in neuronal cells. Yet neurological symptoms are common in acute COVID-19 and long COVID, and viral RNA has been found in brains of some patients. To address how neurons might become infected despite low ACE2, the authors studied co-cultures of permissive Vero E6 epithelial cells (which are infected in the usual way) and non-permissive neuronal cells. They found that SARS-CoV-2 triggers formation of tunneling nanotubes (TNTs) between cells, through which the virus can travel. Inside TNTs, they observed double-membrane vesicles and other structures associated with viral replication (such as nonstructural protein 3, dsRNA), indicating that not only is virus cargo transported but replication-related events occur.

🧫SARS-CoV-2 infection promotes formation of actin-rich filopodia in host cells by activating Cdc42 and engaging actin regulators such as fascin, formins, and the Arp2/3 complex. These filopodia act as “highways” for virus particles or virus-like particles, which use two modes — “surfing” along the filopodial shaft or “grabbing” via attachment then retraction — to reach entry hotspots on target cells more efficiently than via non-protruded plasma membrane. Disrupting either Cdc42 activity or the actin crosslinker fascin significantly reduces viral entry.

This study assessed documentation of Long COVID (post-COVID-19 condition, PCC) among nearly 389,000 U.S. veterans who tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 during the period October 2021 to January 2023. They found that by 12 months after infection, about 5.3% had the ICD-10 code U09.9 in their medical record, indicating a formal clinical recognition of Long COVID. Patients more likely to have this code were older, female, Hispanic or Latino, had more comorbidities or severe acute COVID infection (hospitalization/ventilation), and had more symptoms during the acute phase. Vaccination (especially booster doses) was associated with lower likelihood of Long COVID documentation. Among those who did receive the U09.9 code, the most frequently documented persistent symptoms included shortness of breath, fatigue or exhaustion, cough, cognitive impairment (“brain fog”), and disturbances in smell or taste. The study also found considerable variation across regions and VA facilities in how often U09.9 was used, with higher usage in places with dedicated Long COVID or PCC clinics.

This study rigorously compared long-term health impacts of hospitalization for COVID-19 versus hospitalization for seasonal influenza, following patients for up to 18 months. It found that COVID-19 survivors face substantially greater risks of death, hospital readmission, and new health problems in a wide array of organ systems. The COVID-19 cohort had higher rates for ~68% of the measured adverse health outcomes, whereas influenza predominantly affected pulmonary outcomes more severely. Importantly, although both diseases show significant long‐term burdens beyond the immediate acute phase, COVID-19’s effects are more multi‐systemic: the disease imposes greater risk of long‐term damage across cardiovascular, neurological, kidney, metabolic, mental health, and other systems. Influenza remains more exclusively a respiratory illness in this comparison.

Syncytia formation by SARS-CoV-2 increases the virus’s resistance to interferons and neutralizing antibodies. The study shows that spike protein variants that promote more cell-cell fusion (i.e. more fusogenic S proteins) are better able to withstand interferon treatment in vitro, in airway organ cultures, and in hACE2 transgenic mice. At the same time, higher fusogenicity correlates with reduced neutralization by antibody reagents, meaning that immune pressure favors variants that can fuse infected cells into syncytia. Despite the replication cost of forming syncytia under low immune pressure, the authors suggest that the immune environment in the host selects for fusogenic spike variants. These findings explain why variants with more cell-cell fusion capacity (such as certain Delta or Omicron derivatives) are being selected, and highlight syncytia formation as a mechanism of immune evasion by SARS-CoV-2.

🧫SARS-CoV-2 infection causes distinctive ultrastructural changes in host cells compared to SARS-CoV-1, especially a marked accumulation of lipid droplets in infected cells (both in cultured Vero E6 cells and in type II lung pneumocytes of COVID-19 patients). These lipid droplets often contact mitochondria, and in some cases viral particles are located in or near lipolysosome-like structures, suggesting that lipid metabolic changes are part of the cytopathic effect. Other hallmarks include vacuole formation, mitochondrial swelling/damaged cristae, and general organelle disruption.

🐒SARS-CoV-2 in rhesus macaques can directly infect neurons in the olfactory cortex (and connected regions) within a week of infection, as shown by detection of viral nucleocapsid, spike proteins, and dsRNA. The infection is more pronounced in older and diabetic animals. Although glial cells also show viral markers, neurons carry the bulk of productive infection signals. The virus appears to spread along olfactory neural circuitry, reaching secondary olfactory regions especially in aged animals. Accompanying this neurotropism is strong neuroinflammation and vascular disruption: glial activation, microglial‐mediated synaptic pruning (loss of synaptic markers), myelin degradation, blood vessel and BBB alterations, neutrophil recruitment, among others.

Omicron SARS-CoV-2 variant, which favors entry via clathrin-mediated endocytosis (CME), more strongly induces premature cellular senescence compared to the Delta variant. In lung tissues from deceased patients, Omicron infection was associated with elevated expression of senescence markers such as p16 and p21. Experiments in cultured cells and lung tissue confirm that Omicron but not Delta triggers senescence‐associated secretory phenotypes (SASP) and related gene expression changes.

This large VA cohort study followed 138,818 people with SARS-CoV-2 infection and nearly 6 million controls for 2 years and evaluated mortality, hospitalization and 80 prespecified post-acute sequelae. Risks for many sequelae declined over time — 69% of examined sequelae among nonhospitalized people became not significant by 2 years — but a set of pulmonary, coagulation/hematologic, gastrointestinal, musculoskeletal and metabolic outcomes (including new or worsened diabetes) remained elevated at 2 years, and hospitalized patients retained higher mortality and more persistent sequelae

🧫The authors used cultured human nasal epithelial cells to compare common cold viruses with more severe coronaviruses and influenza, finding that mild viruses trigger fast interferon (IFN) responses that mediate viral clearance in the nose. By contrast, lethal coronaviruses (like MERS-CoV) or SARS-CoV-2 employ mechanisms to delay or suppress IFN signaling, leading to persistent replication in nasal epithelium. Elevated temperature (37°C) strengthens IFN responses and helps suppress replication in many viruses. A noteworthy finding is that the Omicron BA.1 variant of SARS-CoV-2 partly behaves like a mild virus in some respects (stronger IFN induction) but resists IFN‐mediated suppression and is not cleared by nasal epithelium, showing reduced temperature sensitivity.

Elderly hospitalized COVID-19 patients with higher levels of bacterial DNA in their blood early in admission had significantly worse outcomes: increased mortality, more severe immune dysregulation (higher neutrophils, lower IFN-α), and a higher likelihood of having diabetes. After controlling for age, frailty, COPD, and other laboratory markers, BB-DNA remained an independent predictor of in-hospital death. The findings support the idea that bacterial translocation—possibly from impaired mucosal or intestinal barriers—contributes to pathogenesis in severe COVID-19 in older patients, and that BB-DNA may serve as a useful prognostic biomarker.

🧫The paper demonstrates that SARS-CoV-2 spike protein (and heat-inactivated virus) triggers robust mitochondrial and inflammatory responses in human microglial cells. Treated microglia show elevated cytokine and ACE2 expression, activation of HIF-1α and NLRP3 inflammasome, enhanced reactive oxygen species, and morphological changes such as mitochondrial fragmentation and signs of apoptosis. The spike protein alone is sufficient to perturb mitochondrial bioenergetics, raising both basal and maximal oxygen consumption rates.

COVID-19 is frequently associated with smell loss, which has led to speculation that SARS-CoV-2 might trigger inflammation or neurodegenerative changes in the olfactory pathway. To test this, the authors performed post-mortem immunohistochemical studies of the olfactory bulb and tract in 22 COVID-19 patients versus controls (healthy and those with known neurological and neurodegenerative conditions). They assessed microglial activation (via CD68) and presence of characteristic protein-pathologies (phosphorylated α-synuclein, phosphorylated tau, amyloid-β) particularly in the anterior olfactory nucleus (AON). They found that COVID-19 per se did not show a widespread, COVID-specific elevation in microglial activation or proteinopathy in the olfactory bulb/tract compared to healthy controls. Most increases in neurodegenerative markers (tau, α-synuclein) were observed in individuals already having known disease (e.g. Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s). Also, age was inversely correlated with microglial activation in COVID-19 cases.

SARS-CoV-2 can invade the brain, especially targeting the hypothalamus, via both bloodstream and olfactory (nose-to-brain) routes, infecting neurons such as GnRH neurons and support cells such as tanycytes. Evidence includes detection of viral RNA and spike protein in brain tissues of deceased COVID-19 patients, hormonal profiles in male survivors showing low testosterone without expected gonadotropin feedback, and correlations of these hormonal disruptions with long COVID symptoms like brain fog, metabolic dysregulation, and perhaps sexual/reproductive issues.

The article argues that the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 not only uses ACE2 but also binds heavily sialylated glycan structures on red blood cells, platelets, and endothelial cells, leading to RBC aggregation, microvascular blockage, hypoxia, and vascular damage. These processes help explain a number of severe outcomes in COVID-19, including thrombosis, myocarditis, and multi‐organ hypoxia. The authors also correlate known risk factors such as age, obesity, and diabetes with higher RBC clotting/aggregability, which may magnify the impact of glycan‐mediated binding. They contrast SARS-CoV-2 with benign human betacoronaviruses that express hemagglutinin esterase (which cleaves sialic acids), suggesting this difference helps explain virulence.

🧫Murata et al. developed a 3D human cardiac microtissue (human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived) platform to model persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection, finding that mild infection can persist for at least a month with minimal immediate functional impairment. Under simulated ischemic (hypoxic) stress, however, the tissues show viral reactivation, upregulation of ACE2 and spike protein, functional decline, and vascular disruption. They also measured inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α, IL-1β) and found elevation in the culture supernatants after hypoxia/reperfusion stress. Their findings support a scenario where latent or chronic SARS-CoV-2 in the heart might act as a “time bomb,” triggering overt cardiac injury under additional stress.

Hikmet et al. mapped where the human ACE2 protein is present across a wide range of tissues and cell types, combining immunohistochemistry and transcriptomic data. They found that ACE2 is abundantly expressed in non-respiratory tissues (intestine, kidney, heart, reproductive tissues, etc.), while in the respiratory tract the expression is low or limited to few cells in some individuals. These findings suggest that while ACE2 is likely to mediate viral entry, the low abundance in lung/airway tissues might mean other factors (co-receptors, or small specialized cell subsets) are important for SARS-CoV-2 infection of the respiratory tract.

This study reveals that immune cells in the blood (PBMCs) of COVID-19 patients and convalescent individuals harbor diverse intracellular bacterial species, and that the abundance of particular bacteria differs between healthy, infected, and recovered states. By analyzing non-human RNA reads from single-cell sequencing, the authors identified 76 bacterial species overall, of which 16 showed statistically significant differences across health groups. Notably, certain bacteria were enriched in specific immune cell types (memory B cells, naïve T cells, Tregs, etc.), and some pathogenic species were especially elevated during acute SARS-CoV-2 infection, hinting at possible interactions between bacterial presence and disease state.
