The findings suggest that scRNA-seq can go beyond profiling host transcripts to also detect intracellular microbes, potentially opening a window into how such microbes may contribute to immune modulation or disease severity in COVID-19. However, the functional roles of these intracellular microbes remain unclear, and whether they are causative, opportunistic, or simply passengers during infection and recovery is not resolved by this work.

More than one-third of individuals assessed around 11 months after COVID-19 infection exhibited cognitive impairment. Neurocognitive functioning was inversely correlated with LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) blood levels, a potential biomarker of disease severity. Common risk factors for having cognitive problems included older age, male sex, less education, greater disease severity during the acute phase, and specific symptoms like anosmia and dyspnea. Those with impaired cognition also tended to have higher levels of depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress, and worse general functioning. In this study, from 1,344 screened, only 736 entered the screening phase, and 402 completed the baseline in-depth assessment. Those who stayed were older, more often male, less educated, had more severe COVID-19, and worse MoCA scores than those who dropped out.

This study shows that the capacity of neutrophils to generate NETs when exposed to plasma (NETosis induction) is a sensitive measure that tracks with both acute COVID-19 severity and long COVID, more so than measurement of NET fragments like MPO-DNA complexes. In acute disease, markers of platelet activation and coagulation were elevated, and NETosis induction correlated with these and with how severe/long the disease was. Treatment (dexamethasone) and recovery reduce this induction. In long COVID, even after convalescence, patients maintain a heightened NETosis induction capacity despite having similar levels of NET fragments to other recovered patients.

Vaccination with mRNA COVID-19 vaccines in children aged 5-17 years who are exposed to the Omicron variant is associated with significantly reduced odds of experiencing post-COVID conditions (PCC; symptoms persisting or new one month after infection). Fully vaccinated children had about 34% lower odds of reporting one or more PCC symptoms, 48% lower odds of reporting two or more symptoms, and roughly 47% lower odds of respiratory symptoms compared to unvaccinated children. The analysis controlled for factors like age, health status, etc.

A survey (n ≈ 276,840 respondents) found that most people who get symptomatic COVID-19 in England recover within 1–2 weeks. However, a significant fraction continue to have symptoms: about 7.5% report symptoms lasting 12 weeks or more (Long COVID), and ≈5.2% still have symptoms at 52 weeks or beyond. Key risk factors for longer symptom persistence include female sex, having pre-existing health conditions, more severe initial illness, earlier infection (wild-type variant), and higher socio-economic deprivation. Conversely, people infected during the Omicron-dominant period were much less likely to have persistent symptoms. Those with long-lasting symptoms report substantially worse quality of life, mental health, and more frequent, burdensome symptoms (such as fatigue, difficulty thinking or concentrating, breathlessness, loss of smell or taste) compared to both recovered COVID cases and people never infected.

This preprint compares immune cell profiles of HIV/AIDS and COVID-19 patients and finds that both diseases cause reductions in several lymphocyte subpopulations. CD4+ T helper cells are similarly depleted in both, but COVID-19 shows much more severe depletion of CD8+ cytotoxic T cells and NK cells. B cell counts are somewhat reduced in both, though not significantly different across the diseases. These distinct patterns suggest that while both viruses lead to lymphopenia, the immune dysregulation in COVID-19 involves more profound suppression of CD8+ T cells and innate immune NK cells, which may contribute to the acute disease severity.

In a cohort of infants born in a low-income region of Brazil, children exposed in utero to maternal SARS-CoV-2 infection (among mothers unvaccinated at the time) were followed for the first year of life and compared with unexposed children. Neurodevelopmental evaluations at multiple time points revealed that about 20% of exposed infants had neurodevelopmental delays by 12 months, compared to under 6% in controls, giving a relative risk of about 3.44. These delays were particularly evident in fine motor and personal-social domains. The pattern of impairment varied over time in exposed infants: high at 4 months, low at 6 months, rising again at 12 months. 137 children were followed for one year: 69 with prenatal exposure (“exposed group”, EG) and 68 unexposed (“control group”, CG). Neurodevelopment was assessed repeatedly (at 1,2,3,4,5,6,9,12 months) using the Guide for Monitoring Child Development in the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness context. For the exposed group, additional assessments at 4, 6, and 12 months used the Ages & Stages Questionnaire (ASQ-3). Demographics between groups were broadly similar.

Portable HEPA-filter + UV air filtration devices can effectively remove airborne SARS-CoV-2 RNA in a hospital ward environment, especially in less severe settings (non-ICU). When the filters were active, SARS-CoV-2 was not detected in multiple air samples; when inactive, it was again detectible. The ICU, however, showed lower baseline detection and the filtration made less difference in detection of SARS-CoV-2 specifically. Beyond SARS-CoV-2, the filtration systems also reduced the presence of other airborne pathogens (bacteria, fungi, etc.) in both settings.

Two infant cases are described where maternal COVID-19 infection in the second trimester, despite maternal recovery before delivery and negative neonatal PCR tests, was followed by serious neurologic injury in the newborns: seizures, developmental delay, microcephaly, brain tissue atrophy. Examination of the placentas showed SARS-CoV-2 viral proteins, vascular malperfusion, elevated inflammatory and oxidative stress markers, and reduced hCG. In one fatal case, SARS-CoV-2 proteins were also found in the infant’s brain at autopsy, suggesting possible direct brain infection. The study suggests that in utero exposure to SARS-CoV-2 can lead to brain injury via placental inflammation and dysfunction, even in absence of vertical transmission detectable at birth, and that current fetal monitoring may miss these harms.

During acute COVID-19 illness, patients hospitalized with neurological complications show elevated biomarkers of neuroglial damage (NfL, GFAP, tTau, UCH-L1), along with elevated cytokines and the presence of autoantibodies, particularly in those with altered consciousness. This suggests that both innate and adaptive immune dysregulation are involved in the brain injury that occurs in COVID-19. The study identifies specific inflammatory mediators (e.g. IL-6, IL-12p40, HGF, CCL2, IL-1RA) that correlate with the severity of neurological involvement. Autoantibodies against neuronal/glial proteins are more frequent among those with neurological symptoms. Beyond the acute phase, even after systemic inflammation and autoantibody levels decline, markers of brain injury (notably NfL and GFAP) remain elevated in people who had neurological complications. This indicates that some forms of brain injury in COVID-19 may be long-lasting or slow to resolve, despite resolution of overt inflammation.

This study followed over 2,200 adult patients with COVID-19 in recovery clinics in British Columbia, examining their kidney function, primarily through eGFR, over 12 months from about 3 months post infection. While roughly half maintained “normal” kidney filtration rates, there was on average a decline of ~3 mL/min/1.73 m² over that year—about a 3.4% decrease from baseline. Only a small minority (<5%) had severely reduced kidney function. Urine protein levels (via UACR) were also part of the analyses, though the most pronounced findings concerned the eGFR declines.

The PROTECT study of over 3,100 UK adults aged 50+ found that during the COVID-19 pandemic there was a measurable acceleration of decline in working memory and executive function compared with pre-pandemic trajectories, with the first pandemic year showing the biggest drop. Some of the decline in working memory persisted into the second pandemic year. Subgroups—people with mild cognitive impairment and those who had COVID-19—had larger declines. Self-reported lifestyle and psychosocial factors such as reduced physical activity, increased alcohol consumption, depression, and loneliness were associated with worse cognitive outcomes. Whether or not participants had had COVID-19 was based on self-report rather than confirmed PCR/antibody testing.

Long COVID patients who experience post-exertional malaise show substantially reduced exercise capacity compared to recovered controls, largely due to impairments in skeletal muscle rather than cardiovascular or purely ventilatory limitations. Their muscles have more fatigue-prone, glycolytic fibers, smaller oxidative fibers, and reduced mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation. After an exercise challenge, these impairments worsen: metabolic disturbances intensify, muscle damage increases, immune cell infiltration occurs, and amyloid‐containing deposits accumulate in muscle tissue. Importantly, the study did not find elevated levels of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein in skeletal muscle of Long COVID patients relative to controls, before or after PEM induction, implying that viral persistence (at least of that protein in muscle) is not the main driver of these muscle deficits.

People who had received the XBB.1.5-adapted vaccine had substantially lower odds of testing positive among those seeking care, with adjusted odds ratios around 0.4 for hospitalization, ED/urgent care, and outpatient settings—meaning roughly 60% or so lower risk compared to those who did not have the adapted vaccine. Older vaccine versions (non-XBB.1.5) provided much less protection in comparison.

Coronaviruses like the mouse hepatitis virus can infect the central nervous system (CNS) and establish both acute and persistent infection. In acute infection, virus‐specific T cells are crucial: CD8⁺ T cells kill infected microglia and astrocytes, while interferon-γ is required to suppress virus in oligodendrocytes. To avoid excessive damage in CNS tissue, after the acute phase, cytolytic T cell functions are downregulated and virus‐specific antibody responses in the CNS increase. These antibodies are necessary to prevent reappearance of infectious virus; even during persistence, the virus remains replication competent and can resurface without antibody control.

🐁In rats, RSV reinfection caused worse kidney injury than primary infection, with higher protein leakage in urine, lower serum albumin, and structural glomerular damage (podocyte effacement, mesangial proliferation). These effects were dose-dependent and timing-dependent, peaking when the reinfection came 14 days after the first exposure. Mechanistically, reinfection skewed immunity: dendritic cells matured, CD8 T cells increased, the CD4/CD8 ratio decreased, and IL-6/IL-17 surged. RSV F protein persisted in glomeruli up to day 56, implying direct viral involvement in addition to immune-mediated injury. Overall, RSV can directly and indirectly worsen renal damage during reinfection.

More than half (56%) of adults in a Los Angeles County cohort who seroconverted during the Omicron wave were unaware that they had been infected with SARS-CoV-2. Among those unaware, only a small proportion had symptoms, which they often attributed to non-COVID causes. Awareness was somewhat greater among younger individuals, males, and healthcare workers. The study highlights that many Omicron infections go undetected by individuals themselves, even among vaccinated populations.

17 Medical students who had mild COVID-19 at least six months earlier were compared to 18 non-infected peers to look for long-term cognitive effects. While overall attention and combined visual + auditory working memory scores were similar between the two groups, those who had COVID-19 underperformed significantly on auditory working memory tasks, but not on visual working memory.

This study followed 29 hospitalized COVID-19 patients for one year and tested many immune markers during the acute infection to see which might predict development of long COVID. Of all the measures tested — including cytokines, T cell activation, exhaustion, NK/monocyte profiles — the only strong predictor was the degree of apoptosis (programmed cell death) in CD4⁺ helper T cells during the acute phase: people with higher levels were significantly more likely to report long COVID one year later.The findings suggest that early loss of CD4⁺ T cells may set the stage for downstream problems (viral persistence, latent virus reactivation, immune dysregulation, etc.) that contribute to long COVID.

The authors conclude that azvudine has satisfactory effectiveness and acceptable safety in this older cohort, suggesting it could be considered a treatment option for elderly patients with mild to moderate COVID-19. From treatment initiation to nucleic acid negative (NANC) conversion, the median was 8 days for azvudine vs 9 days for nirmatrelvir/ritonavir. Those on azvudine had a median time from symptom onset to NANC of 14 days, compared to 15 days for nirmatrelvir/ritonavir, and 19 days for standard of care. However, being observational and with a small sample size, the findings would need confirmation in larger or randomized studies.

This study examined 16 individuals experiencing long-term fatigue, weakness, or myalgia 5 to 14 months after a COVID-19 infection of mild to moderate severity. Through electromyographic testing and detailed examination of muscle biopsies (light and electron microscopy), the authors found that a large proportion of patients exhibit structural muscle changes: atrophy, signs of fiber regeneration, mitochondrial dysfunction (loss of COX activity, abnormal cristae, subsarcolemmal mitochondrial accumulation), inflammation involving T cells and HLA-ABC expression, and significant capillary injury including alterations in the basal lamina and capillary cells. These findings indicate that skeletal muscle pathology — a myopathy — is likely a significant contributor to fatigue in long COVID. The involvement of mitochondrial impairment and microvascular damage suggests that reduced energy supply and oxygen/nutrient delivery play a role.

In this 2-year follow-up of COVID-19 cases from early 2020 in Korea, over 60% of participants who completed all follow-ups continued to report at least one symptom of long COVID, most commonly fatigue, memory issues, concentration difficulties, and insomnia. Although overall quality of life improved over time, a substantial proportion still suffered from anxiety or depression even after two years post-infection. Despite high vaccine uptake after infection (most had at least two doses), neither vaccination status nor number of doses showed a statistically meaningful reduction in neuropsychiatric long COVID symptoms at 24 months.

This study followed 351 individuals who were hospitalized with COVID-19 and assessed them about a year later, comparing them to nearly 3,000 matched controls. It found that cognitive deficits were still present at 1 year, affecting multiple cognitive domains (not just memory or executive function), and these deficits occurred even in people who had not been diagnosed with neurological complications during their acute COVID-19 illness. Biomarker tests revealed elevated levels of brain injury markers (such as GFAP and NfL), and MRI scans showed reduced grey matter volume in key brain regions (notably the anterior cingulate cortex). The severity of the initial illness, having had encephalopathy, and psychiatric symptoms post-COVID were associated with worse outcomes. Although there was some improvement over time in the subset with longitudinal data, recovery seemed only partial and appeared to plateau.

A vaccinated adult male in Brazil, who had no underlying health conditions, first contracted an Omicron BA.1.1 infection. Sixteen days after the first infection was detected, he acquired a second distinct infection with Omicron BA.2, confirmed by RT-qPCR and genetic sequencing. Both infections produced symptoms lasting about a week, with a return to daily activities in between.

This cross-sectional study examined endoscopic biopsies from 249 patients with a prior PCR-confirmed COVID-19 infection. Using immunohistochemistry, SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid proteins were detected in 30.5% of cases, with significantly higher prevalence in upper GI tract biopsies than in lower GI samples. Viral persistence was not linked to vaccination status, number of infections, or time since the last infection. Instead, smoking and diabetes were identified as major risk factors for persistent gut infection.

Long COVID (LC) is associated with lasting immune changes: eight months after acute SARS-CoV-2 infection, people with LC show evidence of ongoing systemic inflammation, immune cell subset perturbations, and elevated antibody levels compared to people who have fully recovered. Specifically, CD4+ T cell populations in LC are more likely to express markers that allow them to home to inflamed tissues, and SARS-CoV-2-specific CD8+ T cells show exhaustion signatures. There is also a miscoordination between T-cell and B-cell (antibody) responses in LC, suggesting that though both adaptive arms are active, they are not working in a well-orchestrated way. These immune irregularities may underlie the persistent symptoms seen in LC — such as fatigue, cognitive issues, sleep disturbances — perhaps driven by ongoing antigen exposure or dysregulated immune signaling.

Long COVID patients, prior to vaccination, display two distinct types of adaptive immune responses. One group (LC+) is seropositive and shows strong, coordinated antibody and CD4+ T cell responses to SARS-CoV-2 (and breadth comparable to recovered people), while the other (LC−) is seronegative by standard assays, with low or undetectable antibody responses and only partially detectable T cell responses even with more sensitive assays. Both groups report persistent symptoms of similar severity, indicating that immune response strength or detectability does not map straightforwardly onto symptom burden. These findings suggest that long COVID is not a single immunological state but may have (at least) two subtypes: one where the immune system has mounted a strong antiviral adaptive response but symptoms persist (potentially via immunopathology or chronic antigen exposure), and another where the antiviral response is weak, which might allow antigen persistence or inadequate clearance.

Kloc et al. propose that nicotine might modulate lung macrophage responses via nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (notably α7 nAChR) to suppress excessive pro-inflammatory cytokine release (a cytokine storm) in COVID-19, offering a mechanistic hypothesis for observed lower-than-expected rates of smokers among severe COVID-19 cases. They suggest that nicotine stimulation of cholinergic pathways in macrophages could tip the balance toward controlled inflammation rather than runaway immune activation. They emphasize that their suggestion is theoretical, not clinical advice, and that many variables (dose, timing, receptor expression, comorbidities) complicate the idea.

🐁The study shows that mice lacking adaptive immune cells (B and T lymphocytes) infected with mouse-adapted SARS-CoV-2 do not lose weight and exhibit minimal lung inflammation and cytokine release, despite supporting viral replication. Thus, while adaptive immunity is required to clear the virus, its activation also drives much of the tissue pathology associated with COVID-19.

This clinical trial in critically ill COVID-19 patients under mechanical ventilation tested whether nicotine patches might reduce mortality or improve recovery, hypothesizing that nicotine’s interaction with the nicotinic cholinergic system could modulate inflammation or ACE2 expression. However, the study found no significant effects — 28-day mortality was the same in nicotine and placebo arms (28% each), and secondary endpoints (ventilator-free days, extubation timing, organ failure support) also showed no advantage. Nicotine was well tolerated with few adverse events, but conferred no clinical benefit.

SARS-CoV-2 and HIV-1 share some superficial similarities—they are both enveloped, positive single-stranded RNA viruses with spike glycoproteins mediating entry—but differ substantially in their replication cycles, host interactions, and immune evasion strategies. SARS-CoV-2 does not integrate into the host genome, replicates in the cytoplasm with proofreading, and uses ACE2 (plus proteases) for cell entry, leading to a relatively faster replication cycle. In contrast, HIV-1 reverse-transcribes its RNA, integrates into host DNA, uses CD4 plus co-receptors for entry, has high error rates (hence high diversity), and establishes latent infection, which makes eradication extremely difficult. Because of these mechanistic differences, their interactions with the immune system diverge: HIV-1’s dense glycan shield, latent reservoirs, and high mutation rate impede development of broadly neutralizing antibodies, while SARS-CoV-2 tends to be more “open” to vaccine-elicited neutralizing immune responses, despite also evolving escape variants.

In a large national cohort of Brazilian children hospitalized with severe acute respiratory infection, this study compared in-hospital mortality across SARS-CoV-2 and seasonal respiratory viruses. SARS-CoV-2 was the predominant virus and carried the highest 30-day fatality risk (~6.5 %) compared with influenza, RSV, adenovirus, other viruses, or coinfections. After adjusting for competing risks, SARS-CoV-2 positivity was associated with a roughly threefold higher hazard of death relative to SARS-CoV-2–negative cases. Across viral etiologies, lower oxygen saturation at admission, presence of comorbidities, and being hospitalized in the North or Northeast regions of Brazil were independent predictors of death.

This pilot study provides evidence that SARS-CoV-2 actively replicates in the gut of nearly half of hospitalized COVID-19 patients, including those without gastrointestinal symptoms. From 15 hospitalized COVID-19 patients, the authors detected active viral transcription in 7 (47%) patients, even in the absence of GI symptoms. Viral transcriptional signatures persisted in stool for days after clearance from the respiratory tract, suggesting prolonged quiescent GI infection and a potential role in fecal–oral transmission. Patients with high fecal viral activity had stool microbiota enriched in opportunistic pathogens (Collinsella aerofaciens, Collinsella tanakaei, Streptococcus infantis, Morganella morganii) and showed increased bacterial functional capacity for nucleotide, amino acid biosynthesis, and glycolysis. In contrast, those with low or no viral activity had more short-chain fatty acid–producing bacteria (Parabacteroides merdae, Bacteroides stercoris, Alistipes onderdonkii, Lachnospiraceae species), which are linked to immune regulation.

Diorio et al. show that children hospitalized with SARS-CoV-2 infection, including those with minimal symptoms, frequently have elevated levels of the complement activation biomarker sC5b9 compared to healthy controls, and many meet clinical criteria for thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA). The elevation in sC5b9 was seen across minimal, severe COVID-19, and MIS-C groups, and correlated with markers of renal stress (e.g. creatinine).

Analyzing over 2.17 million SARS-CoV-2 raw-read datasets with a unified workflow, the study estimates co-infection in ~0.35% of cases and uses two complementary methods to detect intra-host recombination. Co-infections tracked periods of variant co-circulation (especially Delta–Omicron BA.1), and recombination signals were most detectable where lineage-defining mutations are dense. Because artefacts (PCR chimeras, primer bias, contamination) can masquerade as recombinants, the authors lay out practical safeguards (including a ~0.1 recombinant-read threshold) and show hotspots at gene boundaries plus three intergenic hotspots for Delta–Omicron BA.1.

This study followed 113 COVID-19 patients up to one year post-infection (plus healthy controls) to investigate why some develop Long COVID while others recover. Long COVID is associated with a sustained abnormal activation of the complement system (both classical and alternative pathways) that doesn’t return to baseline, unlike in people who recover. In addition, those with active Long COVID show elevated markers of blood cell damage, platelet activation, and monocyte-platelet interactions, all hinting at ongoing inflammation and coagulation (thromboinflammation). The study also found that higher antibody levels against herpesviruses might be contributing to triggering the classical complement pathway. The results point to specific protein signatures in blood that could serve as biomarkers to distinguish Long COVID patients from recovered ones, and suggest that complement and coagulation pathways are potential therapeutic targets.

The authors differentiated dopaminergic (DA) neurons from human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs), exposed them to SARS-CoV-2, and assessed infection, transcriptional changes, and cell state. They observed that only a minority (~5 %) of DA neurons become infected, but that is sufficient to trigger downstream senescence and inflammation. The authors validated this phenomenon using postmortem human substantia nigra tissue from COVID-19 patients, finding SARS-CoV-2 transcripts (though at low levels) and an inflammatory/senescence signature, along with reduced numbers of neuromelanin-positive and tyrosine-hydroxylase-positive DA neurons in severely affected patients. They also performed a drug screen and identified FDA-approved drugs (riluzole, metformin, imatinib) that can reduce viral infection and rescue the senescence phenotype in DA neurons.

This medRxiv preprint compares antibody subclass responses after repeated mRNA versus protein-based COVID-19 vaccination. Consistent with prior observations, repeated mRNA vaccination is associated with higher proportions of Spike-specific IgG4 and lower Fc-effector surrogates (markers tied to ADCP/ADCC/ADCD). Repeated dosing with Novavax (protein subunit), by contrast, did not show notable IgG4 increases and instead boosted IgG3, a subclass associated with stronger FcγRIIIa binding and historically linked to potent neutralization.

This study examined 97 non-hospitalized individuals recovering from mild COVID-19 (about 2–3 months post-infection) without psychiatric comorbidities, comparing them to 77 matched controls. Clinically, many post-COVID participants reported memory loss (36 %), fatigue (31 %), headache (29 %), somnolence (35 %), and showed deficits on tests of verbal fluency and memory (e.g. ~21 % had impaired phonemic verbal fluency). In DTI analyses, the post-COVID group showed higher axial diffusivity (AD) in certain white matter tracts compared to controls (suggesting microstructural white matter alteration), though no differences were found in fractional anisotropy (FA), mean diffusivity (MD), or radial diffusivity (RD). In rs-fMRI of the default mode network (posterior cingulate seed), there were no significant group differences in connectivity after correction, and no strong correlations between imaging metrics and cognitive scores or fatigue/sleepiness measures.

Persistent complement activation and its crosstalk with coagulation and endothelial injury may underlie many features of Long COVID, such as microvascular damage, chronic inflammation, and prolonged immune activation. Ruf emphasizes that complement dysregulation can perpetuate tissue injury long after viral clearance, creating a feedback loop of immune/coagulation damage.

The authors characterize antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 membrane (M) protein in infected individuals, showing that although such antibodies fail to neutralize the virus, they can trigger Fc-dependent effector functions (notably ADCC) by engaging Fc receptor–bearing cells. In particular, M-directed antibodies from critically ill patients exhibited stronger activation of cytotoxic responses compared to antibodies from those with milder disease. In a clinical correlation analysis, elevated anti-M IgG levels were strongly associated with lung injury, outperforming associations seen with anti-S or anti-N antibodies.

The study used whole-blood digital transcriptomics in a GP-based cohort (48 LC, 12 matched controls; up to 39-month follow-up) and found systemic SARS-CoV-2 RNA persistence in a large subset of Long COVID patients—including antisense viral RNA consistent with ongoing replication. A two-gene classifier (host FYN + viral antisense RNA) discriminated LC from controls with ~94% AUC and ~94%/92% sensitivity/specificity. Host-side signals (elevated ACE2/TMPRSS2, DPP4/FURIN, memory-B and platelet transcripts) and a depressed immunometabolism score (inversely related to viral load) offered mechanistic links to LC biology and symptoms; platelet signatures tracked with viral load, and higher viral RNA associated with worse emotional scores. More COVID-19 vaccine doses associated with lower odds of high viral RNA.

Thao et al. (2020) develop a yeast-based synthetic genomics system for rapid assembly and rescue of full-length RNA virus genomes, including SARS-CoV-2. By amplifying overlapping viral DNA fragments, co-transforming them into yeast for in vivo recombination into a yeast artificial chromosome, and using T7 polymerase–mediated in vitro transcription, the authors were able to reconstitute infectious virus in cell culture. They demonstrate this method’s effectiveness with SARS-CoV-2 and other RNA virus families, and show that recombinant viruses replicate with kinetics similar to isolates and that the genomic constructs are stable over yeast passages. This platform reduces the delay between sequence release and functional virus generation, enabling faster experimental characterization of emerging variants or engineered modifications (e.g. reporter insertions), which is especially valuable during outbreak response. The authors propose this as a general, rapid reverse-genetics tool for RNA viruses, facilitating downstream studies (e.g. pathogenesis, antiviral testing, vaccine design).

The preprint presents evidence that binding of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein (especially from Omicron subvariants) to the ACE2 receptor is temperature dependent, with higher affinity at warmer temperatures (such as those in the nasal/upper airway environment). They show that some mutations in the Omicron spike further enhance this temperature sensitivity, and that this enhanced binding correlates with greater infectivity in respiratory epithelial model systems. These findings support the idea that the transmission advantage of recent Omicron lineages may in part stem from an improved ability to bind ACE2 under physiological temperatures encountered in the upper respiratory tract.

In a cohort of hospital employees with predominantly mild acute COVID-19, about 50% reported ongoing symptoms 90 days or more after infection, indicating a substantial burden of long COVID even in non-hospitalized individuals. The most persistent symptoms varied, and symptom clusters and temporal patterns were analyzed to better understand their co-occurrence and evolution. Predictors of prolonged symptom duration included female gender, a greater number of initial symptoms, and presence of comorbid conditions.

COVID-19 infection is associated with a substantially increased short-term risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) events and death: within 21 days of diagnosis, individuals with COVID-19 had hazard ratios of ~4 to 5 for new CVD and ~67 to 81 for all-cause mortality compared to matched controls. Even after surviving the acute phase, COVID-19 patients remained at elevated long-term risk: over 18 months, the risk of new cardiovascular events remained ~30–40% higher (HR ~1.3–1.4), and mortality ~4- to 5-fold higher than in non-infected controls.

This study of ~13,600 adults over 12 months demonstrates that individuals hospitalized with COVID-19 (i.e. “severe” cases) face a significantly elevated risk of all-cause mortality in the following year compared both to noninfected individuals and those with mild/moderate infection. The hazard ratio for 12-month mortality was ~2.5 versus COVID-negative and ~1.9 versus mild cases, even after adjusting for age, sex, race, and comorbidities. Importantly, most of the post-acute deaths (≈ 80 %) were from causes other than respiratory or cardiovascular disease, implying a broader, systemic impact of severe COVID-19.

Merad et al. provide a sweeping review of COVID-19 immunology, synthesizing what has been learned about how innate and adaptive immune responses respond to SARS-CoV-2 infection. They emphasize that a properly timed and regulated immune response is crucial: insufficient early antiviral defense (e.g. interferon) or overactive inflammation can both lead to worse outcomes. The review also explores how pathological immune activation (cytokine storms, complement, endothelial damage) contributes to severe disease. The article also considers post-acute and chronic consequences of COVID-19, discussing how persistent immune activation, dysregulation, or even residual viral persistence may underlie long COVID.

Long COVID may include a significant autonomic dysfunction component, resulting in symptoms of orthostatic intolerance (such as dizziness, palpitations, fatigue) and impaired regulation of blood pressure and heart rate. Dani et al. outline the rationale that SARS-CoV-2 or the consequent immune response might damage autonomic neural circuits, endothelial support, or reflex arcs, giving rise to a dysregulated autonomic state. They argue that clinicians should recognize and evaluate for autonomic dysfunction in post-COVID patients, and provide a framework of supportive treatments (e.g. increased fluids/salt, compression, graded activity) while noting that stronger evidence is needed.

Pretorius et al. demonstrate that individuals with Long COVID harbor persistent amyloid microclots in their plasma, which resist breakdown by standard fibrinolytic processes. Compared to controls, these microclots trap elevated levels of coagulation and inflammatory proteins — especially α₂-antiplasmin, fibrinogen chains, and Serum Amyloid A — suggesting a dysregulated balance between clot formation and clot dissolution in Long COVID. These findings suggest that microvascular obstruction from persistent, fibrinolysis‐resistant microclots may contribute to Long COVID symptoms, and the authors propose that targeted anti‐clotting or fibrinolytic therapies might help mitigate this phenomenon.

194 people with Long COVID (PCC) show markedly slower cognitive processing than both 63 people who had COVID but did not develop long-term symptoms, and 113 uninfected controls. Using simple reaction time and vigilance tasks, the researchers found that over half of PCC participants responded more than two standard deviations slower than controls, even in a brief 30-second task. This slowing remained significant after adjusting for fatigue, depression, anxiety, sleep issues, or PTSD, suggesting it reflects a core cognitive impairment rather than secondary symptoms.

Vanderboom et al. applied high-resolution proteomics and phosphoproteomics to nasopharyngeal swabs from SARS-CoV-2–infected and uninfected individuals, identifying over 7,500 proteins. They found a strong upregulation of interferon-driven antiviral signaling (e.g. MX1, ISG15, STAT1, RIG-I, CXCL10) accompanied by downregulation of proteasome components, E3 ubiquitin ligases, and translational machinery. Phosphoproteomic analysis revealed altered phosphorylation in antiviral effectors and ciliary proteins (CEP131, CFAP57), and diminished phosphorylation of AKT and PKC family kinases.

Scardua-Silva et al. performed a cross-sectional case–control study comparing 97 individuals who had experienced mild (non-hospitalized) COVID-19 (median ~79 days after diagnosis) with 77 matched healthy controls. The participants were selected to exclude those with current or prior anxiety or depression. The COVID group reported higher rates of fatigue (83 %), memory complaints, and reduced performance on verbal fluency and logical memory tasks. Using diffusion tensor imaging, the authors detected increased axial diffusivity in white matter tracts compared to healthy controls, indicating possible microstructural changes, while resting-state connectivity did not show significant alterations after correction.

Prior infection with the common cold coronavirus OC43 can prime T cells that recognize SARS-CoV-2. In human-HLA transgenic mice, this pre-exposure lowered SARS-CoV-2 lung virus levels and disease, and the protection depended in part on CD4⁺ T cells. A key cross-reactive CD8⁺ response targeted a conserved nucleocapsid epitope; cross-reactive anti-spike antibodies were not detected.

This BMJ clinical review outlines how to recognise and manage cognitive dysfunction after covid-19 in primary care. Cognitive complaints—commonly memory, attention and concentration problems—are frequent in long covid, fluctuate over time and can substantially limit daily life and work. Many patients improve within a year, but persistence beyond 12 months predicts slower recovery. Evidence on mechanisms is still mixed and heterogeneous. The article recommends a structured assessment: document symptom pattern and functional impact, exclude alternative explanations and red flags, and recognise that routine screens may miss executive-function deficits. Management is supportive—education, pacing and energy management, sleep optimisation, vocational accommodations, cognitive rehab/compensatory strategies, and addressing comorbidities—while acknowledging the absence of proven disease-specific pharmacologic treatments.

Mutations in the SARS-CoV-2 N gene (specifically in the region targeted by the N1 qPCR probe) can lead to significant underestimation of viral RNA levels in wastewater surveillance using RT-qPCR. The authors combine mutation detection in field wastewater samples over 2021–2022 with controlled experiments using mutant synthetic templates to show that even a single nucleotide change in the probe binding region can reduce assay sensitivity. As a result, N1 results can be depressed relative to N2, particularly during later Omicron waves when such mutations became common. The authors argue that reliance on a single qPCR target is risky in the face of viral evolution. They recommend multiplexing assays, ongoing assay validation, and quality control protocols to ensure wastewater surveillance remains accurate even as SARS-CoV-2 variants emerge and mutate.

Osiaevi et al. (2024) propose that capillary rarefication — a permanent or long-lasting reduction in capillary density — may be a contributing mechanism to symptoms in Long COVID. The editorial draws on prior evidence of microvascular and endothelial damage after SARS-CoV-2 infection, and suggests that when capillary networks are diminished, tissues receive less oxygen and nutrients, aggravating fatigue, muscle weakness, and organ dysfunction that characterize Long COVID. They also emphasize that microvascular injury, impaired angiogenesis, and endothelial dysfunction could drive this capillary loss, and recommend further research into interventions aimed at reversing or compensating for microvascular deficits.

🐁Many viral infections are linked to neurological complications, but the culprit isn’t always the virus itself. In Zika-infected mice, neurological disease tracked with NKG2D⁺ CD8⁺ T-cell infiltration into the brain, not with how much virus was present. Blocking these CD8⁺ cells or their NKG2D receptor prevented paralysis, while cytokine stimulation (IL-12/18) lowered viral load but worsened neurological symptoms, indicating antigen-independent “bystander” cytotoxicity as the damaging mechanism. Thus, CD8⁺ T cells acting through NKG2D can drive neuropathology during viral infection, making this pathway a promising therapeutic target.

This review compares influenza and SARS-CoV-2 in the respiratory tract, examining how viral tropism, host immune responses, and tissue damage intersect to produce a spectrum of disease severities. While the host immune response is essential for clearance, it can also drive pathology, particularly when dysregulated. Influenza binds to sialic acids on epithelial cells (mostly upper airway), with avian vs. human adaptation defined by α2,3 vs. α2,6 linkages. SARS-CoV-2 binds to ACE2 (with TMPRSS2 and other proteases assisting entry), expressed in subsets of ciliated cells, type II alveolar cells, and other epithelia. This narrower receptor distribution partly explains distinct tissue targets and pathogenesis. Influenza tends to infect upper respiratory tract cells more readily (though severe strains can descend into alveoli). SARS-CoV-2 can infect both upper and lower respiratory tract, with significant consequences in alveolar regions and vascular compartments — this contributes to severe pneumonia and ARDS-like pathology. Influenza has a short incubation period (1–2 days) and rapid onset of symptoms, so transmission peaks around or after symptom onset. SARS-CoV-2 has a longer incubation (4–6 days) and allows pre-symptomatic transmission, which has major implications for pandemic spread. Influenza typically induces a brisk interferon response, sometimes protective but also damaging if excessive. SARS-CoV-2 often shows a blunted or delayed interferon response, with later excessive inflammation (e.g., cytokine storm) contributing to pathology. Influenza usually causes epithelial necrosis and damage in conducting airways, with repair via proliferation of basal and alveolar type II cells. SARS-CoV-2 often involves diffuse alveolar damage, endothelial injury, microvascular thrombosis, and sometimes long-lasting epithelial dysplasia or fibrosis — more extensive and protracted repair failure than typical influenza.

In older adults (age 60+), SARS-CoV-2 infection appears to be temporally associated with an elevated risk of developing new-onset dementia, based on a meta-analysis of observational studies. The stronger associations are observed at longer follow-up intervals (around one year), and more severe COVID-19 may further increase the risk compared to milder cases. The authors note, however, that this increased risk is not clearly higher than risks seen after other respiratory infections like influenza. Because the studies included vary greatly in their design, dementia definitions, follow-up durations, and adjustment covariates the conclusions should be interpreted cautiously.

This matched cohort leveraged pre-infection lung tests to quantify how mild COVID-19 alters lung function over time. Compared with uninfected controls, cases showed a significant additional decline in forced expiratory volume in 1 second from before infection to ~6 months after; forced vital capacity behaved similarly. Between 6 and 24 months, the excess decline attenuated and was not significant, and diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide improved modestly, but overall the data suggest incomplete recovery two years after a mild infection.

In a US EHR study of 62k people with COVID-19, new psychiatric diagnoses in the 14–90 days after infection were more common than after several other acute health events, especially for anxiety, insomnia, and (in older adults) dementia. About 18% had any psychiatric diagnosis and ~6% had a first-ever psychiatric diagnosis in that window. People with a psychiatric diagnosis in the prior year were also more likely to receive a COVID-19 diagnosis (RR≈1.65), even after matching on known medical risks—implying a bidirectional association between COVID-19 and psychiatric conditions, while not proving causality.

BMJ’s practice update equips primary care with a structured approach to long covid: recognise common symptom clusters; take a careful history (including post-exertional worsening); rule out alternative causes; and address symptoms with personalised, supportive care. Practical tips include conservative return-to-activity using pacing; screening for autonomic problems; targeted respiratory and sleep management; and attention to mental health, work/benefits, and caregiver needs. Clear referral thresholds and an at-a-glance infographic support day-to-day decisions. The article stresses that evidence for disease-modifying treatments remains limited; most care is symptomatic and rehabilitative, ideally delivered via integrated, community-based services. It highlights the importance of consistent terminology and patient-centred communication, and signposts resources for both clinicians and patients.

Using a large, nationally reweighted U.S. online survey of adults with prior test-confirmed COVID-19, the authors estimate that ~14% had symptoms persisting ≥2 months, translating to ~1.7% of U.S. adults at the study timepoint. Older age (above 40) and female sex were linked to higher odds, while higher education, higher income, and living in urban areas were linked to lower odds. Risk appeared lower for infections during Epsilon and Omicron predominance versus ancestral-strain periods, and prior completion of a primary vaccination series was associated with reduced odds of long COVID. Commonly reported symptoms included fatigue, loss of smell, brain fog, memory problems, and sleep disruption.

This human SARS-CoV-2 challenge in previously uninfected adults mapped early immune dynamics in the nose and blood. About half became infected. Interferon-related mediators surged early, T cells (CD4⁺/CD8⁺) activated quickly with proliferative phenotypes, and antibodies emerged around day 10; nasal antibodies plateaued earlier than systemic ones. Statistical modeling linked stronger CD8⁺ T-cell responses and rapid mucosal IgA to better viral control, pointing to these as desirable targets for interventions aimed at reducing viral replication and transmission.

This MR study by Li et al. investigated whether genetic predisposition to COVID-19 (severe disease, hospitalization, or infection) could causally influence the risk of developing various cancers. The authors found “suggestive” evidence that higher liability to severe COVID-19 is associated with increased risks of cancers such as HER2-positive breast cancer, esophageal cancer, colorectal cancer, stomach cancer, and colon cancer; and that liability to infection may be associated with stomach cancer risk. However, these associations were not definitive. The authors addressed pleiotropy and heterogeneity, but the magnitude of the associations is small, and the study is limited by MR assumptions, population stratification, and the possibility that the genetic instruments may act through pleiotropic pathways.

Lung cancer and COVID-19 share a number of dysregulated genes, particularly 36 genes whose expression is altered in both disease contexts. These genes cluster in biological processes tied to cell cycle control, DNA repair, immune modulation, and cellular stress responses. Through network analyses, the authors highlight several genes (hub nodes) as potential key mediators, and explore candidate drug compounds that might target these genes or their pathways. Overall, the study suggests that COVID-19 may aggravate lung cancer progression via shared molecular mechanisms, and that some of these molecules may be actionable in the context of co-morbid disease. However, the study is limited in that it is purely computational and based on secondary (public) transcriptomic datasets; there is no experimental or clinical validation of the proposed signatures or drug targets. Moreover, because the datasets derive from different sources (with potential batch effects, differences in sample handling, heterogeneity of patient populations), the overlap of genes may partly reflect technical or sampling artifacts rather than true biological intersection. The approach also does not resolve causality (i.e., whether COVID-19 drives those changes in lung cancer, or vice versa). Finally, since the analysis focuses on lung cancer patients and shared genes, the findings may not generalize to noncancer populations or reflect complexities of the in vivo microenvironment (e.g., spatial heterogeneity, tumor–immune cell interactions).

🐁Kim et al. present a xenograft model in immunodeficient mice using human Calu-3 lung cells to sustain in vivo long-term replication of SARS-CoV-2 over 30 days. Within the tumor xenografts, virus persisted, accumulated mutations (predominantly in the spike protein), and certain variants arose that showed greater replication in the Calu-3 environment without cytopathic effect. When tested in K18-ACE2 mice, the variant isolates were attenuated (less lethal) relative to the parental strain, yet induced cross-reactive neutralizing antibodies and protective immunity upon rechallenge. This model demonstrates how SARS-CoV-2 can evolve under prolonged replication pressure in a permissive tissue niche, yielding variants with altered replication–virulence trade-offs. However, because the host mice are immunodeficient and lack immunological selective pressures, and because the experiment spans only 30 days, the extent to which the mutations and dynamics recapitulate persistent infection in humans is uncertain.

This review article collates and synthesizes existing evidence on the role of the chaperone protein HSPA5 (GRP78/BiP) when expressed on the cell surface, particularly its overexpression in many cancers and its potential role as a SARS-CoV-2 receptor or cofactor. The authors argue that because HSPA5 is highly expressed in many tumors and possibly upregulated under stress, it represents a plausible alternative or supplementary entry point for the virus, especially in malignancy contexts. They further describe docking and expression analyses suggesting that SARS-CoV-2 spike variants could bind HSPA5, and propose that targeting HSPA5 (via antibodies, small molecules, or natural products) might have therapeutic or prognostic value in both cancer and COVID-19.

Viruses account for roughly 10–15% of human cancers. This review explains that viral oncogenesis converges on DNA damage and genomic instability: viral oncoproteins inactivate tumor suppressors (e.g., p53/pRB) and chronic inflammation/oxidative stress from infection and co-factors (smoking, alcohol, radiation, co-infections) create DNA breaks that fuel mutations and chromosomal aberrations. For viruses like HPV, HBV and MCV, integration of viral DNA into host genomes is a pivotal carcinogenic trigger that elevates oncogene expression; activation yet manipulation of DNA damage response pathways (e.g., ATM/Chk2) further enables transformation. Given decade-long latencies, the authors highlight opportunities for prevention and early interception but note that antioxidant strategies remain unproven.

The paper shows that ambient PM2.5 is associated with higher rates of EGFR-mutant lung adenocarcinoma in never-smokers across multiple cohorts. In engineered mouse lungs that already carry EGFR/KRAS drivers, brief PM2.5 exposure promotes tumor formation via inflammation—especially macrophage-derived IL-1β—that shifts mutant AT2 cells into a regenerative, tumor-permissive state. Ultra-deep sequencing reveals that many “healthy” lungs already contain rare EGFR or KRAS driver mutations, implying that pollution mainly promotes cancers from existing clones rather than initiating them. This promotion model helps explain lung cancer in never-smokers and underscores the value of air-quality policies and potentially anti-inflammatory interception strategies targeting IL-1β.

🧫This work demonstrates that the SARS-CoV-2 membrane (M) protein augments malignant characteristics in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells, enhancing migration, invasion, proliferation, stemness, and metastasis in vivo, mediated through activation of NFκB and STAT3 signaling and upregulation of inflammatory cytokines and EMT genes. In contrast, a more hormone-dependent breast cancer cell line (MCF-7) was less responsive to direct M protein treatment in terms of proliferation and metastasis. Moreover, M protein–treated aggressive BCCs can exert paracrine influences on otherwise non-aggressive BCCs, driving them toward more malignant phenotypes via secreted cytokines and EMT induction. The findings raise the possibility that SARS-CoV-2 infection might exacerbate breast cancer progression, particularly in TNBC patients, and suggest that inhibition of NFκB or STAT3 pathways might ameliorate such adverse effects. However, translation to human disease remains speculative, pending further validation in clinical and primary tumor settings.

MALAT1 is a long non-coding RNA that, although non-coding, can influence gene regulation by binding to miRNAs, RNAs, proteins, or chromatin, thereby modulating processes such as apoptosis, proliferation, migration, EMT, and inflammation. This review highlights evidence that MALAT1 is dysregulated in multiple lung pathologies (e.g. asthma, COPD, ARDS, IPF, pulmonary hypertension, lung cancer), with multiple proposed mechanistic axes (miRNA sponging, signaling pathway regulation) linking MALAT1 to disease processes. Experimental targeting of MALAT1 (e.g. via antisense oligonucleotides or pharmacological agents) in preclinical models has shown potential in mitigating lung injury or remodeling. While the review is comprehensive in mapping the literature, the authors also stress that many of the existing findings are from in vitro or animal studies, and causal, in vivo confirmation (especially in human tissues) remains limited. They highlight gaps such as small sample sizes, imbalance or heterogeneity in datasets, lack of mechanistic/histological validation in some disease contexts, and the need for translational and clinical assessment before MALAT1-based diagnostics or therapies can be reliably considered.

Severe long-COVID patients (selected from >1,000 non-hospitalized infections) showed high, persistent anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgG and heightened innate signatures, but blunted expansion of memory CD8⁺ T cells. Plasma viral markers were inconsistently positive across assays, suggesting that serology (elevated IgG) may be a more sensitive surrogate of ongoing antigen exposure than current blood persistence assays. These findings support viral persistence as a driver of severe long COVID and argue for exploring extended antiviral therapy to target potential tissue reservoirs. Symptom/immunologic patterns didn’t form clear clusters, underscoring long COVID’s heterogeneity.

This study followed 55 infected healthcare workers during the Delta wave to compare SARS-CoV-2 viral-load decline after no vaccination, a single ChAdOx1 dose, or two ChAdOx1 doses given <6 weeks apart. By day 5 after PCR positivity, the single-dose group showed significantly lower viral RNA and a faster early decline than both the short-interval double-dose group and the unvaccinated. The authors suggest that when the second ChAdOx1 dose is given too soon, anti-vector (adenoviral) immunity may dampen the desired effect, leading to a slower fall in viral RNA. Because the cohort was small, observational, and confined to Delta-era HCWs, and because outcomes were PCR RNA rather than cultured virus or transmission events, the findings mainly highlight a possible short-term kinetic disadvantage of short-interval ChAdOx1 boosting—not a definitive statement on infectiousness or on other vaccines/variants.

This study examined chest CT scans of COVID-19 patients in Vietnam, documenting that lung abnormalities are common even in mild and moderate disease (up to ~45 %) and identifying ground-glass opacities, consolidations, opacities, and nodular lesions as the dominant patterns. Patients infected with the Delta variant had more severe lung injury patterns compared to those with Alpha or Omicron, and individuals vaccinated with at least two doses had lower risk of CT-detectable lung injury. Interestingly, younger patients (<18 years) were less likely to exhibit lung abnormalities, but the extent of lung injury on imaging did not clearly alter treatment outcomes in this cohort. The authors suggest that CT imaging might help detect otherwise subclinical lung damage in COVID-19, even in cases classified clinically as mild, to better guide management and prevent complications. They also interpret that non-Omicron strains tend to impose more lung burden and that vaccination confers a protective effect on lung involvement. However, they note that imaging findings do not necessarily translate into worse outcomes and should be interpreted in clinical context.

Choi et al. conducted a serosurvey among 79 domestic cats in New York City during 2020–2021, detecting SARS-CoV-2–specific antibodies in 16% overall (and up to 44% in fall 2020). Over half of those antibody-positive cats also had measurable neutralizing activity. There was no clear correlation between seropositivity and respiratory symptoms or typical demographic factors. The study supports the notion that spillover from humans to cats occurred during the early pandemic, even if cat infections were largely subclinical. The study is limited by its modest sample size and the fact that the cats were drawn from an animal hospital population rather than a randomized community sample, raising potential sampling bias. Temporal sampling was uneven, and the high prevalence in fall 2020 may reflect selection or outbreak effects rather than stable prevalence. The study is cross-sectional (with limited longitudinal follow-up), so it cannot resolve directionality of transmission (e.g. cat-to-human) or dynamics of viral shedding. Finally, the serological and neutralization assays, while sensitive, cannot distinguish between recent versus past infection, nor necessarily detect low-level exposures.

This study profiled post-mortem brainstem, cerebellum, and olfactory tissues from individuals who died of COVID-19 at different disease stages using single-nucleus transcriptomics, spatial transcriptomics, and proteomics. In acute cases, the brainstem showed a pronounced type I interferon inflammatory response that was attenuated in late-phase cases. Spatial mapping revealed two patterns: a neuronal response centered on cranial nerve nuclei and a diffuse perivascular pattern involving oligodendrocytes, microglia, and astrocytes. The authors infer that local immune reactions, likely triggered by systemic inflammation, can disturb brain function without ongoing viral persistence in the CNS. This provides a plausible explanation for neurologic symptoms during and after acute infection and emphasizes neuroinflammation—not direct neurotropism—as a key mechanism.

This study used data from the UK Biobank to compare 112,311 individuals with a history of SARS-CoV-2 infection to large control cohorts and found consistently higher risks of developing chronic respiratory diseases such as asthma (HR 1.49), bronchiectasis (1.30), COPD (1.59), interstitial lung disease (1.81), pulmonary vascular disease (1.59), and lung cancer (1.39) over a median follow-up of ~0.8 years (up to 2.7 years). The risks were higher among those with more severe COVID-19, and analyses over time showed that the risk of asthma and bronchiectasis continued rising while risks for COPD, ILD, PVD and lung cancer declined. In those with SARS-CoV-2 reinfection versus a single infection, the hazards for respiratory outcomes were even more elevated (e.g. asthma HR ~3.0).

In a cohort of 207 Indian adults (mean age 48.7 years, 68.1% male), assessed on average 63 days after COVID-19 onset, 35% exhibited a restrictive ventilatory defect (TLC < 80%), 8.3% had obstructive defect, and 44.4% had reduced diffusing capacity (DLCO < 80%). Those who suffered COVID-19 pneumonia (moderate to critical WHO categories) had significantly worse lung function (e.g. FVC% 77.85 vs 88.18, DLCO% 75.30 vs 89.20), lower exercise oxygen saturations (94.89% vs 97.73%), and worse quality-of-life by SGRQ (mean 29.2 vs 11.0) than the mild group. Additionally, severe/critical cases had more pronounced radiographic abnormalities (RALE score median 1.5 vs 0) and functional deficits.

🐁In K18-hACE2 mice, intranasal SARS-CoV-2 caused marked blood-brain barrier (BBB) disruption by 5 days, with IgG leakage, microhemorrhages, loss of ZO-1/Claudin-5, and pericyte depletion. The vasculature showed endothelial activation (VCAM1, COX-2) and brain tissue exhibited astrogliosis (GFAP) and microglial activation (IBA1). Similar barrier breakdown and inflammatory signatures were found at the choroid plexus blood – cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) barrier. Many outcomes were significant with n = 3; p < 0.001. Brain sections stained positive for SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein.

This study of 18 patients with peripheral arterial thrombosis (7 of whom had prior SARS-CoV-2 positivity) found SARS-CoV-2 RNA in 50% of endothelial biopsies and all thrombotic clots, with viral nucleoprotein detected in 15% of endothelium and 50% of clots. Patients with viral presence had significantly lower plasma levels of the anticoagulant PROS1, and among them, those whose tissue was positive for virus had even lower PROS1 than those without. Viral entry receptor ACE2 and CD147 were upregulated in affected tissues from SARS-CoV-2–positive patients. The authors propose that in situ vascular persistence of SARS-CoV-2 may enable localized cleavage of PROS1 by the viral papain-like protease (PLpro), impairing anticoagulant balance and contributing to COVID-19–associated coagulopathies.

This population-level longitudinal study followed 6,833,423 residents of Madrid over the first three years of the COVID-19 pandemic (2020–2022), linking administrative and clinical registries to quantify confirmed infections, hospitalizations, and 30-day mortality. About 21.4% of residents had a confirmed COVID-19 diagnosis and 1.5% required hospitalization. The 30-day mortality among confirmed infections was 1.6%, declining over time (from 11.4% early 2020 to 0.4% in early 2022), while among hospitalized patients the 30-day mortality was 10.8%, decreasing from 14.0% to 6.0% over the same period. Risk of death was higher with older age, male gender, greater socioeconomic deprivation, and underlying comorbidities, reflecting consistent predictors of worse outcomes. The authors present this as a framework for cross-regional comparisons of COVID-19 burden. However, limitations include possible underascertainment of infections, reliance on administrative coding, lack of variant-level or long-term outcome analyses, and limited generalizability to other settings.

This study used a bidirectional Mendelian randomization framework to test whether genetically determined leukocyte telomere length causally influences COVID-19 susceptibility or severity. Using ~20 LTL‐associated SNPs and large genome-wide association studies (GWAS) datasets from the COVID-19 Host Genetics Initiative (e.g. 38,984 cases vs 1,644,784 controls for susceptibility), the authors found no significant associations in either direction, and no detectable genetic correlation between telomere length and COVID-19 outcomes. Sensitivity analyses and alternate instrument sets yielded consistent null results. While observational studies had linked shorter telomeres to more severe COVID-19, the MR evidence here argues against a strong causal role of telomere length (as proxied by common genetic variants) in COVID-19 risk or severity—at least in European ancestry populations. The authors caution that their power is limited (instruments explain only a small proportion of LTL variance), and nonlinear effects or contributions of extremely short telomeres cannot be excluded.

In a case–control study of 117 COVID-19 survivors versus 144 controls, the authors report significant biological age acceleration in survivors (DeltaAge 10.45 ± 7.29 years vs 3.68 ± 8.17; p < 0.0001). 76.6% of survivors were classified as biologically “older” than expected. The effect was strongest in participants <60 years, with no sex differences. Survivors also had shorter leukocyte telomeres (3.03 ± 2.39 kb vs 10.67 ± 11.69 kb, p < 0.0001) and lower ACE2 mRNA in blood (0.000380 vs 0.001390 2^−ΔCt; p < 0.0001); DPP-4 expression was unchanged. The authors suggest SARS-CoV-2 may leave a persistent aging-like epigenetic and telomeric footprint consistent with post-COVID sequelae. However, the study is cross-sectional without pre-infection baselines, uses a limited 4-CpG clock, and shows group imbalances (e.g., BMI, lung disease). Results should be validated with longitudinal, multi-clock epigenetic profiling and standardized TL assays across diverse tissues and cohorts.

This review argues that persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection—ongoing replication lasting well beyond the acute phase—occurs in a subset of patients, particularly the immunocompromised, and is likely under-recognized. The authors highlight tissue reservoirs (including outside the lungs) as a key driver, emphasize the need for diagnostics that detect replication rather than mere exposure, and warn that within-host evolution during these prolonged courses can generate variants with immune-escape potential. They call for standardized definitions, tailored treatment strategies (e.g., extended/combination antivirals and case-specific antibody approaches), and surveillance to track intra-host evolution and potential spread.

This cross-sectional study of U.S. adults using the 2022 BRFSS survey estimated that about 21.7 % of people with prior COVID-19 reported persistent post-COVID symptoms. The most common complaints were fatigue (5.7 %), shortness of breath (4.2 %), and loss of smell or taste (3.8 %). After adjusting for covariates, risk factors for long COVID included female sex, overweight or obesity (BMI ≥ 25), being uninsured, prior pulmonary disease, depression, arthritis, former smoking status, and shorter sleep duration (< 7 hours). Older age (> 64 years), Black race, and higher household income were paradoxically associated with lower odds of reporting long COVID.

This study links brain fog in long COVID to blood–brain barrier (BBB) leakiness measured with DCE-MRI in 11 brain-fog patients versus 11 long-COVID without brain fog and 10 recovered controls; leakage localized to bilateral temporal and frontal regions. Blood profiling in 76 acute COVID patients showed graded increases in inflammatory and endothelial/coagulation markers with severity, and higher S100β in those with brain fog. Structural MRI (vs 60 healthy controls) found reduced brain/white-matter volumes and increased CSF in brain-fog patients, with BBB disruption correlating with these changes. Mechanistically, PBMC RNA-seq suggested coagulation dysregulation and dampened adaptive immunity in brain-fog; long-COVID PBMCs adhered more to brain endothelium, and patient serum or S1 spike protein activated endothelial cells (↑TNF/TGFβ/ICAM1/VCAM1). The authors propose that sustained systemic inflammation plus focal BBB dysfunction underlies cognitive symptoms and highlight TGF-β as a candidate biomarker/target.

This article argues that the enigma of long COVID offers a unique opportunity to understand how a viral infection can transition into a chronic, multi-system disease. The authors survey plausible biological mechanisms—viral persistence, immune dysregulation, endothelial/microvascular injury, latent virus reactivation, autonomic dysfunction, and metabolic disruption—while emphasizing that long COVID is likely heterogeneous rather than a single uniform disease. They call for deeper mechanistic, tissue-based, and longitudinal studies to discriminate causal drivers from secondary signals. They also highlight that some early empirical findings support components of this framework (e.g. persistent viral antigens in plasma, viral RNA in tissues), but emphasize the urgent need for stronger causal evidence, standardized cohorts, biomarker platforms, and interventional trials. The authors conclude that solving long COVID could illuminate general principles of post-infectious sequelae and pave the path toward precision therapeutics.

This WHO-affiliated systematic review/meta-analysis pooled 182 studies (10,023 participants) to quantify SARS-CoV-2 RNA in body fluids relevant to sexual activity. Pooled detection was 82.6% in saliva, 31.8% in faeces/rectal swabs, 3.8% in urine, 2.7% in vaginal secretions, and 1.6% in semen; viable virus was reported in saliva and faeces. Reported maximum persistence reached 210 days in faeces/rectal secretions, 121 days in semen, 112 days in saliva, 77 days in urine, and 13 days in vaginal fluids. The findings suggest that while sexual transmission via semen/vaginal fluids appears unlikely (low detection and no culture positivity), intimate contact remains a risk through saliva and potential faecal exposure.

Using a nationwide Scottish cohort of 198,096 adults (98,666 infected; 99,430 matched never-infected), the authors estimated the true prevalence of long-COVID by subtracting background symptom rates seen in never-infected people and adjusting for confounders. They found an adjusted attributable prevalence of 6.6% at 6 months, 6.5% at 12 months, and 10.4% at 18 months after infection; crude gaps were 13.8%, 12.8%, and 16.3%, respectively. Attributable prevalence was higher in women and in later variant periods (Alpha ~3.9% vs Delta ~6.7% and Omicron ~7.9% at 6 months). Because symptoms are largely non-specific and assessment relied on self-report with PCR-based ascertainment (no antigen tests), misclassification and residual confounding remain important limitations.

In a RECOVER-EHR study across 40 U.S. pediatric hospitals during the Omicron (Jan 2022–Oct 2023) period, the 6-month incidence of Long COVID was ~904 per million after a first infection vs ~1,884 per million after a second—more than doubling risk. Elevated risks spanned demographics, vaccination status, and initial illness severity. Sequelae with higher post-reinfection risk included myocarditis, blood clots, acute kidney injury, respiratory symptoms, fatigue, and cognitive issues.

This prospective observational study in Turkey compared 30 infants who had SARS-CoV-2 infection in the neonatal period (≥ 34 weeks gestation) with 60 matched controls to assess neurodevelopment at 18–24 months using the Bayley-II scale. The SARS-CoV-2–positive group showed worse psychomotor development (PDI) and more mildly delayed performances (MDPs; PDI p = 0.05, MDPs p = 0.03). Among those infected with the Delta variant, both mental (MDI) and psychomotor (PDI) scores were significantly lower (p = 0.03 for both). The infected infants also had reduced head circumference during the first year (p < 0.001), though by the second year, the head circumference difference had largely resolved.

This paper reports on four individuals with B-cell depletion (from rituximab, one also on epcoritamab) who developed persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection over periods from 45 to 242 days, which was difficult to diagnose because upper airway PCR tests occasionally became negative; in two cases, only bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) sampling revealed persistent viral presence. After the persistent infection was identified, all four patients were treated with antiviral therapies (including remdesivir, nirmatrelvir/ritonavir, or a combination), and viral clearance was eventually achieved in all.

In a cohort of 7,039 undergraduates at a Spanish university during the 2020–21 year, 658 (9.3 %) were diagnosed with COVID-19 via frequent PCR testing. Among the infected, only 4.0 % achieved “outstanding academic” performance versus 7.3 % in the uninfected group. Adjusted regression analysis yielded an odds ratio of 0.57 (95 % CI 0.38–0.86), indicating that SARS-CoV-2 infection was significantly associated with lower likelihood of top academic marks.

In a case–control study six months after COVID-19 (n=37 convalescents; controls n=40), the authors found reduced PD-1 on CD8+ T cells in convalescents and elevated plasma IFN-γ (with lower IL-7). Convalescent plasma lowered PD-1 on T cells from healthy donors, and IFN-γ neutralization restored PD-1 on CD8+ cells. Spike protein—but not nucleocapsid—provoked IFN-γ responses only in convalescents (ELISpot n=6). Single-cell analyses and perturbation experiments suggest IFN-γ reduces PD-1 via the AKT/GSK3β pathway (AKT agonism and inhibition modulated PD-1 and p-GSK3β accordingly). About 35% reported lingering symptoms. Overall, the work proposes an IFN-γ↔PD-1 axis that could sustain pre-exhausted CD8+ T cells months after infection, a potential immunologic substrate for long-COVID features.

This study uses a Bayesian hierarchical model to generate monthly estimates of excess mortality in 3,127 U.S. counties from March 2020 to February 2022, finding 1,179,024 excess deaths during that period (634,830 in the first year, 544,194 in the second). The relative excess mortality (excess vs expected deaths) fell in large metropolitan counties from ~24.0 % in year 1 to ~17.1 % in year 2, while it rose in non-metropolitan areas from ~20.2 % to ~21.9 %. The spatial pattern of excess deaths shifted over time: early in the pandemic, excess mortality clustered in large urban counties (especially in the Northeast), but later waves brought stronger increases in rural counties, particularly in the South and West. The authors attribute part of this shift to differential vaccination uptake, rural health resource constraints, and challenges in accurate death attribution, and call for more attention to rural communities and improvements in mortality surveillance.

Researchers profiled PBMC immune subsets in 24 children and 41 adults with first-wave, primary SARS-CoV-2 infection (sampling at ~11–12 days post-symptom onset), analyzed 57 adult samples across mild/moderate/severe disease, and followed 18 adults through recovery. Adults displayed more lung-homing CCR4+ CD8+ T cells and exhausted CD56^dim NK cells, while children had fewer lung-homing CD8 cells and an IFN-prone CD56^bright NK exhaustion profile; children also showed more CD5+ translational B cells. Severity-linked patterns included higher IgM memory B cells and atypical CD11c+ IgD+CD27+ B2 cells in mild cases, versus more Igs− B cells, CD56^dim CX3CR1+ NK, CCR6^hi CD28^hi CD4 T_cm, and PD-1+ TIGIT+ CD8 T_em in severe cases. Several severity-associated subsets (e.g., IgM memory B cells) remained stable during recovery (~2 months), suggesting baseline immune features tied to susceptibility; others (e.g., CX3CR1+ NK) declined (p = 3.0×10⁻³), consistent with infection-related signatures.

This study, leveraging large national cohorts in South Korea and Japan, found that individuals who had COVID-19 between 2020–2021 had a modestly elevated risk of developing autoimmune inflammatory rheumatic diseases (AIRD) over the subsequent months compared to matched uninfected controls (adjusted hazard ratio ~1.25 in Korea) and compared to individuals with influenza (aHR ~1.30). The risk was higher in those with more severe acute COVID-19, and similar patterns were observed across both countries. Vaccination against COVID-19 appeared to attenuate the increased risk, except in the subgroup with severe infection.

In a study of 30 Long COVID patients (symptoms > 3 months), 10 recovered COVID individuals, and 20 healthy controls, the authors report that megakaryocytes (MKs) in Long COVID patients are more frequent in peripheral blood (0.28 ± 0.05% vs. 0.03 ± 0.02% in healthy) and carry both SARS-CoV-2 single- and double-stranded RNA and Spike protein. These virus-harboring MKs appear to produce platelets that also contain viral RNA and Spike, and microclots were observed in all Long COVID participants. Additionally, about 30% of Long COVID patients had detectable Spike protein in plasma (at picogram levels), and levels of platelet serotonin and the enzyme TPH-1 were significantly reduced in LC versus recovered individuals.

In a large Norwegian cohort (~112k people with known test status; ~153k questionnaires), self-reported memory function (Everyday Memory Questionnaire (EMQ), 0–4 scale) was consistently worse after a positive SARS-CoV-2 test than after a negative test, across 0–36 months. Adjusted mean EMQ scores for positives vs negatives were 0.66 vs 0.60 at 0–1 month and 0.82 vs 0.62 at 12–18 and 18–36 months; the two groups were similar before testing (0.61 vs 0.60). Worse scores tracked with more days bedridden (e.g., 1.29 if >13 days). The authors emphasize these are mild deficits on average and self-reported. Limitations include potential recall and response bias, residual confounding, and lack of objective cognitive testing. Still, the pattern suggests a persistent association between COVID-19 and perceived memory problems up to three years post-infection.

In a pediatric case-control study (56 long-COVID patients vs 27 controls; mean ages ~10 y), 24-hour Holter analyses found significant heart-rate-variability (HRV) shifts in the long-COVID group: lower r-MSSD and higher VLF, LF, and HF power. Conventional echocardiography was normal in both groups. These findings suggest a cardiac autonomic imbalance—with relative parasympathetic predominance—as a physiologic correlate of long-COVID symptoms in youth.

In a virology sub-study nested within the PANORAMIC trial, nonhospitalized, at-risk adults with early symptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection were randomized to receive a 5-day course of molnupiravir (n = 253) or usual care (n = 324). Although molnupiravir accelerated viral decline during treatment (viral half-life ~0.41 days vs ~0.72 days in usual care), by Day 14 the molnupiravir group showed significantly higher viral RNA persistence and lower anti-spike antibody titers (~2,200 U/mL lower). Modeling suggested that to suppress viral RNA below detection in 95 % of patients might require a longer (≈10-day) regimen. Genomic sequencing revealed that molnupiravir-treated viruses carried increased mutational burdens (on average ~180 extra mutations, higher transition:transversion ratios) and greater diversity. Among residual virus, ~16.7 % of tested samples were culture-positive, with some viable virus detectable up to 9 days post-treatment. No strong signal of consensus-level spike escape mutations was found yet several recurrent substitutions in polymerase and nonstructural proteins emerged. The authors caution that the standard 5-day molnupiravir course may be too short, potentially risking persistence of mutated virus and attenuated antibody responses, and they suggest that longer treatment durations warrant investigation.

This preprint reports that 25 adults who had mild to moderate COVID-19 showed on average a 2.65-year increase in MRI-predicted brain age (Brain Age Gap) compared to 24 noninfected controls, and 80% of the COVID group displayed accelerated brain aging versus 13% in controls. The elevated BAG correlated with poorer performance on cognitive tests assessing attention, processing speed, and executive function.
