Female sex strongly reduced the odds of accelerated aging (OR = 0.015), and a longer interval since infection was modestly associated with reduced risk of accelerated BAG.

This mini-review (April 28, 2023) compiles evidence that Long COVID disproportionately affects premenopausal women and can disrupt female reproductive health—menstrual cycles, ovarian function, fertility, and symptom patterns around menses—while also interacting with pregnancy and menopause. Data points include 33.8% reporting menstrual problems in a 1,792-person LC survey (irregular cycles 26%; heavy bleeding 19.7%) and higher odds of cycle changes vs. general populations (OR 1.34). Case reports describe premature ovarian insufficiency months after infection; in a small prospective cohort of COVID-positive pregnant patients (n=84), 75.9% developed LC-consistent persistence, and glucocorticoid exposure was linked to greater risk of persistent fatigue (RR 6.92). Given the paucity of direct LC studies, the authors review overlapping conditions common in LC—ME/CFS, POTS, EDS, endometriosis—conditions that are 70–80% female and carry elevated risks of dysmenorrhea, amenorrhea/oligomenorrhea, dyspareunia, infertility, fibroids/bleeding, and adverse pregnancy outcomes.

Tang et al. performed a comparative cross-sectional study of plasma soluble factors and neuronal-enriched extracellular vesicle (nEV) cargo in 33 individuals with persistent neurological symptoms after COVID-19 (nLongC), 12 recovered individuals without lingering symptoms (Cov), and 28 pre-COVID healthy controls. They found that IL-1β was elevated in both COVID-19 groups, while IL-8 was elevated only in the nLongC group; BDNF and cortisol were also increased in both groups compared to controls. In nEVs, the nLongC group showed marked upregulation of proteins linked to neurodegeneration (Aβ42, pTau181, TDP-43, etc.), whereas the Cov group showed more limited changes (only Aβ40). These findings support the hypothesis that SARS-CoV-2 infection can lead to chronic peripheral inflammation and sustained stress responses, and may drive pathological changes in neuronal vesicle cargo associated with neurodegeneration.

In a large adaptive, community-based randomized trial (PRINCIPLE), Hayward et al. tested ivermectin (300–400 μg/kg daily for 3 days) versus usual care in 8,811 SARS-CoV-2 positive adult outpatients. The ivermectin arm had a modest acceleration in time to self-reported recovery (HR 1.15, median ~2.06 days faster), but the probability that this effect reached a pre-specified clinically meaningful threshold (HR ≥ 1.2) was low (≈ 19 %). Hospitalization or death outcomes did not differ (OR 1.02, CrI 0.63–1.62), and long-term recovery (e.g. at 6 months) was similar between groups (74.3 % vs 71.2 %).

This case‐control study evaluated 22 SARS survivors unable to resume work 13 to 36 months post-infection and compared them with healthy controls and fibromyalgia patients. The post-SARS group exhibited persistent fatigue, diffuse muscle pain, depression, and unrefreshing sleep. In polysomnography, they showed signs of sleep instability—elevated cyclical alternating pattern rates, REM-related apneas/hypopneas, and an alpha EEG anomaly—paralleling features seen in fibromyalgia and chronic fatigue syndrome.

In a cohort study leveraging US Veterans Affairs healthcare data, Xu et al. (2022) assessed the 12-month risk of new neurologic disorders in 154,068 individuals who survived the acute phase of COVID-19, comparing them to over 5.6 million contemporary controls and 5.9 million historical controls. They found a hazard ratio of ~1.42 (95% CI 1.38–1.47) for any incident neurologic outcome, corresponding to an excess burden of ~70.7 cases per 1,000 persons over 12 months. Elevated risks were seen across diverse domains — cerebrovascular disease, memory and cognition, peripheral nerve disorders, movement disorders, mental health, sensory and musculoskeletal manifestations, Guillain–Barré syndrome, and encephalitis/encephalopathy. These risks held even for nonhospitalized COVID-19 cases and increased in severity with more intensive acute care settings.

In this large retrospective cohort study of 106,428 individuals with deliveries across seven U.S. states, COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy (≥2 mRNA doses) was associated with lower maternal SARS-CoV-2 infection rates (4.0% vs. 5.3%, p < 0.0001) and improved birth outcomes (preterm birth 7.9% vs. 9.4%, stillbirth 0.3% vs. 0.6%, very low birthweight 1.0% vs. 1.5%) compared to matched unvaccinated individuals. Boosted pregnant individuals (≥3 doses) showed further reduction in infection (3.2% vs. 5.6%, p < 0.0001) and a lower stillbirth risk (0.3% vs. 0.5%, p < 0.025) relative to vaccinated but unboosted peers, though differences in preterm birth and very low birthweight did not reach statistical significance.

Across 18 U.S. jurisdictions (≈45% of population), the share of COVID-19 cases that were reinfections jumped from 2.7% during Delta to 10.3% (BA.1), 12.5% (BA.2), 20.6% (BA.4/BA.5), and 28.8% during BQ.1/BQ.1.1; overall 12.7% of 21.9 million cases were reinfections. The share of hospitalizations occurring during reinfections rose from 1.9% (Delta) to 17.0% (BQ.1/BQ.1.1); for deaths, from 1.2% to 12.3% across the same periods. The median time between infections peaked at 411 days (mid-Feb 2022) and later shortened to 335 days in mid-June 2022 before ending the year at 367 days. Findings indicate increasing reinfection frequency and growing shares of severe outcomes occurring during reinfection as Omicron sublineages spread. Limitations include partial jurisdiction coverage, under-ascertainment from unreported tests, use of a >90-day reinfection definition, and ecological assignment of variant periods rather than sequence-confirmed lineages.

In 147 vaccinated workers with prior mild or asymptomatic COVID-19, blood biomarkers of CNS injury—sNfL and sGFAP—were significantly elevated ~1 week after recovery versus 82 healthy controls, with p < 0.001 for both. Those with early cognitive failure (CFQ ≥43; 7.5%) had markedly higher sNfL and sGFAP (both p = 0.005). At ~10 months, biomarkers declined (median sNfL 18.3, sGFAP 77.2 pg/mL) but remained above controls; meanwhile, mean CFQ scores increased (18.1 → 27.1; p < 0.01), and 14.3% met the CFQ threshold, though without biomarker differences by CFQ at that time. The authors infer persistent neuronal/astroglial injury after mild infection but note important limitations: single-center, loss to follow-up, self-reported cognition, and no imaging/CSF or pre-infection baseline.

This large community study (n = 112,964 completers) used an online 8-task battery and found small, measurable cognitive deficits following COVID-19. Deficits were most pronounced in memory, reasoning, and executive function. Individuals with ongoing symptoms ≥12 weeks showed the largest global deficit (−0.42 SD), whereas those who had recovered—whether their illness lasted <4 weeks or had previously persisted ≥12 weeks—showed smaller deficits (about −0.23 to −0.24 SD) compared with never-infected controls. Deficits were larger for infections during early variants (original/Alpha) than Omicron (e.g., Alpha vs Omicron ≈ −0.17 SD) and worse with hospitalization/ICU (ICU ≈ −0.35 SD). The authors caution that these are small effect sizes, gathered in an online, self-selected sample, so causality and clinical impact remain uncertain; nevertheless, effects were still detectable ≥1 year post-infection.

Al-Aly & Rosen’s NEJM editorial reviews evidence that long COVID commonly involves objective cognitive deficits, not just subjective complaints. They spotlight a 112,964-person NEJM study showing deficits that persist ≥1 year, scale with illness severity and symptom persistence ≥12 weeks, and appear to abate when symptoms resolve; press coverage framed these effects as roughly 3–9 IQ-point equivalents depending on severity. Reinfection contributed an additional loss in IQ of nearly 2 points, as compared with no reinfection.

In a longitudinal analysis of 100 top-league attackers, 76% exhibited significant post-COVID changes in at least one of 28 technical match indicators. Fourteen indicators declined after infection—most notably five scoring-linked metrics (xG, npxG, xAG, SCA, GCA)—and several measures of possession, receiving, and take-ons also decreased. Recovery was relatively swift: players needed a mean of 3.09 matches to return to baseline (elite 2.64 vs control 3.55), and age showed little effect on either decline or recovery. The authors attribute short-term reductions to lingering physical readiness and training disruption rather than durable impairment.

In a cohort of 41 patients with post-COVID-19 syndrome (PCS), Kuchler et al. used retinal vessel analysis to examine microvascular endothelial function. They observed significantly reduced venular flicker-induced dilation (3.42% vs. 4.64%, p = 0.02), narrower arteriolar calibers (CRAE ~178.1 vs. 189.1, p = 0.01), and lower arteriolar-to-venular ratios (AVR ~0.84 vs. 0.88, p = 0.007) compared with matched healthy controls. A combined metric of AVR + vFID discriminated PCS patients from controls with area under curve = 0.75. Moreover, worse symptom severity correlated with lower AVR (R = –0.37, p = 0.017), and these microvascular abnormalities were more pronounced in PCS patients with elevated inflammatory biomarker levels (e.g. CXCL10, IL-6). The authors argue that persistent endothelial dysfunction in the microcirculation is a potential pathophysiologic hallmark of long COVID, potentially explaining enduring symptoms such as fatigue and cognitive impairment. They propose that retinal vessel parameters may serve as noninvasive biomarkers in PCS and inform therapeutic strategies aiming to restore vascular health.

This review argues that long COVID involves persistent thromboinflammation, combining endothelial injury, hypercoagulability, platelet activation, and neutrophil NET formation. Together these changes favor micro- and macrovascular thrombosis, reflected by findings such as microclots, elevated D-dimer, and perfusion defects in lungs and brain; survivors of COVID-19 also have increased rates of arterial/venous thromboses after the acute illness.

The authors propose a Bayesian-weighted mutation walker to simulate realistic evolutionary trajectories of the SARS-CoV Spike protein (using observed mutation frequencies), and then cluster and screen candidate lineages for both retained human-cell infectivity (via binding to hACE2) and altered antigenicity (reduced binding to a known neutralizing antibody). They show that one of the candidate “chimeric” Spike variants (Spike1 / RBD1) recapitulates binding energetics close to SARS-CoV-2’s RBD–hACE2 (–23.73 vs –24.7; –80.7 vs –81.2 kcal/mol) yet has much weaker binding to the P2C-1F11 neutralizing antibody (–22.7 vs –83.7 kcal/mol), suggesting that their method could have “foreseen” a SARS-CoV-2–like lineage from SARS-CoV-1. The authors argue that such in silico forecasting, combined with genomic surveillance and pre-emptive broad neutralization strategies, might reduce the severity of future SARS-CoV pandemics. However, the method is demonstrated only retrospectively, and there remain substantial uncertainties about how well computationally predicted lineages correspond to viable viruses in nature. The assay relies heavily on modeling assumptions, limited mutation frequency data, clustering heuristics, and idealized binding-energy estimates, without experimental validation or consideration of other evolutionary pressures (e.g. viral replication fitness, immune environment, host ecology). Thus, while conceptually interesting, the predictive power in real-world viral emergence remains speculative.

In this matched retrospective cohort study of hospitalized adults (6,614 in each group) from January 2022 to January 2023, the incidence of new post-acute sequelae between 90 and 180 days was higher among COVID-19 survivors (17.9 %) than influenza survivors (13.0 %), corresponding to a hazard ratio of 1.398 (95 % CI 1.251–1.562). The COVID-19 group also had higher risks of specific symptoms such as abnormal breathing, abdominal complaints, fatigue, and cognitive issues, and increased rates of all-cause emergency department visits, rehospitalizations, and death (27.5 % vs. 21.7 %, HR 1.303). Mortality alone was substantially higher (1.5 % vs. 0.4 %) in the COVID-19 group (HR 4.378).

In a survey of 11,697 adults in Western Australia who had a documented SARS-CoV-2 infection during the 2022 Omicron wave, 18.2 % met criteria for long COVID at 90 days post-infection. Women, middle-aged individuals (50–69 years), those with underlying health conditions, and participants who had received fewer vaccine doses had higher adjusted risks. The most common symptoms were fatigue (70.6 %) and cognitive difficulties (59.5 %). Over one-third (38.2 %) of those with long COVID consulted a GP in the preceding month, and 1.6 % had hospitalizations related to post-COVID symptoms. Among those previously employed or studying, 17.8 % reported reducing or discontinuing their activity due to residual symptoms.

This review posits that SARS-CoV-2 infection forces a sweeping rewiring of host cellular metabolism—sugar, lipid, amino acid, nucleotide, and redox pathways—by hijacking viral–host protein interactions and essential host factors like ACE2, NRP1, furin, TMPRSS2, and CTSL. The authors argue that beyond the acute infection, a residual human metabolic reprogramming / dysregulation (HMRD) can persist even when the virus is cleared, providing a unifying mechanistic basis for many of the multi-system symptoms observed in long COVID (PASC). They categorize PASC sufferers into four sub-phenotypes based on dominant organ impairments and link them to underlying metabolic derangements.

This cross-sectional survey of 3,329 Indian HCWs (July–Oct 2021) found 19.65% had ever tested positive for SARS-CoV-2; 24.9% of those infected were hospitalized (mean 9 days). Long COVID was identified in 6.19% of the entire cohort, with fatigue/weakness most common. Risk factors for long COVID on univariate analysis included female sex (OR 1.79, 95% CI 1.25–2.57), alcohol use (OR 1.85, 95% CI 1.30–2.64), and blood group B (OR 1.90, 95% CI 1.33–2.70). Breakthrough infections (25.23% of positives; mean 61.9 days post-first dose) were mostly mild; 3.82% experienced reinfection, all among vaccinated individuals.

This study examines how SARS-CoV-2 virions, even when neural infection is minimal, perturb synaptic structure and electrical activity in human-derived neural tissues. Using cerebral organoids, human brain explants, and post-mortem brains, the authors find that exposure to the virus increases expression of presynaptic proteins (Bassoon, LPHN3, FLRT3), induces abnormal presynaptic morphology, and disrupts local field potentials. Intriguingly, virions appear to accumulate at LPHN3–FLRT3 synaptic junctions, possibly interfering physically with synaptic homeostasis. Treatment with an LPHN3 agonist partially restores electrophysiological activity and corrects some morphological abnormalities. While viral replication in neurons is quite low, this work suggests that even non-productive presence of SARS-CoV-2 may have functional impacts on synapses.

🧫Cao et al. present evidence that the antibiotic daptomycin (DAP) can bind SARS-CoV-2 spike protein (including Omicron variant) via molecular docking, and that co-incubation of DAP (1–100 µM) with Omicron pseudovirus enhances its entry into ACE2-expressing HEK-293T cells (∼1.7-fold increase) under normal calcium conditions. The promoting effect is lost when extracellular Ca²⁺ is removed, indicating the enhancement is calcium-dependent. The authors propose a mechanistic model where DAP binds to the S protein, associates with the host cell membrane, and facilitates viral entry.

This study of over 1.7 million U.S. veterans (89,216 with COVID-19 who survived beyond 30 days vs 1.64 million controls) shows that COVID-19 survivors are at higher risk of long-term adverse kidney outcomes. After rigorous covariate adjustment, COVID-19 status was associated with greater risk of AKI, steeper eGFR decline, and higher incidence of the composite “major adverse kidney events” (MAKE: ≥ 50% eGFR decline, ESKD, or death). The severity of the acute COVID course—nonhospitalized, hospitalized without AKI, and hospitalized with AKI—formed a gradient of increasing risk. The authors also modeled individual eGFR trajectories and found accelerated decline among COVID survivors relative to controls (aging the kidney 4 years in the first year following mild infection). Those who had AKI during their acute disease fared worst in long-term kidney outcomes.

In this study, 83 patients with long COVID and persistent neurological symptoms were compared to 22 controls who had recovered from COVID without lingering neurological issues. The long COVID patients showed significantly worse global cognitive performance (mean OCLz = –0.39 vs. +0.32 in controls, P < 0.01), and domain-specific deficits in episodic memory (in 48 % of patients), attention, working memory, processing speed, and verbal fluency and 27 % also had impaired overall cognition. Structural MRI revealed focal cortical thinning in a left posterior superior temporal region, and diffusion tensor imaging indicated widespread white matter microstructural disruption (reduced fractional anisotropy, increased radial diffusivity). Furthermore, altered white matter connectivity metrics correlated with poorer performance in memory, cognitive, and attentional tasks.

Peluso et al. (2024) measured SARS-CoV-2 spike, S1, and nucleocapsid antigens in plasma up to 14 months after infection, comparing 171 post-COVID individuals (mostly before vaccination or reinfection) to 250 pre-pandemic controls. They found that compared to ~2% baseline in controls, there was an excess of antigen positivity of +11.0% at 3–6 months, +8.7% at 6–10 months, and +5.4% at 10–14 months, indicating persistent antigenemia beyond the acute phase. Hospitalized patients and those with worse acute self-rated health had higher odds of antigen persistence.

This study examined 657 individuals ≥3 months post–COVID hospitalization, comparing 426 with persistent symptoms (long COVID) versus 233 who had recovered. By profiling 368 plasma proteins, the authors identified that elevations in markers of myeloid inflammation and complement activation were associated with long COVID. Distinct protein signatures correlated with different symptom clusters: IL-1R2, MATN2, COLEC12 for cardiorespiratory/fatigue/psychological phenotypes; MATN2, CSF3, C1QA for gastrointestinal symptoms; C1QA and nerve-repair proteins (SPON-1, NFASC) in cognitive impairment; and SCG3 (brain–gut axis) in gastrointestinal symptoms. They also saw that some individuals with long COVID maintained higher SARS-CoV-2–specific IgG levels, but viral RNA was not found in sputum, and nasal fluid inflammatory markers were not clearly tied to symptoms. The results support the idea that different mechanistic “subtypes” of long COVID exist, possibly reflecting tissue-specific damage or dysregulation, which may guide future targeted therapeutic strategies.

🧫This study screened 24 commercially available teas to assess their ability to inactivate infectious SARS-CoV-2 in saliva. Five teas (black, green, mint medley, eucalyptus-mint, and raspberry zinger) were further tested at 10 and 40 mg/mL concentrations with short contact times (10–60 s). The authors found that black tea at 10 mg/mL achieved ~3 log (99.9 %) reduction in infectivity within 10 s, while the other teas achieved ~1.5–2 log (96–99 %) reductions. At 40 mg/mL, all five achieved >3 log reduction in 10 s. They also showed that adding teas at different times (before, during, after virus exposure) produced varying inhibitory effects, with the strongest inhibition when teas were present concurrent with infection. While the results are promising, the experiments are purely in vitro, using Vero-E6 cells and virus mixed in saliva, so the real-world relevance is uncertain.

This narrative review summarizes evidence that Melissa officinalis (lemon balm) exhibits antiviral activity against SARS-CoV-2, HSV, and HIV, attributed to phytochemicals such as rosmarinic acid and essential oils (e.g., citronellal, linalool, menthol). Reported mechanisms include blocking HSV-1 attachment, inhibiting HSV-1 replication post-adsorption, and in-silico inhibition of SARS-CoV-2 main protease (3CLpro) and spike interactions. The PubMed record shows ~121 references, indicating broad literature coverage. However, most data are preclinical (in vitro/in silico) with few or no randomized clinical trials

🐁This study demonstrates that SARS-CoV-2 can infect cells that line the blood-retinal barrier (RPE and retinal vascular endothelium) and provoke a hyperinflammatory antiviral response in the retina when the virus is delivered systemically (via intranasal route) in a K18-hACE2 mouse model. Intranasal exposure led to weight loss, ~25 % mortality by day 9, and detection of viral RNA in lungs, brain, and eyes, whereas direct ocular exposure did not lead to lung infection or systemic disease, though viral RNA was still detectable in eyes. In vitro, BRB cells were permissive to SARS-CoV-2 infection, with infection, viral receptor expression, and cell death exacerbated under hyperglycemic conditions. Moreover, chronic exposure to SARS-CoV-2 spike antigen (by intravitreal injection) led to observable retinal vascular and structural abnormalities—including microaneurysms, retinal atrophy, and vein occlusion—after 30 days, hinting that lingering viral antigen may contribute to ocular sequelae. The work underscores a potential route for retinal involvement in COVID-19 and suggests that comorbidities like hyperglycemia may worsen ocular vulnerability.

According to this study by Novavax researchers, repeated administration of SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines is associated with an increasing shift toward spike-specific IgG4 subclass antibodies, whereas a recombinant protein (Novavax) vaccine regimen did not show this IgG4 skewing. The protein vaccine induced much higher IgG3 levels (~10× vs mRNA) and stronger Fcγ effector activity than the mRNA homologous boosters. This class switching toward IgG4 in mRNA vaccinees raises concerns because IgG4 is known to have a lower ability to engage Fc receptor–mediated effector functions (e.g. ADCC, complement activation). Thus, although neutralizing binding may still be present, the shift could reduce the overall functional quality of the humoral response. The findings suggest that vaccine platform choice and booster scheduling may impact not just antibody titers but also antibody functional subclasses, with possible repercussions for long-term protection.

🧫This study uncovers that coatomer complex I (COPI) is a key component in the intracellular transport of SARS-CoV-2 progeny virions from the ER–Golgi intermediate compartment (ERGIC) to the cell surface. Using high-resolution 3D electron microscopy, the authors visualized virion-containing vesicles bearing COPI coats and observed rearrangements of COPI and ERGIC compartments during infection. Functional depletion of the COPI subunit COPB2 trapped progeny virions within the ERGIC and strongly reduced viral release, despite unaltered intracellular viral protein levels, demonstrating that COPI is essential for virion egress.

🧫SARS-CoV-2 remodels host membranes to build its replication organelles. In infected cells, the Golgi apparatus fragments rapidly—detectable by 6 h and complete by 12–24 h—leaving only ~2% of infected cells with an intact Golgi at 24 h versus ~97% of controls; in parallel, the ER condenses around replication sites in ~90% of infected cells versus ~2% of controls. The ER marker calnexin decorates double-membrane vesicles (DMVs), while Golgi protein markers disperse, even as Golgi-derived lipids appear within the replication organelle. Expression screening identified five viral proteins (M, S, E, ORF6, nsp3) that independently fragment the Golgi, with nsp4 also reshaping ER. M alone can generate DMV-like structures. Disrupting Golgi trafficking with brefeldin A inhibits replication, whereas nocodazole yields only a modest, non-significant reduction—implicating Golgi/ER trafficking as functionally important in coronavirus replication.

🧫This paper demonstrates that β-coronaviruses, including SARS-CoV-2, do not use the canonical Golgi/secretory pathway to exit infected cells, but instead egress via lysosomes. Viral particles colocalize with lysosomal markers, and pharmacologic inhibition of Rab7 impairs release. The viral egress is nonlytic, and the infection causes lysosomal deacidification and suppression of lysosomal enzyme activity, which may impair antigen presentation and immune recognition. The authors implicate the small GTPase Arl8b as a regulator of this lysosomal egress route.

🧫The preprint reports that SARS-CoV-2’s spike protein, beyond its role in viral entry, localizes to the nucleus of transfected cells and disrupts host DNA repair by inhibiting both homologous recombination and nonhomologous end joining. This impairment is mediated by reduced recruitment of repair proteins like BRCA1 and 53BP1 to sites of DNA damage, leading to elevated DNA lesions under stress (γ-irradiation, doxorubicin, H₂O₂). Using a V(D)J recombination reporter assay, they further show that spike expression can suppress recombination efficiency in vitro, which could hypothetically interfere with the development of adaptive immune diversity.

This cross-sectional cohort study collected 317 tissue and blood specimens from 225 individuals recovered from mild COVID-19 at approximately 1, 2, and 4 months post-infection, and surveyed 213 of them for long COVID symptoms. Viral RNA was detectable in multiple tissues (liver, kidney, gut, brain, lung, vessels, skin, thyroid, breast) in up to ~30% of individuals early (1 month), declining to ~11% by month 4. Approximately 34% of respondents reported at least one long COVID symptom (most commonly fatigue). Detection of viral RNA conferred a markedly elevated odds of reporting long COVID (OR ~5.17, 95% CI 2.64–10.13), and higher viral loads correlated with higher symptom probability.

In a UK prospective cohort of 536 adults with long COVID (mean age 45; 73% female), 331 with organ impairment or incidental findings returned for ~12-month follow-up after a multi-organ MRI (CoverScan). Symptom burden decreased (median 10 → 3 symptoms), with extreme breathlessness 38% → 30%, cognitive dysfunction 48% → 38%, and poor Health-Related Quality of Life 57% → 45%. Despite improvement in symptoms, organ impairment was frequent and persistent: single-organ impairment 59% and multi-organ 27% at one year; overall, 59% of those followed still had ≥1 organ impaired. Associations included female sex, younger age, and single-organ impairment. Selection and demographic skew, lack of pre-COVID imaging, and industry ties (Several authors employed by the MRI vendor (Perspectum)) temper interpretation, but the data support prevention and integrated care for long COVID.

Men recovered from COVID-19 had no significant differences in standard semen parameters versus controls, but proteomic profiling of sperm identified 190 altered proteins (161 up, 29 down). The authors validated SERPINB4 and calpain-2 changes and found elevated semen MDA, indicating lipid peroxidation and cellular stress. Hormone profiles were broadly similar, except lower testosterone and higher prolactin/cortisol in the post-COVID group.

Pathogens responsible for respiratory infections are often found in aerosols <5 μm, which penetrate deeply into the lungs and remain suspended, implying a major role for airborne transmission. Accordingly, respirators are recommended for health-care workers near infectious patients, while surgical masks—though less protective for the wearer—can limit source emission when worn by the patient. The observed presence of “super-emitters” helps explain super-spreading patterns.

Menezes et al. (2024) analyzed blood transcriptomes in 48 long COVID patients and 12 matched controls, identifying 212 differentially expressed genes (70 after FDR correction). Among these, they detected upregulation of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNAs—including antisense ORF1ab (suggestive of ongoing replication) and structural/ORF transcripts (nucleocapsid, ORF7a, ORF3a, Mpro)—and host genes (e.g. ACE2, TMPRSS2, memory B-cell and platelet transcripts). Multivariate modeling found that antisense SARS-CoV-2 RNA plus host FYN transcript distinguished long COVID from controls with an AUC of 0.94 (sensitivity 93.8 %, specificity 91.7 %). Patients with long COVID had significantly higher viral RNA positivity (e.g. 60 % vs 8 % total viral load positivity) and lower immunometabolism scores, which inversely correlated with viral load; comorbidities increased risk of higher viral RNA load while more vaccine doses were protective (OR 0.36 per dose, so more vaccine doses means lower viral RNA load). These data suggest that persistent viral RNA, possibly reflecting low-level replication, coupled with immune/metabolic dysregulation, may underlie long COVID.

This preprint reports on a 22-month prospective follow-up of over 120,000 adults in Norway, investigating how cognitive and somatic symptoms evolve before, during, and after SARS-CoV-2 infection. The study shows that compared to negative controls, those with a positive test had markedly higher odds of new memory problems (adjusted odds ratio up to 9.4 beyond 18 months) and concentration difficulties (aOR ~4.4 beyond 18 months), along with fatigue, shortness of breath, anosmia, and dysgeusia. Crucially, these differences persisted through the entire follow-up, indicating durable symptom burden among many individuals.

In this study, Chemaitelly et al. estimated how much protection prior SARS-CoV-2 infection confers against reinfection with the JN.1 variant in Qatar. Using a test-negative, case-control design, the authors found that overall protection was essentially negligible (1.8%, 95% CI: −9.3 to 12.6), but when broken down by time since infection, protection was high (82.4%, 95% CI: 40.9 to 94.7) at 3–<6 months post-infection. However, this protection declined quickly, effectively diminishing by one year after the prior infection.

This preprint demonstrates that SARS-CoV-2 can actively suppress MHC class I on infected cells via multiple viral factors, thereby reducing the visibility of infected cells to CD8⁺ T cells. In both in vitro and in vivo settings, SARS-CoV-2 infection blunts MHC-I upregulation, and the effect is particularly strong in Omicron subvariants compared to earlier strains. The authors suggest that this capacity for T cell evasion complements the already known antibody escape features of Omicron and may contribute to its success in causing breakthrough infections and reinfections.

A previously healthy 22-year-old woman developed ptosis and vision loss one month after an inactivated SARS-CoV-2 vaccination, which later worsened following a COVID-19 infection. Diagnostic workup (imaging, biopsy) confirmed IgG4-related ophthalmic disease (IgG4-ROD): infiltration of IgG4+ plasma cells (ratio > 40 %) and > 50 IgG4+ cells per high-power field, along with elevated serum IgG4 (~280 mg/dL). She was treated with corticosteroids and tacrolimus, then later underwent surgical correction of ptosis; histology of levator muscle showed fibrosis. The authors also reviewed 9 previously reported cases of IgG4-related disease in relation to COVID-19 vaccination or infection (5 cases after vaccination, 4 after infection), and note that onset ranged from 1 day to 3.5 months. They propose potential immunologic mechanisms (molecular mimicry, bystander activation, class switching toward IgG4, involvement of IL-10+LAG3+ T follicular cells) linking SARS-CoV-2 antigen exposure and IgG4-RD pathogenesis.

Severe COVID-19 is often accompanied by marked lymphopenia, but the drivers of T-cell depletion are incompletely understood. In this study, the authors show that a specific progenitor subset, TCF1⁺ CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T-cells, declines preferentially with disease severity (e.g. from ~53% in mild to ~32% in severe in the CD8⁺ compartment) and that this decline correlates negatively with severity (Spearman r ~–0.58). The loss is not mirrored in TCF1⁻ cells, suggesting selective targeting of progenitor populations. Further, in patients with severe disease, residual TCF1⁺ cells show impaired proliferation (lower Ki67), reduced expression of Bcl-2 (a pro-survival factor), and a new subpopulation of TCF1⁻, caspase-3⁺ cells hinting at apoptosis. The authors show that serum from severe patients suppresses TCF1 transcription in healthy T cells ex vivo, and that blockade of IL-12 rescues this effect, implicating an IL-12–mediated suppression axis. They argue that this mechanism may underlie T-cell pool collapse in severe COVID-19, and propose IL-12 blockade (or related strategies) as a potential therapeutic angle.

In a Swedish cohort of 589,722 adults with first covid-19 between Dec 2020–Feb 2022, those vaccinated before infection were substantially less likely to receive a clinical long-COVID diagnosis (ICD-10 U09.9). PCC occurred in 0.4% of vaccinated vs 1.4% of unvaccinated individuals. Adjusted analyses estimated 58% effectiveness (HR 0.42, 95% CI 0.38–0.46), with a dose-response: 21% (1 dose), 59% (2 doses), 73% (≥3 doses).

This review addresses how HIV infection modifies the immune response to SARS-CoV-2 and affects COVID-19 outcomes. It emphasizes that people living with HIV (PWH) are immunologically heterogeneous: many on ART recover well, but up to ~30 % fail to normalize CD4 counts and retain chronic immune dysregulation. Epidemiological data largely suggest similar SARS-CoV-2 infection incidence in PWH and HIV-negative persons, but PWH with poor HIV control (low CD4, detectable viral load) face higher risk of severe COVID-19 and mortality. Immunological studies show that PWH with good immune function often mount T-cell and antibody responses comparable to uninfected people, but those with advanced HIV may produce weaker and less durable responses, and may fail to clear SARS-CoV-2 promptly. Prolonged viral shedding (median ~109 days in some cases) and intrahost viral evolution have been documented in immunocompromised PWH. COVID-19 vaccination is generally safe and beneficial in PWH, but efficacy and durability are reduced in those with immunosuppression, and booster prioritization is recommended.

This study enrolled 9 patients undergoing mitral valve surgery about six months after COVID-19 and found SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the left atrial tissue in 4 (≈ 44 %) of them, despite negative viral tests at admission. In two of the RNA-positive patients, the local expression of inflammatory cytokines IL-6 and IL-1β was strongly elevated (one with ~55-fold and ~110-fold increases, another ~7-fold) relative to patients without detectable SARS-CoV-2 in cardiac tissue. These cytokine elevations were confirmed by immunofluorescence in cardiac sections but were not reflected in systemic serum levels, suggesting a localized inflammatory response. Thus, the authors propose that persistent viral colonization of cardiac tissue might contribute to ongoing local inflammation even months after apparent recovery, which could have implications for long-term cardiac sequelae in COVID-19 survivors.

During 2020–2022 in Yorkshire, UK, the authors observed a striking increase in cases positive for anti-MDA5 autoantibodies—from 0.4 % in 2019 to peaks of 4.8 % in 2021 (totaling 60 cases). Of those, 25 developed interstitial lung disease, with 8 fatal outcomes, while the others exhibited features of autoimmune disease (myositis, Raynaud’s, rashes). Few had documented prior COVID-19 infection, and over half had received SARS-CoV-2 vaccines. Through transcriptomic comparisons, the study showed that IFIH1 (MDA5) expression is induced in COVID-19 and in autoimmune ILD (but not in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis), correlating with type 1 interferon and IL-15 signaling and activated CD8⁺ T cell signatures. A protective IFIH1 rs1990760 TT genotype dampened this response in some individuals. The authors propose a new COVID‐associated syndrome (termed “MIP-C”) linking viral exposure, aberrant MDA5 induction, and autoimmune lung injury.

This study is a systematic review and meta-analysis of 17 studies including 41,249 long COVID patients, estimating that 9.3% of individuals experience either mental health conditions or impaired cognition ('brain fog') between 3 and 24 months after infection. Prevalence was higher in community-managed patients (29.7 %) than in those previously hospitalized (19.5 %, p = 0.047), and the risk increased over time and when validated instruments were used to assess outcomes. Notably, the authors found that populations with higher vaccination rates tended to have lower odds of brain fog (p = 0.000), suggesting a possible protective effect.

This review by Zhang et al. (2024) systematically surveys how SARS-CoV-2 exploits host cell factors at every stage of its life cycle — from receptor binding (ACE2, DPP4, AXL, NRP1/2, CD147) and proteolytic activation (TMPRSS2, TMPRSS4, cathepsins, furin) to hijacking of intracellular translation, trafficking, metabolic, and epigenetic machinery — to facilitate replication and propagation, while suppressing host immune defenses (e.g. via NSP1). The authors then link these host–virus interactions to the pathogenesis of COVID-19 across multiple organs (lungs, gut, liver, kidney, reproductive tissues) and hypothesize how persistent dysregulation (e.g. fibrosis, metabolic reprogramming, senescence, chronic inflammation) may underlie long COVID. They propose that therapeutic strategies should include host-targeted agents (e.g. inhibitors of proteases, metabolic enzymes, translation factors, or RNA-G-quadruplex stabilizers) which might have advantages over direct antivirals (e.g. broad spectrum, reduced resistance). However, they caution that many host factors perform essential physiological functions, and that most evidence to date is derived from in vitro or computational studies, with limited in vivo or clinical validation.

This review synthesizes evidence from over 100 prior studies and meta-analyses to argue strongly that masks—especially high-filtration respirators—are effective in reducing the transmission of respiratory infections (including COVID-19), given correct and consistent use. The authors reaffirm that SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted via airborne routes and present a dose-response pattern: better compliance and mask quality yield greater protection. They further find that mask mandates are associated with lowered community transmission, and that respirators outperform medical or cloth masks in controlled comparisons. However, the authors acknowledge limitations: many RCTs in this field suffer from heterogeneity (different settings, masking strategies, compliance levels) and sometimes low infection prevalence, which can bias toward null effects. Some interventions are difficult to blind or enforce.

This prospective cohort study evaluated 96 children with antenatal or neonatal exposure to SARS-CoV-2 and 243 non-exposed controls at 21–32 months of age, using parent-reported development, respiratory symptom, and health care usage questionnaires. After full adjustment, there was no statistically significant difference in overall developmental score (ASQ-3 total). However, exposed children had greater odds of delays in social–emotional domains (OR ~3.58–3.81), higher ASQ:SE-2 scores, more respiratory symptoms (mean LRSQ z = 0.3), and greater use of inpatient (38% vs 21%), outpatient (38% vs 30%) and GP services (60% vs 50%). While these findings suggest that perinatal SARS-CoV-2 exposure might be linked to social-emotional developmental delay and increased respiratory morbidity in early childhood, the study is constrained by its modest sample size, potential selection bias from low enrolment, reliance on parent-reported measures rather than clinical assessments, and only ~2-year follow-up.

This study examines whether maternal SARS-CoV-2 infection is associated with an increased risk of fetal left–right (LR) asymmetry disorders (such as situs inversus or heterotaxy). Across three centers from 2018 to 2023, 151 fetuses with LR asymmetry were identified (overall incidence ~0.85 ‰). Intriguingly, incidence remained low (0.17–0.63 ‰) from 2018 to 2022, but surged to 3.24 ‰ in 2023, coinciding with a large wave of maternal SARS-CoV-2 infection. In a case–control subset (30 cases and 30 matched controls), the infection rate in mothers was 96.67% in the case group versus 73.33% in controls; first-trimester infection (especially around gestational weeks 5–6) was strongly overrepresented (96.6% in cases) and was associated with odds ratio ~13.07 for LR asymmetry. The authors conclude that SARS-CoV-2 infection during the first trimester may significantly increase the risk of fetal LR asymmetry, with cardiac malformations as the most frequent associated structural anomaly (observed in ~90.9% of dysmorphic fetuses with concurrent malformations).

The authors demonstrate that SARS-CoV-2 infection promotes the expression of unproductive splicing isoforms of interferon-related, class I MHC, and splicing-machinery genes. This effect reduces the host’s ability to produce antiviral and antigen-presentation proteins such as IRF7, OAS3, and HLA-B, while inflammatory cytokine genes (IL6, TNF) remain unaffected. These results suggest that the virus selectively disables antiviral defense while preserving inflammatory signaling, potentially explaining the immune imbalance seen in severe COVID-19. By integrating transcriptomic and proteomic datasets, the study further finds that unproductive transcripts correspond to decreased protein translation, and that viral proteins physically interact with the same host systems they disrupt. The work proposes that SARS-CoV-2 evades immune detection by simultaneously hijacking host RNA splicing, nuclear export, and translation machinery.

A preterm infant born at 28 weeks + 3 days to a mother infected with the SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant (unvaccinated) had positive nasopharyngeal SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR from birth through 28 days, turning negative by day 37. Examination of the placenta revealed high viral RNA loads (genomic N1) and subgenomic E RNA, and in situ hybridization detected both the positive S gene strand and negative orf1ab strand, indicating active viral replication in placental tissue. Histopathology showed placental injury consistent with SARS-CoV-2 infection. Because the infant was delivered by cesarean section and handled under sterile precautions, and given the maternal infection and the evidence of replicating virus in the placenta, the authors argue this represents vertical (in utero) transmission of the Delta variant. As a single case, it cannot quantify incidence or risk, but it suggests that under conditions of high viral load and variant virulence, the placental barrier may be breached.

Over a 3-year follow-up of >135,000 SARS-CoV-2–infected individuals and >5 million controls, this study found that the excess mortality risk associated with COVID-19 largely abated by year 3 in non-hospitalized cases, but persisted (IRR ≈ 1.29) in those hospitalized. While the incidence of new post-acute sequelae (PASC) diminished over time in both groups, meaningful residual risk remained into year 3: in non-hospitalized persons, ~9.6 DALYs per 1,000 were attributable to PASC in that year; in hospitalized persons, ~90.0 DALYs per 1,000. Across 3 years, hospitalized individuals bore a substantial burden of additional sequelae (≈ 252.8 per 1,000) compared to controls. This work shows that the health burden of COVID-19 does not fully resolve within 3 years, especially in people with severe (hospitalized) acute disease, though risks decline over time. The findings underscore the need for long-term monitoring and interventions in high-risk groups.

In this study, Tarke et al. assess how symptomatic SARS-CoV-2 breakthrough infections (after vaccination) reshape T cell immunity. In a cohort of vaccinated individuals (n = 27) with available pre- and post-infection samples, they observed that BTI leads to significant boosts in CD4+ and CD8+ T cell responses against Spike in people lacking prior non-Spike reactivity, and induces new or expanded T cell responses to non-Spike viral proteins (M, N, nonstructural proteins). Moreover, variant-specific mutation-containing epitopes emerged post-BTI, constituting about 9–15% of the recognized epitope repertoire. These findings suggest that breakthrough infection broadens and deepens the antigenic scope of T cell immunity beyond the vaccine target. Importantly, the study found no evidence of T cell functional exhaustion in these boosted responses; rather, T cells became more polyfunctional (producing multiple cytokines and cytotoxic molecules). While neutralizing antibody titers also improved modestly, the dominant signature of BTI was on enhancing T cell magnitude and diversity. The effects were consistent across infections during Delta and Omicron waves, indicating that BTIs can extend vaccine-induced immunity by augmenting cellular memory even against variant-mutated regions.

In a South African cohort (n=994; 113 with advanced HIV disease), 54% of those with advanced HIV had prolonged SARS-CoV-2 infection >30 days, compared with 8% in matched controls (11/24 vs 2/24; P=0.0013). In five vaccinated advanced-HIV participants studied longitudinally, viral clearance aligned with the rise of neutralizing antibodies (live-virus FRNT_{50}); measured CD8 T-cell responses did not track with clearance, and CD4 T cells weren’t reliably measurable due to low counts. Complete HIV suppression wasn’t strictly required at clearance, but was important for effective vaccine responses. Persistent infections showed within-host viral evolution and neutralization escape (notably from a Delta infection), although evolved viruses did not escape contemporary population-level neutralizing immunity. Overall, the data indicate that in advanced HIV disease recovering on antiretroviral therapy (ART), neutralizing antibodies are the key proximate correlate of clearing persistent SARS-CoV-2, highlighting the dual individual and public-health value of restoring humoral immunity and maintaining suppressive ART.

In a retrospective study comparing 152 hospitalized COVID-19 patients versus 136 hospitalized influenza patients, the authors found meaningful differences in presentation. Influenza patients more often had respiratory symptoms such as dyspnea, hypoxemia, and underlying comorbidities; in contrast, COVID-19 patients were more likely to present with lymphopenia, elevated CRP, radiological bilateral infiltrates, and being overweight. Although more influenza patients met the threshold for severe disease on admission (NEWS ≥ 5 in 43.4% vs 19.1%), key outcomes — including length of stay, need for ventilatory support, in-hospital mortality, and 30-day mortality — were not significantly different between the groups. These findings suggest that while influenza tends to manifest more severely at entry from a respiratory standpoint, COVID-19 exhibits lab and radiologic features that may help differentiate it early in hospitalization.

This study tests whether IgG from Long COVID patients can transfer symptoms to mice. The authors collected IgG from 34 Long COVID individuals (none hospitalized acutely, sampled ≥90 days post-infection), stratified them into three biomarker-based subgroups (LC1, LC2, LC3), and injected pooled IgG into mice (260 mg/kg). Behavioral assays over 15 days revealed that mice receiving IgG from LC1 or LC3 developed persistent mechanical and thermal hypersensitivity, whereas mice receiving control donor IgG regained normal thermal sensitivity within 2–3 days. One subgroup (LC2) IgG did not provoke hypersensitivity but reduced locomotion transiently. Human IgG was detectable in multiple mouse tissues (spinal cord dorsal horns, DRG, muscle, heart) in all groups without clear intensity differences. Taken together, the results suggest that in some patients, IgG may be a causal (or contributory) mediator of sensory abnormalities in Long COVID, supporting an autoimmune hypothesis.

🐁In a mouse model of SARS-CoV-2 nasal infection that does not directly infect the brain, the authors demonstrate persistent neurological deficits (loss of tyrosine hydroxylase in the olfactory bulb, altered neurotransmitters in the substantia nigra, behavioral changes, and sustained microglial activation). Early antiviral treatment with nirmatrelvir or molnupiravir successfully lowered viral load and lung inflammation, but crucially did not prevent the neurological pathology, suggesting that neuronal damage may be decoupled from ongoing virus presence and instead sustained by chronic inflammation or degenerative cascades. To connect these findings to human neurological diseases, the authors conduct transcriptomic overlap analyses between SARS-CoV-2 datasets and multiple neurological disease datasets, identifying overlapping DEGs, hub regulators (e.g. MAPK14, FOS), miRNA/TF regulatory networks, and candidate drugs (e.g. NADH, FADH, phenelzine). They propose that SARS-CoV-2 may predispose to or exacerbate neurological disease via inflammatory and autophagy-related pathways.

In this study, Sun et al. estimate how much of immunity to SARS-CoV-2 reinfection (conferred by prior infection) is mediated via serum neutralizing antibodies, and how this changes for variant strains. Using household cohort data from South Africa, they measured neutralizing antibody titers to ancestral (D614G) and Omicron BA.1 viruses prior to exposure, then tracked who became infected in Delta and Omicron waves. During the Delta wave, neutralization against D614G accounted for ~ 37 % (95 % CI: 34–40 %) of the protective effect, whereas during Omicron, neutralization to BA.1 only mediated ~ 11 % (95 % CI: 9–12 %) of protection, indicative of substantial antibody escape by Omicron.

Children born to mothers with SARS-CoV-2 infection during pregnancy had a significantly higher incidence of neurodevelopmental delay: 11.6 % of exposed children (20/172) versus 1.6 % of controls (2/128) met criteria for delay (p = 0.0006). Using the Bayley-III instrument alone, 9.4 % of exposed versus 1.6 % of controls had developmental delay (p = 0.0007). Differences were more pronounced in the Rio cohort than in Los Angeles. The study also found that more severe maternal COVID-19 was a predictor of worse developmental outcomes (OR 2.6, 95 % CI 1.1–6.4).

SARS-CoV-2 detection in aerosol from community indoor environments. RNA extracted & N1, N2, E gene fragments of SARSCoV2 were quantified using RT-qPCR. SARSCoV2 RNA was detected in 8.9% of air samples; highest positivity rates in hospitals (16.2%).

In a platform RCT of 1,949 outpatients with COVID-19, a single 180 µg dose of peg-IFN-λ within 7 days of symptoms reduced the risk of COVID-19–related hospitalization or prolonged ED visit from 5.6% to 2.7% (RR 0.49; 95% CrI 0.30–0.76). Secondary outcomes (time to hospitalization and hospitalization/death) favored peg-IFN-λ, and safety was similar to placebo. Benefits were seen regardless of vaccination status and across variant

This prospective observational study of 120 men recovering from confirmed COVID-19 found no SARS-CoV-2 RNA in any semen sample tested (mean ~52.7 days after infection), supporting the conclusion that post-convalescent semen is likely noninfectious. However, sperm quality was significantly impaired early after infection: e.g. 60% of men tested <1 month had progressive motility < 32%, and 37% had sperm concentration < 15 million/mL. DNA damage (via fragmentation index and high DNA stainability) was also elevated early. Over time, the proportion of men with abnormal parameters declined; by >2 months post infection, only ~28% had low motility and ~6% low sperm count. Higher titers of anti-spike and anti-RBD IgG correlated inversely with motility and sperm count.

Sherina et al. assessed 119 samples from 88 recovered COVID-19 patients up to 6–8 months post infection. They observed that while IgM and IgA antibody levels declined rapidly after about one month, IgG levels and neutralizing activity remained reasonably stable through six months. At 6–8 months, ~80% of samples still had detectable anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgG (albeit lower). In subsets, they demonstrated that SARS-CoV-2–specific memory B and T cells persisted in all tested individuals at 6–8 months, supporting the idea that adaptive immune memory from natural infection endures over this timeframe.

Across human nasopharyngeal swabs, human autopsy tissues, and two animal models (hamster and mouse), the authors show that SARS-CoV-2 disrupts mitochondrial biology in a stereotyped way. In nasopharyngeal samples, as viral titers fall, the virus is linked to suppression of nuclear-encoded OXPHOS genes, induction of miR-2392, activation of HIF-1α and glycolytic programs, and engagement of host stress/immune pathways—consistent with a metabolic shift away from oxidative phosphorylation. In autopsy tissues where virus was no longer detectable, mitochondrial transcription had recovered in lung, but remained suppressed in heart (and, to a lesser extent, kidney and liver), while mtDNA transcription and immune defense signatures were increased—suggesting organ-specific persistence of mitochondrial dysregulation after viral clearance. In hamsters, during early infection (peak lung viral load), lung mitochondrial transcripts were minimally perturbed, but were down-regulated in cerebellum and up-regulated in striatum despite no detectable brain virus, indicating a systemic signal impacting the CNS. In mice, mid-phase infection showed partial recovery of lung mitochondrial transcription. Collectively, the data support a model in which an early systemic host response is followed by viral suppression of mitochondrial gene transcription and a glycolytic shift, with tissue-specific recovery or persistence thereafter.

In 292 clinically indicated MRIs (73 PCR-confirmed COVID-19 cases; 219 matched pre-pandemic controls), ≥5 cerebral microbleeds were more frequent after COVID-19 (12% vs 5%; OR 2.66, 95% CI 1.23–5.76). The association strengthened after excluding dementia (OR 3.31, 95% CI 1.47–7.45) and was most evident in patients >70 y (OR 3.54, 95% CI 1.37–9.14). AI-derived counts agreed with radiology reports in 94%.

The study assessed how strict N95 mask usage by staff and patients in three hospital indoor settings (an ICU corridor, a geriatric ward, and an emergency lab) correlated with detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in air and on surfaces. In the corridor—where over 30% of staff did not strictly wear N95 masks—virus RNA was detected in the air, whereas in the ward and lab (with universal N95 use) airborne viral RNA was not detected. These findings suggest that robust, universal N95 use in indoor hospital settings suppresses aerosol presence of SARS-CoV-2, thereby shifting or reducing the airborne transmission potential.

In a controlled human challenge, unvaccinated, seronegative adults were nasally inoculated with a low dose of SARS-CoV-2, and serial nasopharyngeal and blood samples were profiled at single-cell resolution. The authors classified infection trajectories into abortive, transient, or sustained categories, and found that individuals who rapidly mounted local mucosal immune infiltration (especially in nasal tissues) were more likely to clear virus without sustained replication. Importantly, systemic (blood) interferon responses often preceded detectable mucosal responses, and higher baseline expression of HLA-DQA2 in nasal tissue correlated with resistance to sustained infection. They also uncovered that ciliated epithelial cells are a key permissive target with dynamic immune transcriptional changes, and that T cells and macrophages in the nasopharynx may harbor non-productive viral uptake. Through detailed profiling, they resolved 54 T cell states, including clonally expanding, antigen-responding subsets.

This retrospective observational study assessed 2,980 SARS-CoV-2 infection episodes across 13 Swiss hospitals during the BA.4/5 wave (June–September 2022), of which 444 (≈ 15 %) were classified as healthcare-associated. In six hospitals that switched to a more stringent mask policy in late June, the proportion of nosocomial infections declined following the switch; modeling yielded a rate ratio of 0.39 (95 % CI 0.30–0.49) for the shift from situative masking to general HCW masking in contact with patients.

This study performs a longitudinal, multi-omic immune profiling (single-cell transcriptomics/proteomics and plasma proteomics) of 45 SARS-CoV-2 infected individuals who either developed Long COVID or fully recovered. By sampling during acute infection and at 3 and 12 months, the authors identify immune correlates associated with development, persistence, and resolution of Long COVID. The analyses reveal sex-specific pathways: in men destined to develop LC, upregulated TGF-β signaling in proliferating NK cells during acute infection; in women with persistent LC, enhanced IL-1 signaling in monocytes and increased expression of XIST at 12 months. Across both sexes, convergent immune signatures in LC include reduced monocyte co-stimulation, elevated NF-κB transcription factor expression, increased T cell exhaustion (LAG3), lower ETS1 expression across lymphocytes, and elevated intracellular IL-4 in T cells, suggesting a shift toward Th2-biased responses.

This study examined national-level data from Argentina between 2020 and 2022 to assess how COVID-19 vaccination in children (ages 0–17) affected pediatric mortality. The authors observed that in the 3–11 and 12–17 age groups, COVID-19 deaths declined in 2022, when vaccine uptake was higher, whereas in the 0–2 age group (with late and lower vaccine access) no decline was evident. Comparing vaccinated versus unvaccinated children in 2022, they estimate an 8–15× reduction in mortality for those with ≥1 dose, and 16–18× reduction for those with ≥2 doses.

In this JAMA case series of 4 young, previously healthy men with severe COVID-19, investigators found loss-of-function variants in TLR7—an X-linked receptor for single-stranded RNA—across 2 families. Clinically, all required mechanical ventilation (mean 10 days) and ICU care (mean 13 days), and one patient died. Functionally, patients’ immune cells had blunted type I (IRF7, IFNB1, ISG15) and type II (IFN-γ) interferon responses to TLR7 stimulation, consistent with a defect in antiviral innate immunity. The authors conclude that rare TLR7 variants may predispose certain young men to severe disease—though causal inference is limited by the small, observational design.

Neither three vaccinations nor infections with earlier variants, or a combination of both, protects from infection with the more recent Omicron variants of the virus. Over 31 months (April 2020 to November 2022), this study followed 1,446 participants in Heinsberg, Germany, to monitor SARS-CoV-2 seroconversion, reinfection, neutralising antibody titers, and T cell responses across successive variant waves and vaccination periods. Spike-specific IgA fell quickly after infection, but IgG levels remained more durable (estimated 18-month half-life). Nucleocapsid responses waned over 12 months post-infection but were re-boosted during Omicron waves. Meanwhile, SARS-CoV-2–specific CD4⁺ T cells (TNF-α⁺/IFN-γ⁺) also declined over the first year after infection. The highest antibody and neutralisation titers were observed in triple-vaccinated individuals infected in later waves (2021–2022), yet cross-neutralisation against Omicron subvariants (BQ.1.18, XBB.1.5) was minimal across all groups.

Roughly one quarter (~24 %) of individuals recovering from COVID-19 exhibited evidence of cortical hypoxia (reduced cerebral tissue oxygen saturation) measured noninvasively by fdNIRS, even though systemic arterial oxygenation was normal. Those with such hypoxia showed significantly lower oxyhemoglobin, more fatigue, greater depression, reduced quality of life, and worse performance on neurocognitive tests (processing speed, working memory, verbal fluency) compared to both healthy controls and recovered individuals without hypoxia. This suggests that in some people, lingering microvascular or inflammatory brain alterations post-COVID may impair local oxygen delivery and contribute to cognitive symptoms. The authors note that hypoxia might be part of a feedback “hypoxia–inflammation” loop, and that fdNIRS could help identify individuals at risk of long-term neurological sequelae.

Peluso et al. used whole-body PET imaging with a tracer specific for activated T cells ([^18F]F-AraG) in 24 individuals between 27 and 910 days after SARS-CoV-2 infection and found elevated T cell activation in multiple tissues (brainstem, spinal cord, gut wall, bone marrow, cardiopulmonary sites) compared to prepandemic controls. Activation in spinal cord and gut wall correlated with Long COVID symptoms, and in those with persistent lung symptoms, lung uptake was higher. In a biopsy subset (n = 5), intracellular SARS-CoV-2 single-stranded RNA was found in rectosigmoid lamina propria of all five, and double-stranded RNA in three participants up to 676 days post-infection, suggesting viral persistence in gut tissue may contribute to ongoing immune stimulation.

The authors studied 22 COVID-19 decedents undergoing autopsy, sampling skull sawdust along with other tissues to test for SARS-CoV-2 RNA and live virus via cell culture. They detected viral RNA in 2/22 (9.1 %) sawdust samples and successfully cultured live virus in 1/22 (4.5 %), indicating that infective virus can persist in bone‐adjacent material postmortem. For comparison, airway samples yielded infective virus in 13/22 (59.1 %) and nonairway tissues in 2/22 (9.1 %). No viral RNA was found in central nervous system samples, and no occupational COVID-19 cases were identified among autopsy staff.

In 158 health-care workers re-contacted after the first COVID-19 wave, researchers tested taste (n=141) and profiled foliate-papillae transcriptomes (n=43). Previously infected (IgG+) people who couldn’t detect metallic taste from iron-gluconate had higher IgG titers than those who could (p=0.03). Transcriptomics showed that SSI+ IgG+ participants had distinct tongue expression signatures with downregulation of 10 taste-related genes (8 TAS2R bitter receptors) and 5 olfactory receptors (including OR5K1) linked to metal-associated ligands. Self-ratings for common foods did not differ by IgG status. Authors conclude that long-COVID metallic taste complaints align with local chemosensory pathway changes in tongue tissue.

This multimodal meta-analysis pooled 24 studies (functional: 15; structural VBM: 9) covering 933 individuals with prior COVID-19 and 922 controls. Functionally, COVID groups showed reduced activity in the right superior/middle/inferior temporal gyri, insula, orbitofrontal cortex, and left cerebellum. Structurally, they exhibited lower GMV in bilateral anterior cingulate/medial prefrontal and left cerebellum, but higher GMV in amygdala–hippocampal–temporal regions and right striatum; overlap pinpointed the right temporal pole with decreased activity yet increased GMV. Taken together, COVID-19 is associated with distributed abnormalities across temporal, orbitofrontal/medial prefrontal, limbic, insula, and cerebellar circuits—networks relevant to olfaction, emotion, memory, and executive control—providing a plausible neural basis for post-infection symptoms, while emphasizing the need for standardized, longitudinal imaging to clarify mechanisms and recovery.

This multicenter cross-sectional analysis of 15,137 hospitalized pediatric COVID-19 cases across 52 U.S. children’s hospitals identified that 7.0 % (1,060 children) experienced acute neurologic complications, most commonly febrile seizures, non-febrile seizures, and encephalopathy. Children with neurologic complications had significantly worse hospital outcomes (longer lengths of stay, more ICU admissions, higher readmission and mortality rates, and higher costs) compared to those without neurologic involvement. Risk factors for neurologic complications included having preexisting neurologic complex chronic conditions (aOR ~4.14), while younger age and non-neurologic comorbidities were modestly protective; the incidence was somewhat lower during the Delta variant period (aOR ~0.71). The authors emphasize that these neurologic complications are relatively common and clinically consequential in pediatric COVID-19, arguing for prioritization of immunization, especially in high-risk children.

Using data from the Texas CARES survey (October 2020–May 2022), investigators compared persistent symptom rates in nonhospitalized youth (5–18 y) by SARS-CoV-2 antibody (anti-N) status and other factors. 4.5% (82/1,813) reported long-lasting symptoms: 1.5% for 4–12 weeks and 3.3% for >12 weeks. Pediatric risk for persistent symptoms was lower than adults’ across durations. Higher risk of >12 weeks was linked to severe acute symptoms, unvaccinated status, and unhealthy weight; the share reporting persistent symptoms fell from 8.0% pre-Delta to 3.4% during/after Delta. Findings highlight that long-lasting symptoms also occur in nonhospitalized youth, though less often than in adults.

This study introduces the MENSA assay, which measures antibodies secreted by circulating plasmablasts as a way to detect ongoing viral antigen exposure or reactivation. In validated settings of acute COVID-19 or vaccination, MENSA correctly identifies SARS-CoV-2–specific IgG responses. When applied to long-COVID (PASC) patients (n = 60), 40% showed MENSA positivity to SARS-CoV-2 (versus 0% in recovered controls), and additional fractions had evidence of Epstein–Barr virus (37%), CMV (23%), or HSV-2 (15%) reactivation; cumulatively, 60% of PASC patients had evidence of one or more viral drivers. These findings support a model in which ongoing viral persistence or latent reactivation may contribute to long COVID pathology.

This article is a systematic review and meta-analysis of 19 studies (total 21,155 participants) that assessed how post-COVID-19 (≥ 12 weeks after infection) affects work ability and return to work (RTW). The authors find that persistent symptoms—particularly fatigue—and functional impairments often reduce capacity to work, and estimate that just 60.9 % of patients successfully return to work after 12 weeks. Many of those who do return require adjustments in duties or hours to accommodate ongoing limitations.

🐁This study shows that the SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein (NCAP) binds Tau, recruits it to stress-granule–like condensates, and increases pathological Tau phosphorylation (AT8) in cell culture and in mice after hippocampal AAV-NCAP delivery. In N2a and human AD-iPSC neurons, dialing SUMOylation up (via ebselen or SUMO2 co-expression) reduced NCAP condensates; in vivo, SUMO2 lowered AT8 and rescued NCAP-induced rotarod and Y-maze deficits. Typical doses/timelines: ebselen 2 µM or ginkgolic acid 10 µM for 16 h; behavior tested 1.5–3 months post-AAV; 4–6 mice/group. The authors propose that host SUMOylation is a tractable intervention point against NCAP/Tau neurotoxicity.

In this longitudinal study of 106 unvaccinated individuals, sampled ~10 weeks and ~10 months after first SARS-CoV-2 infection, the authors demonstrate that many immune perturbations persist long after acute infection. At 10 months, convalescent individuals still exhibited significantly lower absolute counts of granulocytes, monocytes, and lymphocytes (including T, B, and NK cells), with prominent depletion of recent thymic emigrants and non–class-switched memory B cells. Meanwhile, SARS-CoV-2–specific antibody titers against Spike, RBD, and nucleocapsid proteins continued to decline, especially in younger persons and those with fewer NK or memory B cells.

This study demonstrates that in COVID-19, male patients experience a greater decline in circulating follicular regulatory T cells (cTfr) relative to females, and that in men, a network of T peripheral helper cells (Tph), plasmablasts, proliferating B cells, and atypical CD11c⁺ memory B cells is tightly correlated with neutralizing antibody levels—suggesting that extrafollicular B cell activation compensates for the reduced regulation by cTfr. The strength of these correlations is weaker or differently patterned in female patients, implying a sex-biased reorganization of humoral immune control. The authors propose that this imbalance between regulatory Tfr cells and extrafollicular B-cell networks helps explain observed sex differences in COVID-19 antibody responses. Overall, the findings support a mechanistic hypothesis that in males, a loss of regulatory restraint (via cTfr) may favor extrafollicular B cell pathways, potentially contributing to dysregulated antibody responses, whereas females maintain a more balanced regulatory/effector ratio.

Using matched cohorts of 1.28 million women each (from 4.87 million total records) in the TriNetX network, the authors examined 3-year outcomes after SARS-CoV-2 infection in 2020. Infection was associated with higher hazards of HPV-related invasive cancers—cervix (HR 1.67), vagina (2.31), vulva (1.99), anus (1.92), and oropharynx (1.78)—and similarly elevated risks for the corresponding carcinoma-in-situ lesions (HRs 1.34–1.96). Patterns were largely consistent across age and race strata. The authors propose immune dysregulation after COVID-19 as a plausible link but did not test mechanisms.

This study reveals a conserved signaling axis by which inflammatory or stress signals in the brain communicate directly to skeletal muscle, bypassing neural circuits. In flies and mice, CNS stress (due to bacterial infection, SARS-CoV-2 protein expression, or amyloid-β) triggers ROS accumulation in the brain, which induces expression of Upd3 (in flies) or IL-6 (in mice). The cytokine then travels systemically and activates JAK-STAT signaling in skeletal muscle, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction, reduced energy production, and impaired motor performance. Interfering with IL-6 or JAK-STAT in muscle rescues the dysfunction, supporting the functional importance of this axis. They also conducted rescue and inhibition experiments: interfering with IL-6 or JAK-STAT signaling mitigated the muscle dysfunction phenotype, supporting causality. Their results extend to chronic brain stress models (e.g. amyloid β) and suggest that even after infection clearance, the reduced muscle performance effect may persist beyond the acute CNS insult.

After one year of widespread mask wearing during the COVID-19 pandemic, preschool children (3–5 years) showed a marked improvement in their ability to recognize emotions from masked faces. While in an earlier study the mask-related impairment in toddlers was ~23.4 %, in the follow-up it had dropped to ~10.9 %, making their performance under masked conditions comparable to that of adults. Face masks continued to reduce accuracy in both groups, but the “cost” of masking no longer disproportionately affected toddlers.

In a cross-sectional study of 1,406 healthcare workers in a hospital in southern China, the authors identified 262 SARS-CoV-2 infection events between April and June 2023, of which 161 were reinfections (reinfection rate 11.5%) and 101 were first infections. Nearly all infected HCWs (257/262) had been vaccinated, largely with inactivated vaccines, but the group with first infections had a much higher proportion receiving four vaccine doses (23.8% vs. 3.7%). The average time between first infection and reinfection was about 149.9 days (±11.9). Symptoms in reinfections were generally milder: fever occurred in 50.9% (vs. 83.2% in first infections), myalgia in 37.9% (vs. 56.4%), and rhinorrhea was more frequent in reinfections (60.9% vs. 45.5%). Given the relatively high reinfection rate and short interval, the authors stress the importance of better monitoring and protection for HCWs during ongoing SARS-CoV-2 circulation.

The study demonstrates that patients with Long Covid exhibit persistent spontaneous release of interferon-γ (IFN-γ) from peripheral blood mononuclear cells, even in the absence of ex vivo viral peptide stimulation, a phenomenon not observed in people recovering from acute COVID-19—by 180 days post-infection, spontaneous IFN-γ returns to baseline in those without Long Covid. This sustained IFN-γ release is primarily mediated by CD8⁺ T cells interacting with CD14⁺ antigen-presenting monocytes via MHC class I. Over time, reductions in spontaneous IFN-γ correlate with symptom improvement or resolution, and vaccination was associated with a drop in IFN-γ in patients whose symptoms improved.

Li et al. analyzed single-cell transcriptomes from bronchoalveolar lavage in people with respiratory PASC and from a complementary mouse model. They found a shared pattern featuring pro-fibrotic monocyte-derived macrophages and dysregulated interactions with lung-resident T cells, with IFN-γ emerging as a central driver of these abnormalities. Crucially, neutralizing IFN-γ after the acute phase in mice dampened lung inflammation and fibrosis and improved gas exchange, nominating the IFN-γ signaling axis as a potential target for treating long-COVID lung sequelae.

This study shows that infection with SARS-CoV-2 predisposes patients to coinfection with Staphylococcus aureus, and that such coinfections are clinically deleterious. Using a clinical collection of S. aureus isolates from both SARS-CoV-2–positive and –negative patients, the authors found no clustering by lineage but noted a bias toward low-cytotoxic S. aureus strains in coinfected patients. Clinically, these coinfections were associated with increased mortality during the acute phase. In a mouse model, preinfection with SARS-CoV-2 increased susceptibility to a low-cytotoxic S. aureus strain: coinfected mice had worse outcomes and higher bacterial burdens, indicating that SARS-CoV-2 impairs host defenses in a way that favors secondary bacterial infection, including by strains with relatively weak virulence.

In 21 Division-1 soccer players tested before infection and ~60 days after symptomatic (mild–moderate) COVID-19, CPET showed reduced aerobic capacity: VO₂max dropped from 57.35 to 54.34 ml·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹, VO₂RC from 49.80 to 47.47, and treadmill time from 17.54 to 16.56 min. Velocity at VO₂max fell (17.43 → 16.86 km·h⁻¹), HR at ventilatory threshold and at RC rose, while VO₂ at VT, velocities at VT/RC, and HRmax were unchanged. The authors infer that two months may be insufficient for full recovery of aerobic performance in elite players and advise individualized return-to-play assessments.

Over a 2-year follow-up of COVID-19 survivors (n = 144 initially, 57 at 2 years), the authors found increasing prevalence of long COVID in lung and kidney systems: pulmonary fibrous stripes were observed in 8.7 % of patients at 1 year and 17.8 % at 2 years, and renal long COVID in 15.2 % and 23.9 % respectively. Using clinical and multi-omics data collected within the first 30 days of infection, they built a machine learning model with 87.5 % accuracy to predict which patients would develop pulmonary or renal long COVID. Molecular profiling revealed that downregulation of serum surfactant-associated protein B correlated with persistent lung changes, while suppression of urinary proteins was linked to renal long COVID.

🐁his study compares Delta, Omicron BA.1, and BA.2 in human iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes and in hamsters. BA.2 infected the highest fraction of cardiomyocytes (55.7% vs 30.4% BA.1 vs 8.3% Delta at 24 hpi) and reduced cell numbers by ~37.5% at 48 hpi. In hamsters, cardiomyocyte necrosis occurred in 6/6 BA.2 vs 2/6 Delta at 2 dpi, with higher pathology scores (necrosis, immune infiltration, congestion, edema) for BA.2. BA.2-induced repression of mitochondrial/contractile genes and ion-handling genes (e.g., SDHA, MYL2, MYH7, TNNI3, SCN5A, KCNJ2, CACNA1C, ATP2A2) suggested impaired cardiac energetics and electrophysiology, and some changes persisted to 7 dpi after viral clearance.Mechanistically, BA.2 exploits TMPRSS2-independent endocytosis, matching the lack of TMPRSS2 in cardiomyocytes. Notably, BA.2 did not cause worse lung disease than Delta (similar or milder pathology with lower lung titers), implying its cardiac pathogenicity is not secondary to respiratory severity. Overall, BA.2—despite milder airway disease—directly damages the heart in vitro and in vivo.

In a prospective UK cohort of 475 hospitalized COVID-19 survivors (mean age ~58 years), Taquet et al. found that at 2–3 years post-discharge participants performed ~0.71 SD below expectations across cognitive domains, and many experienced psychiatric symptoms: ~74.5% had at least mild depression, ~53.5% anxiety, ~62.3% fatigue, and ~52.1% subjective cognitive decline; over 20% met criteria for severe depression, fatigue, or cognitive decline. Symptoms such as depression, anxiety, and fatigue were on average worse at 2–3 years compared to 6 or 12 months, indicating both persistence and new onset in some individuals. Importantly, later symptom severity was not well predicted by the acute illness severity, but was strongly linked to the 6-month recovery profile (explaining ~35–49% of variance), and to a “biocognitive” signature (acutely high D-dimer relative to CRP). Objective cognition at 2–3 years was mainly predicted by cognition at 6 months (explaining ~10.6% variance). Around 26.9% of participants changed their occupation (often for health reasons), and those occupational changes were specifically associated with both objective and subjective cognitive decline (OR ~1.5 per decrement in cognitive score).

🧫The authors used human forebrain and midbrain organoids to compare the ability of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron BA.2 to infect and replicate versus WT, Delta, and BA.1. They found that BA.2 achieved substantially higher replication (e.g. 3.7-, 5.1-, and 7.9-fold greater than WT, Delta, BA.1 in forebrain organoid supernatants at 96 h) and induced less type I interferon and proinflammatory cytokine responses. Immunostaining showed that BA.2 can infect mature neurons and glial cells (but not progenitor SOX2⁺ cells), with evidence of neuronal degeneration. Moreover, BA.2 triggered stronger apoptosis (measured via CHOP, PUMA, TUNEL, caspase-3) than the other variants. In supplementary testing, BA.5.2 replicated even more efficiently than BA.2 in the organoid systems.

The authors compared the incremental effect of multiple comorbidities on mortality across COVID-19, cardiovascular disease, and cancer using ISTAT death registry data for 2020–2021. They stratified decedents by number of comorbidities and expressed the death counts in those strata relative to deaths in persons with only one comorbidity. While having multiple comorbidities increased death rates in all three conditions, the amplification was far more dramatic in COVID-19: the ratio of deaths in patients with six or more comorbidities to those with one comorbidity was 136.7 for COVID-19, compared to maximum ratios of ~12.1 for cardiovascular disease and ~12.5 for cancer.
