This preprint presents evidence that a subset of long COVID patients harbor autoantibodies against nervous system proteins, and that those autoantibodies may causally mediate neurological and pain symptoms in the syndrome. Using a >21,000 human protein microarray, the authors identified elevated autoantibody responses in LC patients with neurological features; purified IgG from these patients bound neural tissues (pons, sciatic nerve, meninges) and such binding correlated with symptoms like headache and disorientation. When the patient IgG was passively transferred into mice, the animals developed heightened pain sensitivity, balance/coordination deficits, and motor changes that recapitulated aspects of donor symptom profiles.

In 199 MIS-C cases versus 45 infected controls, the authors map antibodies and T-cells and find an immune focus on a nucleocapsid region (aa 134–190, “MADS”) that mimics a motif in the host protein SNX8 (linked to the mitochondrial MAVS pathway). Many MIS-C children with anti-SNX8 antibodies also carry cross-reactive CD8⁺ T cells that bind both the viral and self epitopes; at least 17% of MIS-C sera are SNX8-autoreactive by strict testing (≈37% with broader criteria). Several cross-reactive TCRs were cloned/validated; estimated circulating frequencies are ~10⁻⁴–10⁻⁵ of CD8⁺ T cells, and binding fits HLA-A*02. This supports molecular mimicry as a mechanistic link between SARS-CoV-2 infection and a subset of MIS-C. Limitations include small T-cell experiment Ns, focus on HLA-A*02–restricted epitopes, and heterogeneity (many MIS-C cases lack SNX8 reactivity), so this is not a universal explanation.

Ximeno-Rodríguez et al. present a computational study proposing that the SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid (N) protein could bind to CD147 on lymphocytes, enabling infection of these immune cells. They argue that certain N genotypes (notably “N/120” and “N/152”) yield enhanced binding affinity in docking simulations, which might lead to lymphocyte depletion and immune suppression. This mechanism is hypothesized to underlie persistent viral reservoirs and contribute to long COVID or an “AIDS-like” syndrome following SARS-CoV-2 infection. Because the study is purely in silico, it lacks experimental confirmation of infection, replication, or clinical immunologic impact. The predicted binding affinities do not guarantee real biological effect, and no patient data link these genotypes to immunodeficiency.

🐁This study demonstrates that SARS-CoV-2 can infect peripheral sensory and autonomic neurons in vivo and in vitro, establishing productive replication within ganglionic neurons (including TG, SCG, and LS-DRG), and thereby offering a potential pathway for CNS neuroinvasion ahead of systemic viremia. In infected mice, very high proportions of SCG neurons (93–96%) and a substantial fraction of TG neurons (37–41%) became positive for viral antigen by day 6 post infection, and dsRNA signatures confirmed intra-neuronal replication. Using primary neuronal cultures, the authors show that neuropilin-1 contributes to neuronal entry, though inhibition does not fully block infection, indicating other routes may exist.

This article reports a 35-year-old man who, after a mild episode of COVID-19 in December 2020, developed persistent symptoms over months—fatigue, brain fog, body aches, exertional malaise—that persisted as a long COVID syndrome. Over time, imaging revealed bilateral hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and biopsy confirmed non-necrotizing granulomas consistent with sarcoidosis. Modest elevations in inflammatory markers (ESR 23 mm/h, CRP 3.1 mg/dL) were present. When systemic corticosteroids were initiated, the patient’s sarcoidosis responded, and remarkably many of his long COVID symptoms resolved; ACE levels normalized.

This controlled human aerosol study evaluated how well different face coverings reduce exhaled SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA ('source control') in 44 infected volunteers. By comparing paired masked vs unmasked exhaled breath samples, the authors found that duckbill N95 respirators reduced exhaled viral load by ~98 % (95 % CI 97–99 %), significantly outperforming KN95, surgical, and cloth masks. Cloth masks (≈ 87 % reduction) performed better than surgical and the tested KN95 in this context.

In a cluster-randomized trial among 1,441 health care workers in Beijing, MacIntyre et al. compared continuous use of medical masks vs N95 respirators (fit-tested or not) over 4 weeks, with an additional no-mask control group of 481. They measured clinical respiratory illness, influenza-like illness, laboratory-confirmed respiratory viral infection, and influenza. The N95 groups showed lower incidence across all outcomes (e.g. CRI 3.9% vs 6.7%, influenza 0.3% vs 1.0%), and non–fit-tested N95 masks were significantly more protective than medical masks for CRI after clustering adjustment, but no statistically significant difference emerged for other endpoints. There was no advantage of fit testing in this trial, and compliance was good, with few fit-test failures. In the intention-to-treat analysis (adjusted for clustering), non–fit-tested N95 respirators were significantly more protective than medical masks for CRI, but differences for ILI, lab-confirmed virus or influenza were not statistically significant after clustering adjustment. There was no significant difference between fit-tested and non–fit-tested N95 arms in any outcome, and fit test failure rates were low. In a post hoc analysis adjusting for confounders (hospital level, high-risk procedures, vaccination, handwashing), use of N95 (vs medical mask) and hospital level remained significant predictors, whereas medical mask use, vaccination status, handwashing, and performance of high-risk procedures did not.

Analyzing 441k infected veteran patients vs 4.75M controls, the study estimated 1-year PASC risk across pandemic eras. In unvaccinated people, risk fell from 10.42% (pre-Delta) → 9.51% (Delta) → 7.76% (Omicron). In vaccinated people, it was 5.34% (Delta) → 3.50% (Omicron). Decomposition attributed about 72% of the decline to vaccination and 28% to era/variant changes.

🧫The study demonstrates, in permissive cultured cells, that SARS-CoV-2 can persist in an “infectious form” despite treatment with 3CL protease inhibitors (like nirmatrelvir). This residual infectivity decays slowly (half-life ~ 1 day) and can reignite viral replication after drug withdrawal. Interestingly, this persistence was not seen with treatment by a polymerase inhibitor (remdesivir). Extending the protease inhibitor treatment beyond 8 days in vitro prevented viral rebound upon treatment cessation. These results suggest a possible mechanistic basis for the ~ 20 % of patients who clinically experience viral rebound after nirmatrelvir therapy.

This study assessed how personality traits (via the HEXACO model plus narcissism, sadism, and compassion for others) correlate with pandemic behaviors — mask-wearing, social distancing, and hoarding — in a sample of 455 U.S. university students. Participants who always wore masks scored higher in compassion and lower in sadism; those who consistently socially distanced were higher in openness, conscientiousness, and compassion; and hoarders scored lower in agreeableness. Some hypothesized trait effects (e.g. extraversion, honesty-humility) were not observed. The authors interpret these results as suggesting that prosocial traits may encourage compliance with health-protective behaviors, whereas darker personality traits may undermine them.

Cynomolgus macaques exposed to lethal aerosolized monkeypox virus (Zaire strain) died 9–17 days later from fibrinonecrotic bronchopneumonia. Early virus replication occurred in the lower airways and regional lymph nodes, followed by monocytic cell-associated viremia and necrotizing lesions across multiple organs (lymphoid tissues, thymus, spleen, skin, oral mucosa, GI tract, reproductive system), with the liver rarely involved. Viral antigen was abundant in epithelial, macrophage, dendritic, and fibroblast populations; endothelial involvement was seen in lung. Apoptosis in lymphoid/epithelial tissues was confirmed by TUNEL; Guarnieri bodies were occasional, and syncytia appeared sporadically.

In a Colombian cohort of 100 patients with neurologic post-COVID sequelae (50 previously hospitalized, 50 non-hospitalized), researchers found that brain fog (60%) and fatigue (74%) were the most common persistent symptoms, along with myalgia, sensory disturbances, sleep problems, and anxiety. The hospitalized group had more frequent abnormal neurologic exam findings (64% vs. 42%), while the non-hospitalized group performed worse on executive function testing (T = 42.6 vs 48.5). Both groups had deficits in processing speed and attention compared to normative populations. Symptomatic anxiety and depression were associated with worse cognitive performance and quality of life. Importantly, brain fog and fatigue persisted across durations of Long COVID, and exploratory modeling suggested incremental monthly increases in risk for depression, tinnitus, anxiety, and brain fog with longer symptom duration. The authors argue that neurologic manifestations of Long COVID are frequent, long-lasting, heterogeneous, and present even after 'mild' acute disease.

By 12 months after an Omicron SARS-CoV-2 infection (or reinfection), about 7 % of children and young people (CYP) reported ongoing or new cognitive impairment (“brain fog”), with no significant difference between first infections (7.0 %, 24/345) and reinfections (7.5 %, 27/360). The onset of symptoms was most often when first tested or by 3 months, and older adolescents (15–17 years) were disproportionately represented among those with lingering cognitive issues. Those who reported cognitive impairment consistently had worse mental health, greater fatigue, poorer well-being, and more sleep problems across the follow-up.

In this study, the authors investigate the pathophysiological basis for post-COVID cardiovascular symptoms by analyzing endomyocardial biopsies from five Long COVID patients who developed myocarditis or related cardiac issues. They document inflammatory infiltration, myofilament damage, and especially pervasive mitochondrial ultrastructural abnormalities (vacuolization, cristae disruption) in cardiomyocytes. Parallel studies in mice infected with Omicron subvariants (BA.5.2, BQ.1) reveal similar mitochondrial disorganization in cardiac tissue, with cristae density reductions (to ~9–15 µm⁻¹ versus ~32 µm⁻¹ in healthy controls) and differential expression of mitochondrial transport proteins (e.g. TOM/TIM family, ADP/ATP translocases).

This study analyzed data from 898 school-age children (6–11) and 4,469 adolescents (12–17) with and without prior SARS-CoV-2 infection to characterize prolonged symptoms (≥ 90 days) associated with Long COVID. Using adjusted models, they identified 14 symptoms common to both age groups and found additional age-specific symptoms. Through LASSO modeling, the authors derived age-tailored “PASC research indices” (weighted symptom sums) that discriminated children with infection history and correlated with worse caregiver-reported health, quality of life, and developmental outcomes. Cluster analyses revealed 4 phenotypes in children and 3 in adolescents. For example, in school-age children, the index emphasizes neurocognitive, and gastrointestinal symptoms, while in adolescents the index emphasizes changes in smell or taste, and fatigue/malaise symptoms.

This preprint applies single-cell transcriptomic re-analysis of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid to discern how lung immune cell states differ across COVID-19 severity. The authors find that severe disease is associated with a marked expansion of neutrophils with hyperinflammatory and survival signatures (e.g. IL1β, ICAM1, MCL1), coupled with a shift in macrophages toward proinflammatory M1 phenotypes and upregulation of pyroptosis pathways. Dendritic cells in severe cases show reduced antigen-presenting capacity and increased apoptosis, while NK and T cells manifest signs of activation but also exhaustion and dysfunction.

🐁In a mouse model, SARS-CoV-2 populations evolving in the central nervous system show significantly greater genetic diversity than in the lung after intranasal infection. A recurring target of variation is the spike furin cleavage site (FCS). Deletion of the FCS reduces virulence when infection is initiated intranasally (lower viral loads, less morbidity), but when infection is delivered intracranially, the ΔFCS mutant regains CNS virulence, though its ability to spread from CNS to lung is impaired without the FCS.

The authors performed a genome-wide DNA methylation comparison between 96 post-COVID individuals (6 months after infection) and 191 controls, finding 42 CpG sites differentially methylated (FDR < 0.05) largely in promoter/CpG island regions (including genes like GLUD1, ATP1A3, ARRB2). They also detected an increase in stochastic epigenetic mutations (SEMs) across the genome (mapping to 790 genes) in the post-COVID group, implicating pathways such as insulin resistance, VEGF signaling, apoptosis, hypoxia response, and T-cell activation. These epigenetic signatures were accompanied by a modest but significant acceleration of epigenetic age (via Horvath’s clock) in those with prior COVID-19

This study demonstrates that commercial immunoglobulin replacement products now commonly contain neutralizing antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, reflecting widespread donor vaccination or prior infection. In 35 antibody-deficient patients on IRT, anti-spike antibody levels increased from a median of ~2,123 U/mL to ~10,600 U/mL post-infusion, and neutralization titers rose to levels approximating healthy donors. The immunoglobulin products themselves neutralized Omicron subvariants including BQ.1.1 and XBB in live-virus assays, though with variability among batches. Initiation of IRT alongside remdesivir in patients with antibody deficiency and prolonged COVID-19 infection (median 189 days, maximum >900 days with an ancestral viral strain) resulted in clearance of SARS-CoV-2 at a median of 20 days.

A meta-analysis showed over a five-fold increased occurrence of AD (Alzheimer’s disease) with Chlamydophila pneumoniae infection which is a pathogenic bacterium frequently causing pneumonia. Spirochaetal infection that also can be occurred in the lung infection had over a ten-fold increased occurrence of AD. Additionally, some pathogenic bacteria use their own molecular mechanisms to indirectly contribute to the development of AD. the impact of COVID-19 on cognitive function has been the focus of an increasing number of researchers. [In a recent study,] overall incidence of cognitive impairment among older COVID-19 survivors was 19.1%. These research literatures suggests that microbial infections of the lungs are associated with AD and cognitive dysfunction.

🐁This study identifies a spike–fibrin interaction that reprograms blood clots to be pro-inflammatory and resistant to breakdown. In mice, fibrin’s inflammatory domain was necessary for lung thromboinflammation, microglial activation, and neuronal loss after SARS-CoV-2 infection; spike plus fibrin could also trigger brain innate immune activation without active infection, aligning with Long COVID observations. Binding affinities were measured (Kd ≈ 390 nM for trimeric spike–fibrin; 98 nM for S1(N501Y)), and the relevant fibrin γ-chain epitope (γ364–395) was mapped. A fibrin-targeting monoclonal antibody (5B8) blocked microglial activation, neuronal injury, and lung thromboinflammation without impairing normal hemostasis, and a humanized version has entered phase 1 safety testing.

This preliminary study examined whether amyloid-type microclots are present in “unclotted“ platelet-poor plasma of COVID-19 patients, comparing 20 COVID-19 cases versus 10 T2DM and 10 healthy controls, using a fluorescence-based amyloid stain. The authors found substantially elevated microclot burden in COVID-19 plasma, such that using defined percent-area cutoffs they report sensitivity 85% and specificity 100% (COVID vs healthy), and they claim a “100% sensitivity (P < 0.0001)” in distinguishing COVID-19 from controls. The T2DM group also showed some microclot signal, which complicates the diagnostic discrimination; T2DM vs COVID-19 comparison yielded sensitivity 69% and specificity 67%.

🧫This peer-reviewed lab study tested whether SARS-CoV-2 spike S1 directly alters clot formation. Using healthy donor plasma (n=10–11), the authors found that adding 1 ng/mL S1 increased amyloid-like fibrin(ogen) signal from a median 0.3% to 1.9% (P=0.004) and, with thrombin, from 0.9% ± 0.6 to 2.4% ± 1.3 (P=0.0036). Platelets became hyperactivated, and microfluidic assays showed more disruptive clots with spike-exposed plasma versus control. Proteomics indicated spike-associated structural/trypsin-resistant changes in β/γ-fibrin(ogen), complement C3, and prothrombin. The authors argue that spike can promote fibrin(ogen) conformations resistant to fibrinolysis, helping explain microclots reported in COVID-19.

This longitudinal study followed 40 adults with prior COVID-19 (22 moderate, 18 severe) against 30 controls, assessing neuromuscular function (via chronaxie and related SET metrics) and muscle architecture (ultrasound echogenicity, thickness, fascicle length, pennation) of tibialis anterior and gastrocnemius lateralis over 4 timepoints across 12 months. Severe-COVID participants showed substantially higher NED prevalence in tibialis anterior—55.55%, 33.33%, and 16.66% at the first three visits—and elevated chronaxie early after illness (p < 0.001). Echogenicity—a marker of reduced muscle quality—was consistently higher in severe cases across muscles, especially early. Echogenicity predicted chronaxie (≈ +652 µs, +468 µs, +81 µs per unit at ~days 21–30, 31–90, 91–180, respectively; nonsignificant by 181–360), linking structural abnormalities to impaired excitability. The authors interpret the pattern as long-COVID polyneuromyopathy centered on tibialis anterior, with implications for targeted rehabilitation.

In a community survey of 1,485 residents in Shenzhen, China (August 2023), the authors found that 73.3 % (1,089) reported prior SARS-CoV-2 infection; among those, 89.1 % reported at least one ongoing persistent symptom and 70.3 % had two or more. The most common symptoms were fatigue (46.7 %), cough (44.3 %), headaches (23.5 %), dizziness (19.7 %), chest tightness/shortness of breath (18.2 %), loss/change in smell or taste (17.9 %), impaired sleep (17.1 %), and brain fog (13.3 %). About 14.1 % of the infected individuals reported reinfections. After adjustment for demographics, reinfection was associated with elevated odds of reporting headaches (OR 1.54), loss/change in smell or taste (OR 1.90), impaired sleep (OR 1.55), and brain fog (OR 1.76). Older age (≥ 45) and higher educational attainment were also linked to higher likelihood of certain persistent symptoms.

In a cross-sectional sample of 102 individuals living with Long COVID (average symptom duration ~15 ± 10 months), the authors assessed self-reported physical symptoms (fatigue, dyspnea, post-exertional malaise, myalgia) along with objective movement data (accelerometry) and functional tests (6MWT, chair-stand, TUG). They found that fatigue, post-exertional malaise, and having multiple symptoms were negatively associated with daily step counts, while post-exertional malaise was also inversely associated with moderate-to-vigorous physical activity. Dyspnea in particular was linked to poorer performance in the battery of functional capacity tests. These results suggest a pattern whereby certain symptoms (especially fatigue and PEM) relate more to reduced physical activity (behavioral limitation), while dyspnea may limit actual functional capacity.

Preterm infants with very low birth weight (VLBW) who experienced their early development during the COVID-19 pandemic showed significantly worse outcomes in language, cognitive, and gross motor domains compared to similar infants born and assessed before the pandemic. The study of 1,683 infants found that, adjusting for confounders, the pandemic-exposed group had lower language scores at both 18–24 and 33–39 months, a mean 7-point deficit in cognitive scores at the later follow-up, and a higher rate of gross motor delay (≤ –1 SD).

This article proposes that long COVID (LC) and hypermobility spectrum disorders (HSD, including hypermobile Ehlers–Danlos syndrome) share substantial clinical and mechanistic overlap. The authors note that joint hypermobility is found in 30–57 % of patients with LC, ME/CFS, fibromyalgia, and POTS (versus ~10–20 % in the general population). They argue that both conditions manifest with musculoskeletal pain, dysautonomia, fatigue, and cognitive dysfunction, and may share pathophysiologic pathways such as persistent inflammation, mast cell activation, connective tissue damage, mitochondrial dysfunction, and remodeling of the extracellular matrix. They further suggest that in some cases, COVID-19 might trigger or worsen hypermobility via chronic inflammatory or adrenergic stress, particularly in genetically susceptible individuals (e.g. those carrying MTHFR polymorphisms).

During adolescence, cortical thinning is a normal developmental process; Corrigan et al. used a normative model to estimate expected thinning, then compared post-lockdown scans and found that adolescents (especially females) showed excess thinning consistent with an acceleration of brain maturation (~4.2 years “older” in females, ~1.4 years in males). This pattern was more widespread in female brains, whereas in males effects were more localized. The authors argue that pandemic lockdowns and associated stressors may have driven these deviations in brain structure.

🧫This preclinical study tested a 1% astodrimer sodium nasal spray against SARS-CoV-2 in cell cultures and human nasal epithelium models. The spray reduced infectious virus by 96.6% after 4 h (0.07 vs 1.53 log₁₀ PFU/mL vs PBS; p<0.0001) and preserved epithelial integrity, cilia beating (within 4–8 Hz), and mucociliary clearance. By contrast, HPMC-based spray impaired mucociliary function and epithelial integrity (TEER falling to ~5–29 Ω·cm² depending on dose/time, far below the 100 Ω·cm² integrity threshold), and NO-NS reduced virus by about 90% but showed monolayer disruption in microscopy. The authors conclude astodrimer sodium spray shows an acceptable nonclinical efficacy and safety profile as a barrier nasal spray.

Across four phase-3 trials (mRNA-1273, AZD1222, Ad26.COV2.S, NVX-CoV2373) conducted in 2020–2021, vaccinated participants who developed COVID-19 often had lower viral loads at diagnosis than placebo recipients. The mRNA-1273 and NVX-CoV2373 trials showed ~2–3 log10 lower loads (–2.12 and –2.78 log10, respectively), implying markedly fewer viral copies; AZD1222 and Ad26.COV2.S showed no statistically significant VL reduction. Because viral load is only a proxy for infectiousness, and measurements were single time-point during the ancestral-strain era with uneven case numbers, the findings suggest—but do not prove—that some first-generation vaccines reduced short-term transmission early in the pandemic.

This prospective case–control study of 61 SARS-CoV-2–infected pregnant women and 10 uninfected controls provides evidence that SARS-CoV-2 can actively replicate within the human placenta. Among infected placentas, 15 (≈ 24.6 %) had detectable replication, and 3 (≈ 4.9 %) showed intense replication; notably, the three intense-replication cases were all associated with fetal demise (stillbirth or miscarriage). The authors found that higher viral protein/RNA scores correlated with more severe maternal COVID-19, and that ACE2 expression was elevated in infected placentas, while immune/inflammatory marker expression did not differ significantly versus controls.

In a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled pilot trial, 41 participants with fatigue-dominant Long COVID were treated for 4 weeks with the metabolic modulator AXA1125 (twice daily) versus placebo. The primary mitochondrial function measure (phosphocreatine recovery time constant, τₚ꜀ᵣ) and 6-minute walk distance showed no significant differences between groups. However, fatigue — as measured by the Chalder Fatigue Questionnaire — improved significantly more in the AXA1125 group (mean difference –4.30, 95% CI –7.14 to –1.47; P = 0.0039). The treatment was generally well tolerated: more participants in the AXA1125 arm reported mild adverse events (52.4 %) compared to placebo (20 %), but none were serious or led to discontinuation. The authors conclude that although the primary mitochondrial endpoint was not met, the fatigue benefit is promising and warrants further investigation in larger, multicentre trials.

Preschool children (younger than ~5 years) mount a qualitatively and quantitatively distinct adaptive immune response to SARS-CoV-2 compared with older children and adults. During infection, these youngest children show lower frequencies of SARS-CoV-2-reactive CD4⁺ T cells, whereas older children and adults with mild disease exhibit similar magnitudes and phenotypes of CD4⁺ T cell responses. Adults with severe disease tend toward more proinflammatory and cytotoxic T cell profiles. Eleven months after infection, preschool children maintain neutralizing antibody levels comparable to adults but have notably fewer circulating SARS-CoV-2 reactive memory B cells. Despite this lower B cell memory quantity, preschoolers’ memory CD4⁺ T cells exhibit distinct phenotypic features, including higher inflammatory signatures and traits associated with migration toward inflamed tissues.

This study examined whether SARS-CoV-2–specific long-lived plasma cells are established in the bone marrow after mRNA vaccination, which might explain why vaccine-induced antibody levels decline relatively rapidly. In 19 adults (2.5–33 months post-vaccination), the researchers sorted bone marrow antibody-secreting cells into LLPC (PopD) and non-LLPC subsets, and assayed them (plus serum) for antigen-specific responses to influenza, tetanus, and SARS-CoV-2 spike. While influenza and tetanus responses were readily found within the LLPC compartment (mean ~7.3 % and ~2.1 % of total IgG ASCs, respectively), SARS-CoV-2–specific ASCs were essentially excluded from LLPCs (mean ~0.14 %) and instead were largely located in non-LLPC cell subsets (PopA/PopB). Only 6/17 individuals had detectable SARS-CoV-2 ASCs in LLPCs, and those were at very low frequencies. The authors argue that this lack of SARS-CoV-2–specific LLPC seeding helps explain why serum antibody titers decline within 3–6 months post-mRNA vaccination, whereas influenza/tetanus antibodies remain more stable. They found that the ratio of non-LLPC : LLPC for SARS-CoV-2 (~29) far exceeded that for influenza (~0.61) or tetanus (~0.44). T

In vaccinated healthcare workers, those who experienced frequent symptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection exhibited similar IFNγ and IL-2 responses upon variant antigen stimulation compared to HCWs with no prior infection, whereas HCWs with asymptomatic infection had significantly higher cytokine responses. Paradoxically, the frequent infection group displayed higher IgG levels to certain variants (e.g. B.1.617 and BA.4/5) and stronger neutralising antibody activity against Omicron sublineages, indicating that their humoral immunity was intact or even enhanced. These findings suggest a dissociation between humoral and cellular immunity in this subgroup: despite robust antibody responses, a blunted T cell cytokine signature (IFNγ / IL-2) might predispose to repeated symptomatic infection.

This study explored why some individuals maintain stable anti–SARS-CoV-2 antibody levels (“sustainers,” n = 14) while others show rapid decline (“decliners,” n = 13) by deeply profiling B and CD4+ T cell subsets ~4–6 weeks after mild COVID-19. Although both groups had broadly similar frequencies of virus-specific B and T cells, the sustainers had a lower frequency of IgG+ memory B cells early after infection and showed a progressive enhancement in neutralization potency of RBD-directed antibodies over ~5 months, a pattern consistent with ongoing germinal center-driven affinity maturation. The decliners, by contrast, had relatively more early memory B cell output but did not improve neutralization capacity over time. CD4+ T cell magnitudes and phenotypes did not differ significantly between groups. Distinct correlation patterns between B, T, and serological metrics in each group suggest different B–T cell interaction dynamics in sustainers versus decliners. Overall, the results imply that durability of SARS-CoV-2 antibody responses may depend on differential germinal center programs, in which some individuals favor sustained plasma cell generation and high-affinity maturation rather than memory B cell output.

The authors of this preprint report that SARS-CoV-2 Spike (S1) protein accumulates in skull marrow, meninges, and brain parenchyma in both a mouse model (via injected fluorescent S1) and in human post‐mortem samples from COVID-19 patients. In mice, exogenous S1 induced changes in the brain proteome and signs of parenchymal cell death. In human brain cortex samples (8 COVID vs 11 controls), proteomic analysis revealed 76 proteins differentially expressed (49 up, 27 down) and enrichment in immune, complement/coagulation, and neutrophil/NETs pathways, implicating local inflammatory/vascular processes.

The risk of death increased with the viral RNA load in plasma. In a prospective cohort of 101 older adults (mean age ~ 80 years) hospitalized in pulmonary intermediate care settings, SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia (≥ 50 copies/ml in plasma) was present in 27.7% of patients. Patients with RNAemia had markedly higher in-hospital mortality (50.0% vs. 13.7%) and 180-day mortality (57.1% vs. 19.7%). After adjustment for age, disease severity, sepsis, lymphocyte and platelet counts, and CRP, RNAemia remained an independent predictor of 180-day death (HR ≈ 2.75). The study also showed that higher plasma viral RNA loads were associated with increased mortality and elevated systemic inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-8, IL-10). The authors propose that RNAemia reflects systemic viral dissemination and greater inflammatory injury, making it a useful biomarker for long-term mortality risk in elderly COVID-19 patients.

This study uses a 3D in vitro skeletal muscle model to test how sera from ME/CFS and long COVID patients impact muscle metabolic and structural behavior. After 48 h of exposure, the muscle constructs show markedly impaired contractile function, upregulation of PDK4 (suggesting a shift toward glycolysis), and downregulation of DRP1 (indicating altered mitochondrial dynamics). The mitochondria appear hyperfused, and mitochondrial respiration assays show increased oxygen consumption and elevated non-mitochondrial respiration. With longer exposure (96 h, 144 h), the models become more fragile, fatigue quickly, and mitochondrial networks become fragmented or adopt toroidal shapes, implying stress or membrane dysfunction.

In a retrospective cohort of 463 Brazilian healthcare workers followed for a median of 18 months after COVID-19 infection, nearly half (49.0 %) experienced post-COVID-19 syndrome, with fatigue (32.5 %), memory complaints (21.5 %), dyspnea (16.0 %), anxiety/depression (15.0 %), and cough (9.4 %) being the most frequent persistent symptoms. Female sex and obesity were independently associated with increased risk of long COVID in this population.

In a cross-sectional survey of 408 adults in southern Italy who had been infected with SARS-CoV-2 (March 2022–January 2023), the vast majority (95.3%) reported poor sleep quality (PSQI ≥ 5). Common issues included poor subjective sleep, daytime dysfunction, and frequent use of sleep medications. Concurrently, extremely severe levels of anxiety, stress, and depression were reported by 86%, 77.2%, and 71.1% of respondents, respectively. Multivariate analysis revealed that worse sleep (higher PSQI) was significantly associated with more severe depression and stress, bereavement from COVID-19 (i.e., having had a close contact die), and being employed. Use of sleep medication was more likely among older or employed individuals, those in earlier pandemic waves, and those who lost someone close. Trouble staying awake socially was more common in women, older participants, and those with severe stress.

This study surveyed 74,075 Chinese residents via an online questionnaire to assess prevalence, symptomatology, and risk factors of long COVID in a high vaccine–coverage, large-population setting. The authors found that a nontrivial proportion reported persistent symptoms (such as fatigue, memory decline, exercise intolerance, cough, sleep disturbance) following SARS-CoV-2 infection. More severe acute infection, female sex, older age, and comorbidities increased the risk of long COVID. Pre-infection vaccination was associated with reduced odds of long COVID, though protection varied by vaccine dose and timing.

Over the course of one year following hospitalization for COVID-19, this study tracked 500 patients and identified distinct trajectories in physical and mental health-related quality of life (HRQoL), fatigue, and dyspnoea. For physical HRQoL, about 16 % maintained a “stable high” level, 40 % showed improvement, while 44 % remained at “stable low.” For mental HRQoL, trajectories included a “stable high” (43 %), “improving” (14 %), “middle declining” (17 %), and “low” (26 %). Fatigue trajectories varied from “no fatigue” (15 %) to “high-severe” (18 %), while dyspnoea largely bifurcated into “almost never” (75 %) versus “severe” (25 %). Predictors such as older age, overweight/obesity, lower education, and existing comorbidities increased the odds of falling into worse physical HRQoL and symptom trajectories. Interestingly, younger age was associated with worse mental HRQoL trajectories.

This retrospective study of 1,767 hospitalized COVID-19 patients (mean follow-up ~181.5 days) used vertebral Hounsfield unit measurements on chest CT scans to infer changes in bone mineral density (BMD). The authors identified three latent BMD decline trajectories (early low-normal decline, average decline, early high-rapid decline), all showing downward trends, and found that trajectory membership was associated with baseline age, sex, and prior vertebral surgery. Patients in the “early high-rapid decline” trajectory had significantly lower odds of mortality (OR = 0.52, 95% CI 0.32–0.83) and hospital stay >10 days (OR = 0.61, 95% CI 0.46–0.81) compared to the “early low-normal decline” group; ICU stay length did not differ by trajectory. The results suggest that COVID-19 patients may suffer vertebral bone loss over months after infection, and that the pattern or speed of this bone loss may carry prognostic information for survival and hospitalization duration.

Insomnia is common in post-COVID patients: in a cohort of 280 individuals evaluated in a COVID-specific clinic, 50 % had clinically significant insomnia at the first visit, and among 78 followed later, 42 % continued to have insomnia. Risk factors for more severe insomnia included younger age, female sex, racial/ethnic minority status, and worse anxiety or depression scores. Importantly, measures of physiological impairment (e.g. cardiopulmonary function) did not show any association with insomnia severity.

In a cohort of 899 predominantly male U.S. Marines (median age ~18), nearly 90 % had documented SARS-CoV-2 infection, and of the 798 infected, 24.7 % (n = 197) reported symptoms lasting at least four weeks (PASC). The most frequent persistent complaints were loss of smell/taste (41.6 %), dyspnea (37.6 %), and cough (22.8 %). Compared to non-PASC participants and to a historic Marine cohort, those with PASC reported higher rates of somatic, depressive, and anxiety symptoms. Functionally, Marines with PASC underperformed on aerobic/fitness tests (notably slower run times, p = 0.002), and this decreased performance endured up to one year post-training.

The study compared 22,087 adult COVID-19 hospitalizations in 2020 (wave 1: 9,668; wave 2: 12,419) with 7,586 pre-pandemic viral pneumonia/respiratory hospitalizations in 2019, linking hospital clinical data with socio-economic records. The authors observed a pronounced social health gradient in both groups—higher hospitalization rates and longer hospital stays among those with lower income, lower socio-economic status, and in high-density areas—but this gradient was steeper in the COVID-19 waves (p-trend < 0.0001). Men, people aged ≥ 45, foreign nationals (except sub-Saharan origin), and those with comorbidities had elevated risk of COVID-19 hospitalization compared to controls, and many of the same factors predicted longer hospital stays (which were longer in COVID-19: median 7 days in wave 1, 6 days in wave 2, vs 3 days in controls).

This prospective cohort study of 180 men (90 smokers vs 90 non-smokers) showed that SARS-CoV-2 infection leads to deterioration of semen parameters (concentration, motility, morphology) and increased sperm DNA fragmentation in both groups. However, smoking men exhibited more severe reductions post-infection and distinct proteomic and metabolomic alterations compared to non-smokers. The molecular signatures included dysregulation in proteins (e.g. HSPA5, HSPA2, PGK2) and metabolites (e.g. acetylcarnitine, oxaloacetate, nicotinate) linked to sperm damage.

The study demonstrates that administration of anti-spike monoclonal antibodies (e.g. casirivimab + imdevimab) at the time of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination can specifically reduce the vaccine-induced pseudovirus neutralizing antibody titers, while not broadly suppressing other spike-specific immune responses (such as binding antibodies, B cell memory, and T cell responses). This effect is explained by epitope masking: high-affinity mAbs bind key spike epitopes and block B cell receptor access, thereby redirecting the endogenous B cell response away from those epitopes. Encouragingly, this reduction in neutralization capacity can be reversed with booster immunization. In human infection settings, the authors show that in individuals treated with mAbs during SARS-CoV-2 infection, alteration of the endogenous humoral response is observed predominantly in those who had not yet initiated their natural immune response when the mAbs were given. Together, these observations suggest that therapeutic or prophylactic anti-spike monoclonal antibodies can interfere with the host’s own antibody maturation when given early, but that this interference is not absolute and can be at least partially overcome by additional vaccination.

In ACTIV-2/A5401, non-hospitalized adults with COVID-19 randomized to amubarvimab/romlusevimab versus placebo underwent PCR testing on days 3, 7, 14, and 28. Viral rebound (~≥3 log10 copies/mL with ≥0.5 log10 rise) occurred in ~5% per arm among 713 analyzed, showing no treatment effect. Among 574 participants who initially improved symptomatically, symptom rebound risk was similar (HR 0.95; 95% CI 0.52–1.75), and <1% had both viral and symptom rebound. The authors infer that this monoclonal antibody regimen did not elevate rebound risk, in contrast to signals reported for some short-acting antivirals.

🧫This study demonstrates for the first time that human iPSC-derived motor neurons (iPSC-MNs) are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection. The authors show that iPSC-MNs express canonical viral entry factors (ACE2, CD147, NRP1, TMPRSS2, FURIN), with CD147 and NRP1 being relatively abundant. Infection with SARS-CoV-2 at MOI = 1 results in low but increasing viral replication over 72 hours, release of infectious particles (TCID₅₀ rising from ~9.5 to ~85.4), and detection of intracellular viral RNAs and nucleocapsid protein in a small fraction of cells. Importantly, infection alters neuronal gene expression: 10 genes implicated in apoptosis, inflammation, metabolism, and antigen presentation were significantly dysregulated (e.g. upregulation of IL-6, BAX/BCL2, CD147, S1PR1 and downregulation of HLA-A, ERAP1, ANG). These changes hint at possible mechanisms of neuronal stress, immune evasion, or dysfunction.

The study identifies Neuropilin-1 (NRP1) as a host factor that enhances SARS-CoV-2 entry and infectivity. Blocking NRP1 with an antibody reduces infection in cell systems, and a spike mutant lacking a functional furin-cleavage site loses this NRP1 dependence. NRP1-positive cells in the human olfactory epithelium from COVID-19 autopsies contained viral material, suggesting a plausible nasal route aligned with anosmia. Overall, NRP1 is proposed as an entry cofactor and a candidate therapeutic target, though the evidence is primarily in vitro and histological; it does not establish the quantitative in-vivo contribution or clinical benefit of NRP1 blockade across variants.

The study examined 71 organ samples from 15 autopsies (non-immunocompromised) and found widespread extra-pulmonary SARS-CoV-2 RNA—including lung, intestine, heart, kidney, and liver—in most organs of most cases. Sequencing revealed compartmentalized intra-host diversity, with ≤10 intra-host single-nucleotide variants (iSNVs) per lung sample but ~11–45 iSNVs per case when considering multiple organs, consistent with organ-specific evolution and seeding.

🐹Golden hamsters intranasally infected with SARS-CoV-2 (Wuhan, Delta, Omicron/BA.1) were followed for 80 days. Viral genomic RNA appeared in the brainstem within 4 hours and persisted to 80 dpi; notably, infectious virus could still be isolated from brainstem at 80 dpi despite very low titers (<10² TCID₅₀/mL) in 75% (Wuhan), 87.5% (Delta), and 75% (Omicron/BA.1) of animals. Behaviorally, infected hamsters developed persistent depression-like features, impaired recognition memory, and late-onset anxiety-like signs across three test sessions up to day 80, relative to mock controls. Bulk RNA-seq of brainstem revealed thousands of DEGs at 4 dpi and hundreds at 80 dpi, with enrichment for neurodegeneration (e.g., Parkinson’s pathways), dopaminergic and glutamatergic synapses, proteostasis, and mitochondrial energy metabolism. Early interferon responses and glial changes were evident.

In 279 unvaccinated COVID-19 patients followed to ~50 days after symptom onset, overall T-cell counts normalized in ~90–98% of moderate–severe cases. However, persistent B-cell lymphopenia (<90 cells/µL) remained in 7.3% of moderate and 12.5% of severe cases, and this subgroup also exhibited lower total T cells, CD4⁺ T cells, and Tregs, with a reduced CD4/CD8 ratio in the moderate group. CD8⁺, NK, and DN T-cell counts were largely comparable at follow-up; CD4⁺–Treg correlations seen in moderate disease disappeared in severe cases, implying severity-dependent regulatory imbalance. The cohort was unvaccinated and early-pandemic (Jan–Mar 2020, single region).

This medRxiv preprint analyzes SARS-CoV-2 spread and long-COVID burden in California state prisons up to March 25, 2022. Among 196,652 residents, 66,684 were infected across two major winter waves hitting all 35 prisons. Using detailed nightly room assignments and testing records, the authors reconstructed likely transmission links and estimated effective R values typically between 0 and 5. Contrary to earlier expectations, they find substantial transmission in both dorms and cells, irrespective of door type or season. They estimate 9,100–11,000 (15%) cases of long COVID, including 1,700–2,000 with disabling consequences, with a disproportionate burden on Black and Indigenous residents due to incarceration disparities.

This multicenter EHR cohort (Massachusetts; 2020) followed 7,772 infants to age 12 months, including 222 with in-utero SARS-CoV-2 exposure. Neurodevelopmental diagnoses occurred in 6.3% of exposed vs 3.0% of unexposed infants (crude OR 2.17; aOR 1.86; 95% CI, 1.03–3.36). Diagnoses tended to appear earlier among exposed infants (median 214 vs 275 days). The signal was stronger when maternal infection occurred in the third trimester (aOR 2.34; 95% CI, 1.23–4.44).

The study compared 134,565 adults with confirmed COVID-19 to 35,987 adults with pneumonia (prepandemic) and found that COVID-19 was associated with a substantially greater acceleration in decline of estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR). After adjustment, COVID-19 patients lost eGFR ~3.4% faster per year (or ~4.1 mL/min/1.73 m² extra decline), with hospitalized cases experiencing ~5.0 mL/min/1.73 m² extra loss, versus pneumonia patients who had ~0.9 mL/min/1.73 m² extra decline. The hazard for ≥25% eGFR decline was 1.19-fold higher in COVID vs pneumonia (rising to 1.42 in hospitalized).

This study analyzed whole-genome sequencing data from 6,321 Japanese individuals across autoimmune disease, COVID-19, and healthy control groups to quantify blood DNA virome signatures, focusing on endogenous HHV-6 (eHHV-6) and anellovirus. The authors report that eHHV-6B carriage (~0.35%) is associated with increased risk of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP), and among SLE patients, eHHV-6B positivity correlates with markedly higher disease activity (average SLEDAI 30.5 vs 6.0, P = 1.3×10⁻⁸). Integration mapping places HHV-6B into a locus on chromosome 22q, and immune profiling suggests distinct immune activation patterns in eHHV-6B positive patients. Meanwhile, high anellovirus load is strongly associated with SLE, rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and COVID-19; for example, in SLE the adjusted odds of anellovirus infection is ~58.5 (95% CI 15.6–293). Association signals also extend to certain clinical features (e.g. complement levels, immunosuppressant use).

This nonhuman-primate study shows that two doses of an adjuvanted SARS-CoV-2 spike protein vaccine establish bone-marrow long-lived plasma cells (LLPCs) detectable for several months. Using a new “antibody-tethering” assay to isolate rare LLPCs, the authors found these cells were RBD-enriched, clonally related to memory B cells observed ~2 weeks post-boost, and carried additional somatic hypermutation. Antibodies secreted by these LLPCs displayed improved neutralization and broader cross-reactivity versus earlier time points.

In a longitudinal cohort of adults aged 50+ in the UK Biobank followed for a median of ~24 months, individuals with prior COVID-19 infection had a 41% higher hazard of new-onset all-cause dementia and a 77% higher hazard of vascular dementia (VaD) compared to matched non-infected controls, whereas no significant association was found for Alzheimer’s disease. Subgroup and sensitivity analyses largely confirmed these associations, and risks were especially pronounced among older, unvaccinated, or comorbidity-bearing participants.

This cross-sectional web-based study surveyed 783 healthcare workers (HCWs) at Hamad Medical Corporation (Qatar) between Jan 24 – Apr 24 2022 to estimate the prevalence and risk factors of Long COVID. About 75 % of participants reported at least one persistent symptom after infection, and 36 % reported more than 3 symptoms. Fatigue was the most common, followed by sleep disorders, headache, joint pain, anxiety, low mood, and “brain fog.” Among respondents, 60 % had previously tested positive for SARS-CoV-2; 71 % of those with > 3 symptoms were female. A significant association existed between Long COVID symptom burden and both prior psychiatric history (adjusted OR 0.25 [95 % CI 0.08–0.78] for those without history) and current depression scores (PHQ-9 p < 0.001). Participants who had been infected with SARS-CoV-2 were more likely to report multiple long-term symptoms (adjusted OR 2.46 [95 % CI 1.21–5.00]).

Children who experience a high burden of common infections in the first three years of life are more likely to suffer moderate to severe infections and require systemic antibiotic treatment later in childhood (ages 3 to 10 or 13). In this Danish birth cohort, those in the high-infection group (≥16 diary-registered events) had a 2.39-fold increased incidence of later serious infections and a 1.34-fold higher incidence of antibiotic prescriptions, compared to children with lower early infection burdens. Each additional early-life infection was also associated with a small but measurable rise in later risk (AIRR ~1.05 for infections, ~1.02 for antibiotic use). Subtype analyses revealed that early colds, otitis media, pneumonia, fever, and gastroenteritis were individually linked to later increased risk, while tonsillitis was not consistently so. In a smaller subgroup with viral testing, higher burdens of enterovirus (and marginally rhinovirus) but not RSV were associated with elevated later pneumonia or broader infection risk.

This systematic review and meta-analysis pooled 44 studies with 8,114 participants to test whether Long COVID is associated with a more atherogenic lipid profile. Across multiple indices, LC showed significantly higher atherogenicity: CRI1 0.199 and CRI2 0.202; TG/HDL 0.294; composite (TG+LDL+VLDL)/(HDL+ApoA) 0.264; and ApoB/ApoA 0.515. Individual lipids shifted in the same direction (↑LDL, ↑total cholesterol, ↑TG, ↑ApoB; ↓HDL, ↓ApoA). The pattern supports the notion that LC may carry elevated cardiovascular risk signals, though the evidence base is heterogeneous and largely cross-sectional.

This retrospective cohort study of 2,511 essential workers in New York found that 18.9 % of participants developed post-acute sequelae (PASC), and 16.1 % had experienced multiple COVID-19 infections. After adjusting for confounders, reinfection was significantly associated with higher PASC risk (RR 1.41), and the risks were substantially higher for those who had experienced severe acute illness (RR 3.17) or who were unvaccinated before their first infection (RR 3.29).

In a case–control study of 169 children (129 LCS; 32 convalescent; 8 uninfected), Kovács et al. found that long COVID in children is associated with poorer quality of life and functioning and a distinct neutrophil dysfunction signature. The most frequent LCS symptom was fatigue, and LCS participants reported significantly worse QoL-F than convalescent controls (t(119)=7.456, p < 0.001). In a mechanistic subset (29 LCS; 17 controls), neutrophils from LCS children exhibited lower superoxide production (including a p < 0.0001 time×disease interaction) and reduced phagocytosis. Symptom counts correlated with neutrophil effector dysfunction, suggesting innate immune impairment may contribute to pediatric LCS pathology or vulnerability.

In a retrospective cohort of 2,511 essential workers in New York, the researchers found that 475 (18.9%) developed long COVID (PASC) following SARS-CoV-2 infection. Among them, 403 (16.1%) had experienced reinfection. After adjustment for demographics, comorbidities, and other covariates, reinfection was associated with a 41% increased risk of PASC (RR = 1.41, 95% CI 1.14–1.74). Notably, severe initial COVID-19 (RR = 3.17, 95% CI 2.41–4.16) and lack of vaccination at first infection (RR = 3.29, 95% CI 2.46–4.41) were also strong predictors of PASC.

The study followed 1,300 patients (200 hospitalized, 1,100 nonhospitalized) with persistent neurologic symptoms after COVID-19 to see if vaccination before infection was associated with milder neurologic long COVID outcomes. They found that regardless of prior vaccination status, the prevalence, severity, and cognitive testing deficits of neurologic symptoms (e.g. brain fog, headache, anosmia, dizziness) were largely similar between those with pre-vaccination infection and those with breakthrough infection. Some minor differences (e.g. rates of anosmia or dizziness) may reflect differing SARS-CoV-2 strains rather than vaccine effect. The authors interpret these results to indicate that, among individuals who develop Neuro-PASC, prior vaccination does not substantially modify its neurologic phenotype, although breakthrough cases often had more comorbidities.

This case–control study (129 PCC; 36 controls) shows that the choroid plexus is enlarged more than a year after SARS-CoV-2 infection and that larger ChP volume tracks with worse cognitive performance and widespread brain changes—reduced gray-matter in frontal/subcortical regions, white-matter microstructural alterations (lower FA/higher AD), and specific functional connectivity increases. Quantitatively, group differences were robust (e.g., ChP volume F=20.072; p<0.001), and cognitive correlations included Digit Span Backwards (r=−0.233; p=0.009). On the immune side, larger ChP volume associated with myeloid alterations (lower CD11b+, higher CX3CR1; fewer CD14+CD16+ monocytes and CCR2). A moderation analysis indicates the ChP influences how gray-matter loss relates to cognition, with effects emerging above ~759 mm³.

This Scientific Reports study shows that expressing SARS-CoV-2 spike in human endothelial cells causes the formation of syncytia—~10–13% of cells after 72 h, averaging ~6 nuclei each—and disrupts VE-cadherin adhesions, leaving gaps that could impair vascular barrier integrity. Inhibiting MLCK (ML-7) significantly reduced syncytia incidence and size, whereas ROCK inhibition did not. Biomechanical context mattered: stiffer matrices increased syncytia, arterial-level shear stress (12 dyn/cm²) suppressed it, and cyclic stretch was neutral. Endothelial cells were permissive to SARS-CoV-2 infection and replication (MOI 0.1), with syncytia visible for an early isolate and productive replication for Omicron.

Ruf’s commentary reviews and integrates evidence suggesting that persistent activation of the complement and coagulation systems may play a central role in driving Long COVID through sustained endothelial injury, microvascular dysfunction, and chronic inflammation. He notes that Long COVID patients often show elevated complement markers long after acute SARS-CoV-2 infection, and he proposes that cross talk between complement, coagulation, and vascular damage may perpetuate symptoms. Based on that, targeting complement or coagulation pathways is posited as a promising therapeutic strategy, though robust mechanistic and clinical trials remain lacking.

🐁In a transgenic mouse model (K18-hACE2), intratracheal instillation of inactivated SARS-CoV-2 induced acute skeletal muscle injury characterized by reduced muscle strength and histopathological changes (leukocyte infiltrates, vacuoles, centralized nuclei) in gastrocnemius and diaphragm muscles. Apoptotic signaling (elevated caspase‐3) and inflammatory mediators (HMGB1, TNF-α, phospho-NF-κB, caspase-11, pannexin-1) were significantly increased, while pyroptosis markers (caspase-1, IL-1β, gasdermin D) were unchanged. Pre-treatment with the P2X receptor inhibitor Brilliant Blue G ameliorated the muscle damage and dampened molecular inflammation, implicating purinergic signaling in the pathogenic process. This work suggests that SARS-CoV-2, even in a non-replicative form, can trigger acute myopathic effects via inflammatory and apoptotic pathways, and that targeting purinergic signaling may protect muscle from viral-induced injury.

In Qatar’s national datasets, a prior pre-Omicron infection cut the risk of reinfection by ~81% and this barely waned over time; protection against severe disease on reinfection was ~98%. By contrast, during the Omicron era, protection from a recent Omicron infection began high (~81% at 3–<6 months) but fell to ~28% by 9–<12 months and to ~5% beyond a year, while protection against severe outcomes on reinfection remained ~100%. These results indicate rapid immune escape with Omicron: natural infection gives short-lived protection against getting infected again but continues to strongly prevent severe disease on reinfection.

In a retrospective analysis of 769 hospitalized U.S. patients with both myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and COVID-19, the authors identified 151 in-hospital deaths and explored predictors of mortality. Compared with non–COVID MDS patients, the MDS+COVID cohort was older (77.3 vs 53.5 years), had longer hospital stays (7.9 vs 5.1 days), and higher hospital charges (~USD 85,060 vs ~66,888). HSCT history was not linked to increased risk. Male sex was associated with a higher unadjusted mortality (64.9% vs 53.9%), but its adjusted odds ratio (1.51) was only of borderline significance (p = 0.076). Key complications distinguishing nonsurvivors included stroke (2.0% vs 0.3%, aOR 4.7), severe sepsis (17.9% vs 0.6%, aOR 9.1), acute respiratory failure (66.9% vs 49.5%, aOR 3.93), and acute kidney injury (45.7% vs 29.1%). Vasopressor use was far more frequent among nonsurvivors (9.3% vs 0.2%), though its adjusted association did not reach significance.

This study of 94 undergraduate students (mean age ~20.6 y, ~89 % female) investigated whether past COVID-19 infection is associated with lingering cognitive impairment and altered brain hemodynamics. About 40 % of participants recalled “brain fog,” and 37 % of those with prior infection exhibited objective impairments on cognitive testing (especially in executive function). However, at the group level, performance differences were modest, possibly because some individuals compensate better than others. Importantly, NIRS measurements over the prefrontal cortex revealed distinct task-evoked hemodynamic patterns in the previously infected group, patterns akin to those seen in much older adults. Participants reporting brain fog showed more aberrant oxygenated hemoglobin responses during tasks.

This study of 20 unvaccinated individuals with prior SARS-CoV-2 infection found that bone marrow aspirations revealed a striking deficiency of spike-specific long-lived plasma cells (LLPCs), despite detectable circulating anti-spike IgG in these individuals. In contrast, plasma cells specific to tetanus toxoid were readily detected and correlated strongly with serum tetanus IgG levels (model explaining ~98% of variance). The disconnect between LLPC presence and circulating anti-spike antibodies suggests that durable, bone marrow–resident humoral memory to SARS-CoV-2 spike is weak or poorly generated by natural infection.

People with vasculitis receiving the B cell–depleting treatment rituximab show profound deficits in developing neutralizing antibody responses to SARS-CoV-2 vaccines, especially against Omicron subvariants. After the first two vaccine doses, neutralization was largely absent even when binding IgG was detected; subsequent booster doses (third and fourth) improved neutralization in many cases, but responses against XBB remained weak. The closer the vaccination was to the last rituximab treatment (within 18 months), the more severely blunted the neutralization. Interestingly, non-neutralizing effector functions (measured via antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity) were more frequently detectable than neutralization in rituximab-treated individuals, suggesting that binding antibodies with nonneutralizing capacities may survive B cell depletion better than neutralizing ones.

This population-based study of 237,356 U.S. cancer patients who died in 2020 found that 5.3% of those deaths were attributed to COVID-19, making it a leading cause of death behind cancer and cardiovascular disease. Haematologic cancers (especially chronic lymphocytic leukaemia) had the highest risk of COVID-19 mortality, with an HR of 2.37 compared to prostate cancer, whereas lung cancer had a lower risk (HR 0.61). Other solid tumours such as colon, bladder, kidney, and breast cancers had modestly elevated risk (HRs ~1.10–1.22). Time since cancer diagnosis was a strong independent predictor: survivors >15 years from diagnosis had a >2-fold higher risk compared to those 1–5 years out, and older age and male sex were also risk factors.

This Yale LISTEN preprint compares 42 individuals with post-vaccination syndrome (PVS) to 22 vaccinated controls. PVS participants showed lower memory/effector CD4⁺ T cells, higher TNF-α⁺ CD8 T cells, lower anti-spike antibodies (largely due to fewer vaccine doses, especially among those never infected), more frequent EBV reactivation, and detectable circulating spike in a subset—sometimes >700 days post-vaccination. Together, the data point to immune dysregulation with possible contributions from antigen persistence and latent virus reactivation.

Paternal SARS-CoV-2 infection in mice (intranasal P21 strain, 10^4 TCID50) led to durable changes in sperm small noncoding RNAs—four Clu-aligned piRNA clusters were downregulated (FDR<0.05), while miR-3471 and pro-TGG-3-1 were upregulated. When these sires bred four weeks post-infection, F1 offspring showed higher anxiety-like behavior (e.g., anxiety z-score F(1,71)=9.166, P=0.003; males had longer latency to enter light, P=0.022) and hippocampal transcriptomic alterations, without changes in locomotion, memory, or sucrose preference. Microinjecting sperm sncRNA from infected sires into naïve zygotes partially phenocopied the anxiety-like phenotype, supporting a functional role for paternal sperm RNAs. Grand-offspring (F2) showed limited effects (no body-weight trajectory differences; small, sex-dependent depression-score interaction).

In a Belgian real-world cohort of 106 Long COVID patients followed for 220 person-years, second-line Paxlovid (15 days) was the single best predictor of clinical recovery: patient-reported OR 6.18 (1.35–34.13) and “strict/broad” improvement OR 4.57 (1.19–20.74), while anticoagulants did not predict improvement. Predictive models performed well (e.g., AUC 0.90 for concordant patient+clinician improvement). In a biomarker subset, antivirals were associated with rapid 15-day decreases in GFAP (p=0.012; n=9) and NFL (p=0.0078; n=9), whereas anticoagulants left GFAP/UCHL1 unchanged and increased NFL (p=0.017; n=12).

Over a roughly three-year follow-up of 3,663 individuals with SARS-CoV-2, the study found that those with ongoing Long COVID (27.1 % of the sample) had markedly worse physical and mental health outcomes compared to those who never developed Long COVID, with deficits in PROMIS scores, and higher odds of stress, fatigue, loneliness, and dyspnea. Very few (1.8 %) reported full resolution of Long COVID, and even among those, modest lingering impairments remained relative to never-affected individuals. Greater vaccination (i.e. more doses) was associated with better outcomes across multiple measures. The authors did not find a strong effect of illness duration on severity once Long COVID was present.

This retrospective case–control study compared 32 glioblastoma patients who became COVID-19 positive during their disease course with 64 matched GBM patients without COVID-19. The authors observed that the COVID-positive group had more frequent and aggressive progression: 84 % progressed (vs 72 % in controls), and hyperprogression occurred in 48 % vs 9 % of controls. The median time to progression was dramatically shorter (35 days vs 164 days), and median survival from the date of COVID diagnosis was 8.3 months vs 17 months in controls. However, overall survival from initial GBM diagnosis did not differ significantly (20.7 vs 24.6 months).

In a cross-sectional study of 63 children/adolescents (Germany, 2021), free-breathing low-field (0.55 T) functional MRI showed reduced ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) match after COVID-19 compared with 9 healthy controls. V/Q-matched lung parenchyma averaged 81% in controls vs 62% in recovered and 60% in long-COVID participants; only 1 participant showed a morphologic MRI abnormality. The deficit persisted regardless of time since infection—remaining abnormal <180 days and 180–360 days, and appearing even lower >360 days post-infection.

In this prospective, cross-sectional study of 27 children/adolescents with post-COVID-19 condition (PCC) and 27 matched healthy controls, the authors used free-breathing phase-resolved functional lung MRI (PREFUL MRI) to detect subtle lung functional abnormalities otherwise not evident. They found that PCC participants had significantly lower pulmonary perfusion (median 49 vs 78 mL/min per 100 mL; P < .001) and slightly lower regional ventilation (P = .047). In symptomatic PCC patients, metrics such as flow-volume loop correlation (FVL-CM) were reduced, and ventilation and perfusion defect percentages were higher than in controls. Moreover, in the PCC group, greater lung perfusion correlated with worse fatigue (ρ = 0.48, P = .009) and higher ventilation–perfusion mismatch correlated with higher heart rate (ρ = 0.44, P = .02). These findings support a distinct “lung perfusion phenotype” in pediatric long COVID, potentially contributing to symptoms.

This study of 175 individuals previously infected with COVID-19 explored associations between IL-6 signalling (including IL-6, sIL-6R, sgp130) and the IL-6R gene variant rs2228145 with self-reported long-COVID symptoms. They found that more severe/multiple infections and hypertension increased long-COVID odds, while vaccination was protective. Overall, IL-6 signalling was elevated in long-COVID sufferers, though across the full cohort the rs2228145 genotype was not significantly associated with long-COVID risk. Importantly, the authors observed seasonal effects: in the summer subgroup (but not in winter), the AA genotype of rs2228145 was overrepresented among those with long-COVID, and AC/CC genotypes had lower odds compared to AA.

In 11 COVID-19 autopsies (plus 2 additional brains) vs 23 controls, the authors map a consistent pattern of microglial dysfunction concentrated in medullary autonomic nuclei: loss of P2Y12R, impaired CX3CR1–CX3CL1 signaling, mitochondrial injury, and excessive phagocytosis of synapses/myelin. Microglial P2Y12R loss scaled with regional viral RNA (e.g., medulla r = −0.87), and snRNA-seq of 16,260 nuclei identified nine cell populations reflecting inflammatory state shifts. The picture is one of “gliovascular failure” at sites of vascular inflammation and Blood Brain Barrier (BBB) injury, with glutamatergic terminal loss. Inflammation in brain and CSF was dominated by IL-1/IL-6 signatures tightly coupled to systemic inflammation (e.g., spleen IL-6 vs medullary IL-6 r = 0.93; lung IL-1β vs CSF IL-1β r = 0.87). PRR and inflammasome-related transcripts (AIM2, TLR3/7/9, RIG-I, MDA5, NLRC5) associated with these changes, linking virus-sensing to microglial dysfunction.

Using registry and biobank data from Finland (FinnGen) and the UK (UK Biobank), the authors report that 45 different viral exposures are significantly linked to increased risk of neurodegenerative diseases, and 22 of those associations were replicated across cohorts. The strongest association was between viral encephalitis and Alzheimer’s disease, while influenza with pneumonia was associated with 5 of the 6 neurodegenerative disorders they studied. Some associations persisted even when the viral exposure preceded the neurodegenerative diagnosis by up to 15 years, suggesting long latency between infection and disease onset.

In a population-based Catalonia cohort of 2,764 SARS-CoV-2–infected adults, about 23% developed long COVID, and among those identified in 2021, 56% still had symptoms two years later. Vaccination before SARS-CoV-2 infection was associated with a relative risk (RR) of 0.33 (95% CI 0.29–0.38) for developing long COVID. Using latent class analysis, the authors categorized long COVID into three subtypes (mild neuromuscular, mild respiratory, severe multi-organ), with the severe subtype more likely to persist. Risk of long COVID was higher for women, younger participants (<50 years), low socioeconomic status, severe acute disease, obesity, elevated pre-vaccination IgG, and preexisting chronic or mental health conditions. Protective factors included prior vaccination (before infection), infection during the Omicron-dominant era, higher physical activity, 6–8 hours of sleep, and vaccination within 3 months post-infection.

🐁This study reveals that in the context of SARS-CoV-2 infection, excessive interferon signaling can remodel and degrade peroxisomes in lung macrophages, impairing their capacity to resolve inflammation and drive alveolar repair. Without functional peroxisomes, macrophages overactivate the inflammasome and produce excess IL-1β, triggering accumulation of dysplastic epithelial progenitors (KRT8^high) and promoting lung fibrosis. In mouse models, pharmacological enhancement of peroxisome biogenesis ameliorated both acute lung injury and post-acute sequelae (PASC), supporting a causal role for macrophage peroxisome dysfunction in chronic lung pathology after SARS-CoV-2 infection.

This pilot study tested whether dogs trained to detect acute COVID-19 infection via odor (volatile organic compounds) can also distinguish samples from individuals suffering from Long COVID. In comparisons of Long COVID vs healthy controls, dogs achieved a sensitivity of about 94.4 % and specificity of about 96.1 %. When acute COVID-19 and Long COVID samples were pitted directly against each other, dogs more often indicated the acute COVID-19 samples (sensitivity ~86.7 %, specificity ~95.8 %) rather than the Long COVID samples, suggesting that the odor signature in Long COVID might be weaker but still present.

Swank et al. measured circulating SARS-CoV-2 antigens (spike S1, full spike, nucleocapsid) in plasma or serum from adults sampled between days and 14 months after SARS-CoV-2 infection in four cohorts. They observed that antigenemia persists in a nontrivial fraction of individuals: ~20% of asymptomatic participants and ~50% of those reporting long COVID–type symptoms still had detectable antigen at various time points. The findings support the possibility that residual viral antigen (or viral persistence) may underlie at least some aspects of postacute sequelae. However, antigen detection decreased over time, and many with long COVID symptoms were antigen-negative, indicating that persistent antigenemia cannot explain all cases of PASC.

This study examined whether the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein subunit S1 persists within monocyte populations long after acute COVID-19, particularly in individuals with Long COVID / PASC. Among their cohort, the authors found that non-classical monocytes (CD14^lo CD16^+) in 73% (19/26) of PASC patients and 91% (10/11) of severe COVID-19 patients contained measurable S1 protein (versus essentially none in classical or intermediate monocytes). Using immunoprecipitation combined with mass spectrometry, they confirmed peptide matches to the S1 antigen, retrieving up to 44% of S1 peptides in some cases.

In a cohort of 29 individuals with persistent symptoms at least four weeks after acute COVID-19, Tejerina et al. found that 45 % had detectable SARS-CoV-2 RNA in plasma and 51 % had at least one positive RT-PCR in plasma, stool, or urine. Nearly half (48 %) exhibited severely reduced functional status. Of the group, 62 % received compassionate-use antiviral therapy, and those treated showed statistically significantly better functional outcomes compared to untreated patients (p = 0.01), while overall improvement over time was also significant (p = 0.000).

This retrospective cohort study leveraged smart thermometer data from 862,577 individuals in 320,073 households over 3 years to infer intrahousehold viral transmission events via the onset and timing of fevers. Among 54,506 febrile episodes judged to involve within-household spread, in 38,787 events involving both children and adults, a median of 70.4 % had a pediatric (child) as the inferred index case. The fraction of pediatric-origin transmission dropped during school breaks (e.g. winter break 68.4 % → 41.7 %) and varied over time, supporting that children served as important vectors when schools were in session.

In a patient who had cleared SARS-CoV-2 in the nasopharynx (swab negative) but later developed ileal ulceration, the authors detected SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein in the ulcerated intestinal tissue and demonstrated increased VEGF expression (co-localized with Spike) and elevated fibronectin compared to control ileum. Electron microscopy further revealed disruptions in epithelial intercellular junctions in the ulcerated area, with widened intercellular spaces and irregular junctional structures.

The authors conducted a longitudinal surveillance of pet dogs in Ibadan, Nigeria, over three years (2022–2024), employing immunochromatography and RT-qPCR on blood, nasal, and rectal samples. They observed IC positivity of 11.7% in 2022 (23/197), 85.7% in 2023 (6/7), and 100% in 2024 (3/3), and RT-qPCR positivity of 37.9% (11/29), 33.3% (2/6), and 100% (3/3) in those same years, respectively. Among the tested animals, three dogs repeatedly tested positive over multiple years, consistent with possible continuous viral shedding. The authors interpret this as evidence suggestive of endemic SARS-CoV-2 in that pet dog population, with implications for One Health strategies and zoonotic risk mitigation.

Over a follow-up period (e.g. 5 years), the study found that patients undergoing standard laser (e.g. panretinal photocoagulation) exhibited substantial losses in visual field sensitivity early, whereas those treated with an anti-VEGF agent (e.g. ranibizumab) had less immediate loss but still accumulated decline after 2 years. Quantitatively, the cumulative mean change in visual field total point score was, for instance, –527 dB in the laser group vs –330 dB in the anti-VEGF group at 5 years (adjusted difference ~208 dB). The anti-VEGF group also had lower incidence of vision-impairing macular edema (22 % vs 38 %) and fewer eyes requiring additional interventions over time.

In blood from people 10–16 months after mild COVID-19, the team quantified leukocyte mRNA of 11 biomarkers tied to long-COVID VCD and profiled CCL11 promoter CpG methylation. They then added 1 nM vitamin B12 to the cultures for 24 h. Persistent-VCD participants (4/7 at follow-up) showed higher CCL11 and LIF mRNA. B12 normalized CCL11, boosted HGF, and lowered CSF2/CXCL10; methylation at key CCL11 CpGs increased with B12 and correlated inversely with CCL11 expression—consistent with an epigenetic mechanism.

This paper demonstrates an “inverse vaccine” strategy: antigens are synthetically glycosylated with pGal and linked via a self-immolative tether so that, after hepatic uptake, the antigen is presented in a tolerogenic environment. In mice, a single platform suppressed established effector and memory T-cell responses, mechanistically engaging PD-1 and CD276 pathways, and reduced disease in both chronic and relapsing–remitting EAE models of multiple sclerosis. In non-human primates, administering pGal–antigen after a DNA SIV vaccine dampened the antigen-specific T-cell response across several weeks, indicating the approach can recalibrate memory responses without blanket immunosuppression.

🐒Researchers built a spike-targeting immunoPET probe, [⁸⁹Zr]COVA1-27-DFO (affinity 0.7 nM; 86 ± 4% labeling; >99% purity), to image SARS-CoV-2 in non-human primates. In convalescent animals 3 months after infection (n=2), PET revealed ongoing lung signal co-localizing with CT ground-glass changes and detectable brain signal, suggesting antigen persistence. In an acute infection study (exposed + tracer n=4, exposed + IgG control n=2, mock + tracer n=2), tracer uptake highlighted nasal cavity, trachea, lungs, and kidneys, with tracheal PET tracking RT-qPCR positivity at 2–3 dpe and diminishing thereafter. PET-guided necropsy confirmed that PET signal correlated with viral RNA in lung tissue (R = 0.68, p = 0.0001), and kidney PET localized to tubules.

This study of 465,717 children and adolescents (<21 years, mean age ~8.2 years, 52 % male) from U.S. pediatric EHRs found that among 58,417 individuals who had a second SARS-CoV-2 infection (reinfection, ≥ 60 days after the first) during the Omicron era, the risk of being diagnosed with PASC (long COVID) was more than doubled compared to the first infection (RR 2.08; 95% CI 1.68–2.59). Reinfection was also linked to significantly increased risks of many specific conditions, including myocarditis (RR 3.60), taste or smell disturbances (RR 2.83), thromboembolism (RR 2.28), heart disease, kidney injury, abnormal liver enzymes, fatigue/malaise, cognitive dysfunction, POTS/dysautonomia, respiratory symptoms, and musculoskeletal pain, among others.

This large retrospective cohort study of U.S. veterans (231,899 COVID-positive vs 605,014 test-negative persons) found that surviving a COVID-19 infection was associated with modest but consistent increases in rates of subsequent bacterial, viral, and fungal infections over the next year. For example, nonhospitalized COVID-positive individuals had a 1.17-fold higher risk of outpatient infectious illness diagnoses (95% CI 1.15–1.19), a 1.46-fold higher risk of outpatient respiratory infections, and a 1.41-fold higher risk of hospital admission for infectious illnesses compared to test-negative controls. The risk elevations tended to be stronger in those with more severe initial disease, and were also greater compared to persons hospitalized for seasonal influenza (e.g. RR 1.24 for infectious hospitalizations).

In a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase-2 trial (PAX-LC) of 100 adults with long COVID, participants received nirmatrelvir–ritonavir or placebo–ritonavir twice daily for 15 days. The primary outcome—change in PROMIS-29 PHSS from baseline to day 28—showed no significant difference: adjusted mean difference −0.55 points (95% CI −2.32 to 1.21; p=0.54). Safety was acceptable with no deaths or serious AEs; drug-related AEs were more frequent with nirmatrelvir–ritonavir (76%) than placebo (55%), mostly dysgeusia. The authors conclude a 15-day course did not improve health status at 4 weeks, while highlighting the practicality of decentralized long-COVID trials.

In a single-center cohort during China’s Dec 2022–Jan 2023 Omicron surge, investigators analyzed semen from 604 men cross-sectionally and 140 men longitudinally (with 149 COVID-negative controls). Across both designs, COVID-19 was consistently associated with worse semen quality: lower total sperm count (e.g., 173.63×10^6 → 131.80×10^6 post-infection), reduced motility (grade-A 8.50% → 2.61%; progressive 24.88% → 19.82%; total 32.25% → 26.64%), and higher DNA fragmentation (26.49% → 32.10%). Morphology and chromatin immaturity were unchanged. Within-person comparisons showed deterioration in 58–75% of COVID-positive men (vs <40% in negatives), strengthening the association.

Nelson et al. (2025) systematically reviewed 16 structural MRI studies comparing brain volumes in individuals ≥ 6 weeks post-COVID-19 to non-COVID controls. Most studies reported reduced grey matter volumes in COVID-19 patients, though three showed increases; importantly, studies of more severe (hospitalised/ICU) COVID-19 more often found volume loss than studies of milder cases.

In a cohort of 12 children with acute non-A–E hepatitis, Röttele et al. performed spatial single-cell and multiplexed imaging analyses on liver biopsies and found robust immune infiltration dominated by CD8⁺ T cells, which correlated with disease severity. They observed microanatomic interactions linking CX3CR1⁺ endothelial cells, myeloid cells, and effector CD8⁺ T cells, consistent with a potential local pathogenic triad. Remarkably, they also detected SARS-CoV-2 antigens in ACE2-expressing hepatic cells in 11 of the 12 cases, despite negative SARS-CoV-2 PCR, suggesting possible antigen persistence.
