In a case–control MRI study of 19 preschoolers about 30 days after mild COVID-19 versus 22 controls, researchers found increased LGI/area/volume in the left superior parietal cortex and greater cortical thickness in the left lateral occipital cortex. Graph-theory analysis of LGI-based structural covariance networks showed lower clustering coefficient in the COVID group (AUC P = 0.028) and fewer network hubs (2 vs 5), though small-worldness persisted. Glymphatic proxies were mixed: choroid plexus volume was higher after COVID (left CP P = 0.041; total CP P = 0.043), but DTI-ALPS indices did not significantly differ (total P = 0.385; left P = 0.081).

In a RECOVER EHR cohort of 1.21 million children/adolescents (<21 y) from 19 U.S. institutions, those with documented SARS-CoV-2 infection (n=297,920) had higher risks of cardiovascular outcomes 28–179 days post-infection versus controls (n=915,402). Composite “any cardiovascular outcome” risk was RR 1.63 in both CHD and non-CHD strata. The largest relative increases were for inflammatory heart disease (myocarditis/pericarditis: RR 2.92 non-CHD), with notable elevations across arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation in CHD RR 2.64), heart failure/cardiomyopathy (≈RR 1.5–1.8), thrombotic events (≈RR 1.26–1.42), and symptoms such as chest pain and palpitations (≈RR 1.7–2.1). Absolute risks were modest but non-trivial; for example, in non-CHD, chest pain was 1.23% vs 0.61% in controls. Effects were broadly consistent across age, sex, race/ethnicity, obesity, acute severity, and variant periods (including Omicron).

This review posits an oral-vascular-pulmonary pathway for COVID-19: SARS-CoV-2 replicates to 10^8 copies/mL in saliva, crosses inflamed periodontal tissues into the blood, and seeds the pulmonary microvasculature, producing the characteristic vascular (not airway-dominant) pattern of lung injury. Observational data link periodontitis to markedly higher risks of hospitalization (OR 36.52), ventilation (7.45), and death (14.58), and show salivary viral load predicts mortality.

In 40 unvaccinated adults with acute COVID-19, chest CT showed universal parenchymal lung injury but relatively infrequent and limited airways inflammation (23%). Vascular abnormalities dominated: dilated peripheral pulmonary vessels feeding damaged lung in a gravity-dependent, bilateral (95%), basal (90%), peripheral (92.5%), and posterior (90%) pattern; macrothrombosis was present on 23% of CTPAs, and wedge-shaped peripheral opacities suggestive of vascular congestion/infarction occurred in 53%. Plain chest radiographs mirrored CT distribution in 98%, indicating that radiographs can capture the same vascularly patterned disease geography.

In a cohort of 4,697 symptomatic adult COVID-19 patients from middle- and high-income settings, one in four (25.1%) reported at least one symptom persisting to 180 days post-enrolment. The most frequent symptoms were sleeping disturbances (12.8%), joint pain (9.8%), fatigue (8.7%), and headaches (8.1%). Long COVID prevalence was significantly higher in lower-middle income countries (29.8%) than in high-income countries (14.4%), and was elevated among those who had required hospitalization (adjusted odds ratio 2.04). Additional risk factors included older age, male sex, and hypertension, while vaccination, prior lung disease, smoking, and diabetes appeared to confer protective associations.

The authors hypothesize that SARS-CoV-2 may exploit allergen-like epitopes to provoke IgE responses, thereby dampening conventional antiviral immunity, and that the immune system responds with elevated IgG4, a subclass known for immunoregulatory/tolerizing behavior. They marshal clinical correlations showing that higher total IgE and SARS-CoV-2–specific IgE levels associate with disease severity, lung damage, and hypoxia, and that in fatal COVID-19 cases, high IgG4 levels (> 700 mg/dL) are common, with autopsy lung samples showing 80–90 % IgG4 expression during acute disease. They further argue that repeated exposure (e.g. booster vaccinations) could skew immunity toward IgG4, impairing effector functions (complement activation, Fc-mediated phagocytosis) and potentially promoting viral persistence or chronic infection (and possibly long COVID).

In a multi-centre questionnaire-based study of 3,693 individuals in China with a history of SARS-CoV-2 infection, the authors found that 30.2 % (n = 1,117) reported at least one persistent symptom fitting the WHO definition of long COVID, and 10.7 % (n = 394) had symptoms impacting daily life. Systemic complaints (especially fatigue) dominated the symptom profile, with fatigue (16.3 %), cough (6.3 %), and expectoration (5.5 %) being most frequent. Both the prevalence of symptoms and the cumulative symptom severity score declined significantly over a 180-day follow-up period. Risk analysis revealed older age (OR 1.63), female sex (OR 1.19), and SARS-CoV-2 reinfection (OR 3.56) increased long COVID risk, while higher COVID vaccine doses (OR 0.87) and use of traditional Chinese medicine (OR 0.51 for daily-life impacting symptoms) were protective.

In a 126-person cohort, the study compared SARS-CoV-2-naïve controls (N=30) to individuals ~4 months after infection (pre-Omicron) who either recovered (N=38) or developed Long COVID (N=58). Multi-omic immune profiling showed persistent immune and metabolic disruptions after COVID-19, including inflammasome-active immature monocytes, oxidative stress, ↑ arachidonic acid, ↓ tryptophan, and altered T-cell phenotypes. Within Long COVID specifically, they report greater CD8⁺ T-cell senescence and distinctive single-cell transcriptomic signatures in CD4⁺/CD8⁺ T cells and monocytes.

This study performed untargeted lipidomic profiling on plasma from individuals approximately two years after COVID-19 infection (first wave), comparing to healthy controls and to their own acute-phase samples, to explore residual lipid metabolic disturbances associated with long COVID. In 22 post-COVID patients (13 with paired acute vs follow-up samples), the authors found that 59 % still experienced fatigue and 50 % musculoskeletal symptoms. Multivariate analyses separated post-COVID lipidomes from both controls and acute-phase COVID, and the paired comparison identified 170 dysregulated lipid features. Pathway enrichment suggested persistent perturbations in sterol, bile acid, isoprenoid, and fatty ester metabolism, including elevated phosphatidylcholines and sphingomyelins. Despite the normalization of many standard clinical lab values over two years, the lipidomic signatures imply continuing molecular-level dysregulation that might underly the heterogeneous symptoms of post-COVID.

In this panel study of 65 elite athletes (average age ~23, 66 % male) who contracted pre-Omicron SARS-CoV-2, long-term outcomes and exercise capacity were assessed at two time points: immediately after recovery (negative PCR) and 16 weeks later. The infection prevalence was similar in contact and noncontact sports (10.8 % vs 11.3 %). Notably, 37 % had symptoms longer than 4 weeks, 25 % beyond 8 weeks, and 20 % remained symptomatic at 16 weeks. More than half paused training for 4–8 weeks. At 16 weeks, 40 % still perceived reduced performance, and 64 % reported ongoing limitations in participation, especially due to fatigue, breathlessness, and musculoskeletal complaints.

The authors measured NK cell subsets in participants ~4 months after SARS-CoV-2 infection and found that those with long COVID had reduced percentages of mature cytotoxic NK cells (CD56^dim/CD16+ and KIR2D+ subsets) compared to people who recovered fully. The lower percentages of these NK phenotypes correlated with greater symptom burden, and unsupervised clustering revealed altered NK‐cell subpopulation structures depending on long COVID symptom categories, CMV serostatus, and presence of SARS-CoV-2 antigen in plasma.

The article proposes that a subset of patients with long COVID—persistent symptoms lasting months after SARS-CoV-2 infection—may face elevated cancer susceptibility or faster cancer progression. Mechanistically, SARS-CoV-2 is argued to influence oncogenic signaling, create sustained inflammatory milieus, and induce tissue injury, all conditions known to support tumor initiation and growth.

Cordon-Cardo et al. conceptualize COVID-19 as a systemic illness with distinct clinical and pathophysiological stages rather than a single respiratory condition. Their four-stage model spans asymptomatic viral entry, symptomatic dissemination, multi-system inflammation, and critical endothelial injury with thrombosis and organ failure. The framework integrates viral load dynamics, immune and coagulation biomarkers, and targeted treatment strategies for each stage. By likening COVID-19 progression to metastatic cancer, the authors propose that SARS-CoV-2’s spread to multiple organs via the vasculature justifies “metastatic” terminology.

Using human mast-cell lines (LUVA, LAD2, HMC-1), Zhang et al. show that coronavirus Spike/RBD proteins and common-cold CoVs (HCoV-229E, HCoV-NL63; MOI = 1) rapidly trigger mast-cell degranulation and pro-inflammatory gene expression via a conserved Src→PI3K→AKT→Ca²⁺ pathway that also depends on microtubules; pharmacologic inhibition (LY294002 100 µM, BAPTA-AM 20 µM, nocodazole 20 µM) blunts degranulation, implicating this cascade as a mechanistic driver of MC activation by coronaviruses.

Even after a mild SARS-CoV-2 infection, individuals may suffer persistent neurocognitive deficits, particularly when “brain fog” is present. In this study, among 75 participants (25 with brain fog, 26 without, 24 healthy controls), those with brain fog showed deficits in memory, attention, and visuospatial performance compared to both other groups. MRI revealed that COVID-19 survivors (with or without brain fog) had reduced gray matter concentration in temporal, fusiform, and orbital regions; those with brain fog also showed further reductions in subcortical areas (caudate, putamen/pallidum, amygdala). Functional connectivity changes were also detected: increased connectivity in default mode and visual networks, and decreased connectivity in dorsal attention networks—suggesting remodeling of brain networks after infection.

This preprint reports that although patients with long COVID and ME/CFS and healthy individuals subjected to 60 days of strict bed rest exhibit similarly reduced whole-body aerobic capacity, the muscle and metabolic underpinnings differ substantially. Bed rest leads to overt muscle atrophy, lower mitochondrial content (succinate dehydrogenase), and compensatory capillary changes. By contrast, patients do not show global atrophy, but instead display a shift away from type I (oxidative) fibers, intrinsic mitochondrial dysfunction beyond simple mitochondrial loss, and relatively lower capillary supply for a given fiber size (especially in ME/CFS). These findings argue against the idea that long COVID / ME/CFS exercise intolerance is simply due to deconditioning. Instead, intrinsic muscle and microvascular abnormalities likely contribute.

This study demonstrates that SARS-CoV-2 infects the human olfactory neuroepithelium—including sensory neurons, support cells, and immune cells—and triggers local inflammation and apoptosis. In parallel, in golden Syrian hamsters, intranasal SARS-CoV-2 causes transient anosmia and ageusia that persists until viral RNA and infectious virus disappear; the virus travels from the nasal epithelium into the olfactory bulb and other brain regions, with accompanying host gene expression changes in the olfactory bulb. Critically, in human patients with prolonged (> ~196 days) loss of smell, the authors detected viral RNA and infected cells in the olfactory mucosa alongside elevated inflammatory markers (e.g. IL-6), supporting the hypothesis that viral persistence and chronic inflammation in the olfactory epithelium may underlie long-lasting anosmia in COVID-19.

This pilot study compared 10 post-COVID individuals with persistent cognitive complaints to 7 matched COVID survivors without residual symptoms, assessing cognitive performance, self-reported health, and biomarkers. Although the groups performed similarly on most neuropsychological tests (with the exception of lower letter fluency in the symptomatic group), the long COVID group reported markedly worse quality of life, emotional and physical well-being, and had higher depression and anxiety scores. Biologically, the symptomatic group had lower serum nerve growth factor (NGF), a marker of neuroplasticity, and were more likely to exhibit elevated interleukin-10 (IL-10) and a higher pro-inflammatory index (9/10 vs. 1/7). These results suggest potential ongoing inflammation and reduced brain repair capacity in long COVID.

In a cohort of 98 long COVID patients (9–12 months post infection) with cardiopulmonary symptoms, this study used advanced imaging (hybrid ^18F-FDG PET/MRI and lung DECT) plus plasma protein profiling to detect persistent inflammatory and structural abnormalities. Ninety percent of subjects had lung abnormalities on DECT (67% infiltrates; 59% abnormal perfusion), and 57% had PET/MRI findings (myocarditis in 24%, pericardial uptake in 22%, periannular in 11%, vascular uptake in 30%). None of the control group (n = 9, history of SARS-CoV-2 but no cardiopulmonary symptoms) showed such PET/MRI abnormalities. The plasma protein signatures also differed between long COVID patients and controls and among those with versus without PET/MRI abnormalities.

In a retrospective series of 19 hemorrhagic stroke cases (2023–2024), Ota et al. used immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization to look for SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in cerebral arteries. They detected spike protein in 43.8% of vaccinated patients (up to 17 months post-vaccination), mostly in the intimal layer, with accompanying mild immune cell infiltration (CD4, CD8, CD68), but no nucleocapsid protein to indicate active viral infection. In situ hybridization in select cases supported that both vaccine-derived and virus-derived mRNA encoding spike could be present. They observed that all cases positive for spike were female (P = 0.015). The authors conclude this raises safety questions about mRNA vaccine biodistribution and long-term vascular effects in the brain.

This study followed 18 long COVID patients and 19 matched controls approximately 2 years after acute COVID-19 to assess persistent cardiovascular, autonomic, and vascular abnormalities. The long COVID group showed elevated muscle sympathetic nerve activity, increased aortic stiffness (via carotid–femoral pulse wave velocity), higher resting heart rate, and impaired endothelial function (lower flow-mediated dilation), as well as subtle cardiac dysfunction (lower ejection fraction and global strain, altered E/A ratio) and lower aerobic exercise capacity (reduced peak VO₂). Biomarker analysis revealed higher endothelial cell-derived extracellular vesicles and oxidative stress (protein carbonyls) and lower antioxidant SOD activity, while Ang II did not differ.

Yeung et al. identify a rare lung macrophage subset — nerve- and airway-associated interstitial macrophages (NAMs) — that plays a critical role in restraining SARS-CoV-2–induced lung pathology via type I interferon signaling. In mice, depletion of NAMs results in uncontrolled viral spread, heightened inflammation, severe weight loss, and 100 % mortality; conversely, mice with intact NAMs show limited viral dissemination, reduced tissue damage, and full survival. The authors further demonstrate that NAMs require IFNAR signaling to suppress excessive inflammation, and that human COVID-19 lung samples from deceased patients show reduced NAM-gene expression and elevated inflammatory signatures relative to survivors.

This study shows that neutrophils from hospitalized COVID-19 patients display signs of degranulation and express elevated LOX-1 and PD-L1, markers associated with polymorphonuclear myeloid-derived suppressor cells (PMN-MDSCs). The authors further demonstrate in vitro that SARS-CoV-2 can directly induce neutrophils from healthy donors to adopt a LOX-1⁺, PD-L1⁺ suppressive phenotype (without productive infection), capable of repressing T cell proliferation. Early expression of LOX-1/PD-L1 in patients was associated with worse disease progression. The authors suggest that neutrophil reprogramming into immunosuppressive PMN-MDSCs may contribute to immune dysfunction in severe COVID-19, and that targeting PD-L1 might help restore immune competence.

In a cohort of 107 healthy young adults (university students, aged 18–34), roughly two years after SARS-CoV-2 infection, those with persistent post COVID-19 condition (n = 16) showed notable long-term cognitive impairments. Compared to never-infected and recovered groups, the PCC group had significantly poorer performance in verbal working memory, divided attention, and response inhibition, with over half of subjects scoring below average in working memory and attention, and many showing concurrent deficits across domains. They also exhibited slower reaction times (“cognitive slowing”) across tasks, indicative of a generalized processing delay.

This prospective cohort of 108 hospitalized children in Japan found that 44.9%, 37.8%, and 22.8% reported at least one long-COVID symptom at 1, 3, and 6 months respectively after SARS-CoV-2 infection. The most frequent symptoms were cough, fatigue, and sleep disturbance, and the latter correlated with significantly lower quality of life at all timepoints. Children aged 7–17 years had a prevalence of ME/CFS-type symptoms comparable to their parents, whereas younger children (0–6 years) had fewer such symptoms. No clear risk factors (sex, acute disease severity, vaccination status) emerged for overall long-COVID, though older age was associated with ME/CFS-like symptoms.

In a U.S. cohort of ~1.9 million children and adolescents (487,378 with COVID-19, 1,412,768 controls), SARS-CoV-2 infection was associated with increased risk of new-onset chronic kidney disease (CKD stage ≥2: HR 1.17; CKD stage ≥3: HR 1.35) compared with uninfected controls. Among those with preexisting CKD, COVID-19 correlated with higher risk of composite kidney events (HR 1.15), and in those with acute kidney injury during infection, the hazard for further adverse kidney outcomes in the postacute period (90–179 days) was 1.29. The authors suggest that while these risks are relatively small, children with prior kidney disease or AKI warrant close monitoring after COVID-19.

Using Visium HD spatial transcriptomics, this study profiled epipharyngeal tissue from three long-COVID patients and two controls. It found residual SARS-CoV-2 spike RNA in the epipharynx of all long-COVID patients along with activation of SARS-CoV-2 signaling networks across epithelial cells, B cells, and pDCs. Clinically, patients had chronic epipharyngitis with elevated inflammation and symptoms. After 3 months of weekly epipharyngeal abrasive therapy, viral RNA cleared in two patients and decreased in one, T-cell receptor signaling was suppressed, IL-6/TNF-α expression dropped, and excess antibody production was mitigated; histology suggested removal of inflamed ciliated epithelium. Inflammation and VAS symptom scores improved.

In a preprint of 46 people with Long COVID, researchers ran two sub-maximal cardiopulmonary exercise tests 24 hours apart with blood draws before and after each session. On Day 2, VT1 VO₂ dropped from 9.7 to 8.9 ml·kg·min⁻¹ and O₂-pulse from 8.3 to 7.5 mL/beat, indicating worsened physiological response. Exercise fragmented large microclots and increased small microclots, and these shifts tracked with rises in inflammatory and vascular-injury cytokines. The authors conclude that exercise may aggravate LC by increasing microclot fragmentation and inflammation, cautioning against standard exercise-based rehabilitation without strategies targeting microclot clearance and endothelial repair.

This retrospective multicentre study assessed nailfold videocapillaroscopy (NVC) patterns in 1,294 participants (494 systemic sclerosis, 430 other CTDs, 370 healthy controls). The authors found that a “scleroderma” capillary pattern was highly prevalent in SSc (63.4 %), rare in other CTDs (5.6 %), and almost absent in healthy controls (0.3 %), with mean capillary density notably lower in SSc (4.9/mm) compared to other CTDs (6.8/mm) and controls (8.6/mm). Even among patients with disease duration ≤3 years, the scleroderma pattern was present in over half (51.6 %) of SSc cases. These findings support NVC as a potentially discriminative tool for SSc versus other connective tissue diseases, even in early disease.

In this cohort of 60 hospitalized COVID-19 survivors (mean age ~57 years; 41 requiring invasive mechanical ventilation, 19 with noninvasive ventilation), evaluated approximately 12 weeks post-discharge, 66 % scored below 26 on the MoCA and 85 % demonstrated impairment in at least one neuropsychological test. Structural brain MRI revealed correlations between specific cognitive deficits (e.g. naming, memory, visuospatial, executive) and imaging markers such as parietal or frontal atrophy, hippocampal and cingulate hyperintensities, and white matter lesions. Differences between ventilation groups were modest (e.g., MoCA score, subjective memory complaints), but prolonged intubation days, elevated D-dimer, anxiety, and depression were associated with worse functional prognosis.

🐁This study demonstrates that the SARS-CoV-2 Spike S1 subunit, administered to mice via intracerebral, intravenous, or intranasal routes, can induce region- and sex-specific neuroinflammation and perturb α-synuclein homeostasis. Intravenous administration in particular elevated aSyn immunoreactivity and microglial density in brain areas relevant to Parkinson’s disease, while intracerebral injection increased phosphorylated α-synuclein in males and intranasal exposure led to microgliosis and sex-dependent aSyn changes. All exposure routes also triggered changes in astrocytic reactivity, receptor expression (e.g. ACE2/Neuropilin-1), and the density of inhibitory parvalbumin-positive interneurons.

This double-blind, sham-controlled RCT (n=73 completers) tested hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) for persistent post-COVID symptoms. The HBOT arm received 40 sessions of 100% oxygen at 2.0 ATA for 90 min over ~8 weeks; the sham arm received normoxic air at 1.03 ATA with pressure cues. Versus sham, HBOT significantly improved global cognition (d = 0.50), attention (d = 0.48), executive function (d = 0.46), energy/fatigue (d = 0.52), sleep quality (d = −0.48), psychiatric symptoms (d = 0.64), and pain interference (d = 0.74) at 1–3 weeks post-treatment. Brain MRI showed increased perfusion and microstructural changes in fronto-insular and parietal regions, consistent with neuroplasticity. Limitations include the small, single-center sample; short follow-up; and industry relationships (two authors employed by, and one shareholder in, a company providing HBOT).

🐁In a mouse model of SARS-CoV-2 infection followed for 84 days, male mice had worse acute disease (more weight loss, delayed recovery, lung pathology) but no sex difference in viral loads or persistence. After recovery, female (XX) mice developed long-term neurocognitive impairments and CNS inflammation (microglial activation, dysregulated T cell subsets) that were not seen in males. Genetic experiments indicated that having two X chromosomes (XX) was sufficient (even in the absence of Y) to drive susceptibility to long COVID–like sequelae, possibly via upregulation of X-linked genes including Xist and Tlr7.

This multi-site NIH-supported study (Stanford, MaineHealth, Kentucky) explored adipose tissue’s role in post-COVID-19 sequelae. While prior autopsy work suggested viral persistence in fat, this analysis of living donors found no evidence of SARS-CoV-2 persistence months to years after infection. Instead, transcriptional remodeling occurred during the subacute phase—marked by suppressed immune signaling and up-regulation of Hox and integrin genes, which may affect adipose metabolism and systemic inflammation. Despite these short-term molecular changes, adipose tissue from Long COVID patients (>1 year post-infection) was transcriptionally indistinguishable from controls. Thus, subcutaneous adipose tissue likely contributes to transient inflammatory dysregulation following acute infection but does not drive Long COVID pathophysiology.

🧫Nguyen et al. (2025) report that amphotericin B (AmB) and nystatin, rather than inhibiting SARS-CoV-2, unexpectedly enhance infection in vitro. In Vero E6 cells, AmB increased viral replication up to ~100-fold (and ~10-fold in Calu-3 cells) while other tested antifungals had no effect. Mechanistic assays suggest this effect is mediated by enhanced viral entry, potentially through AmB overcoming the antiviral barrier of IFITM3 (an interferon-induced restriction factor).

This study shows that human adipose tissue is frequently infected by SARS-CoV-2 and that visceral adipocytes are markedly more permissive than subcutaneous adipocytes. In 23/47 (49%) post-mortem fat samples from COVID-19 decedents, viral RNA and spike protein were detected within adipocytes. In vitro, visceral adipocytes had ~240× higher viral RNA and secreted ~770× more infectious particles at 24 hpi than subcutaneous cells, consistent with higher ACE2 levels; viability dropped to ~70% by days 4–5 in both depots. Responses also depended on viral lineage: the Gamma (P.1) variant yielded ~17× lower viral load than the original B lineage in visceral adipocytes and induced up-regulated interferon-signaling proteins, whereas the B lineage down-regulated interferon-pathway proteins and strongly increased cytokines (e.g., TNF-α >100-fold). The work supports adipose tissue—especially visceral fat—as a potential extrapulmonary reservoir and inflammatory driver in COVID-19, while noting in-vitro and sampling limitations and the absence of clinical outcome data.

This study shows that human fat (adipose) tissue is a direct target of SARS-CoV-2. In 7/8 COVID-19 autopsies, adipose depots contained viral RNA and inflammatory cell infiltrates. In ex vivo infections, mature adipocytes from multiple depots supported productive infection and released infectious virus, while adipose-resident macrophages underwent abortive infection coupled to strong inflammatory signaling; preadipocytes became inflamed as bystanders. Notably, the infected cell types lacked detectable ACE2 protein, implying alternative entry mechanisms in fat. Single-cell profiling across ~199k cells mapped these responses at high resolution. The findings suggest a biological explanation for why obesity increases COVID-19 severity: adipose tissue can act as a viral niche and an amplifier of inflammation.

This study in 38 post–COVID-19 men (27 mild, 11 moderate) found that SARS-CoV-2 RNA was detectable in semen in 55% of cases overall (21/38), especially in moderate disease (91%). The viral RNA signals had high Ct values (38–39). Infectious virus was successfully cultured from 17 participants, with evidence of viable viral particles up to 8 months after infection. Semen quality parameters (count, motility, concentration) were depressed in early samples but improved by 6 months. Inflammatory lymphocyte markers (CD3, CD4, CD8, CD45) in semen peaked at 3 months and decreased by 6 months.

In severe COVID-19, the study finds that tiny blood vessels are often blocked not by classic clots, but by sticky layers of membranes from burst red blood cells. These layers form where endothelial cells die by necroptosis (MLKL-dependent), and complement helps drive the RBC rupture. The authors observed this mechanism across multiple human organs in COVID-19 and replicated it in mouse ischaemia-reperfusion and SARS-CoV-2 infection models—watching the “endo-seal” form in real time. When modest, the seal prevents bleeding; when excessive, it aggregates RBCs and occludes microvessels, explaining COVID-19 microangiopathy. The human set included 8 autopsies sampling 5 organs each, with post-mortem delays 12–48 h (one 216 h case excluded from injury metrics). Kidney, liver, and heart showed dominant RBC-membrane–driven obstruction in COVID-19, lungs did not. Endothelial Mlkl deletion in mice reduced haemolysis, obstruction, and tissue injury, pointing to necroptosis/complement as therapeutic targets—beyond standard anticoagulation, which targets platelets/fibrin that were not central here.

🧫The study investigates how the SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid (N) protein, even in the absence of replicating virus, may persist in cells and tissues and thereby drive a sustained type I interferon–based inflammatory response via mitochondrial dysfunction. Using in vitro and ex vivo models, the authors show that residual N expression associates with elevated reactive oxygen species, mtDNA release, and activation of innate immune sensing pathways, resulting in prolonged upregulation of interferon-stimulated genes. They propose that this mechanism offers a plausible molecular basis for some long COVID phenomena—i.e. persistent immune activation in the absence of detectable viral replication.

🐁🐹This paper demonstrates that the SARS-CoV-2 nonstructural protein 15 (nsp15) functions as a virulence factor by using its endoribonuclease (EndoU) activity to reduce the accumulation of viral double-stranded RNA intermediates. By doing so, nsp15 dampens host innate immune sensing and signaling, thereby promoting viral replication and pathogenicity in lung epithelial cells and in vivo models (hamsters, K18-hACE2 mice). In K18-hACE2 mice, the wild-type virus (with intact nsp15 activity) caused higher mortality and evidence of neuroinvasion, whereas EndoU-inactive mutants were attenuated and largely confined to the respiratory tract. Viruses carrying inactive nsp15 were attenuated: they stimulated stronger antiviral responses, had lower replication, and caused lower mortality. These findings support a mechanistic role for nsp15 in immune evasion and pathogenesis of SARS-CoV-2.

In immunocompromised patients with persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection, the authors demonstrate that autologous virus-specific T cell therapy can be feasibly manufactured in most patients (10/12, 83.3 %) and, when infused, was associated with viral clearance (3 patients cleared viral RNA in 3–9 weeks) and clinical improvement without serious adverse events. The therapy appeared safe (no cytokine release syndrome or GVHD), and immunologic profiling suggested emergence of SARS-CoV-2–specific CD4 and CD8 T cell responses and subsequent development of neutralizing antibody titers post-VST infusion.

This 7 Tesla MRI study compared hippocampal subfield volumes in 17 long COVID patients, 29 ME/CFS patients, and 15 healthy controls, finding that both long COVID and ME/CFS patients showed larger volumes than controls in left hippocampal subfields (subiculum head, presubiculum head, molecular layer head, and the whole hippocampal head). No significant volumetric differences were seen between the long COVID and ME/CFS groups. The enlarged subregions may indicate structural adaptation or neuroplastic responses in these illnesses. Moreover, in both patient groups, hippocampal volumes correlated with symptom severity metrics: for example, in long COVID, higher pain, fatigue, duration of illness, and unrefreshing sleep were generally associated with smaller subfield volumes in certain regions (negative correlations). In ME/CFS, associations were also seen between hippocampal volumes and unrefreshing sleep, pain, concentration, and physical function.

Prenatal exposure to SARS-CoV-2 infection in the third trimester (35-37 weeks) was studied in a cohort of pregnant women in Brazil, with cord blood cytokine/chemokine profiling and follow-up of their children at 6 and 24 months. The children had substantial proportions of developmental delays in cognitive, communication, and motor domains, with delays increasing over time (communication delays rising from 20% at 6 months to ~64% at 24 months, motor from ~40% to ~57%). Cord blood immune markers (elevated IFN-γ and TNF-α) were associated with cognitive delays, while IL-6, IL-8, IL-17, IL-1β related to motor delays, and chemokines like CXCL10 related to communication delays.

Thomas et al. conducted a two-day submaximal CPET study in 68 people with long COVID (mean age 50 y, 68% female) to investigate whether physiological deterioration could be demonstrated after repeated exertion (a potential model for post-exertional symptom exacerbation). They observed a statistically significant decline between Day 1 and Day 2 in VO₂ at the ventilatory threshold (0.73 → 0.68 L/min), work rate at VT₁ (28 → 24 W), and oxygen pulse (8.2 → 7.5 mL/beat), as well as reduced end-tidal CO₂, suggesting reduced cardiopulmonary performance or oxygen delivery/utilization 24 h later. Notably, half the participants failed to reach 85% of age-predicted maximum heart rate, and logistic regression showed that younger age and a longer time since acute COVID predicted better submaximal exercise attainment.

This study used optical coherence tomography angiography imaging to examine retinal microcirculation in COVID-19 recovered patients (n = 33) and healthy controls (n = 28), approximately 138 ± 71 days post infection. It found that vessel density (VD) in the intermediate capillary plexus (ICP) was significantly reduced in post-COVID individuals (p = 0.0133 overall, and in multiple “circular” sectors), and that peripapillary VD was also lower (p = 0.0179). Post-COVID patients who had required hospitalization showed additional reductions in adjacent vascular layers (SVP, DCP), and VD metrics negatively correlated with severity markers (e.g. D-dimer, GPT). In a retrospective subset of 29 ICU COVID-19 patients, 17% exhibited retinal hemorrhages or cotton wool spots during their hospitalization.

This preprint reviews evidence that many inflammatory and vascular conditions—including acute and Long COVID, ME/CFS, sepsis, and neurodegenerative diseases—feature fibrinaloid (amyloid) microclots that resist normal fibrinolysis and can obstruct capillary flow. In parallel, nailfold capillaroscopy (NFC) frequently shows decreased capillary density/length and flow, increased tortuosity/meandering, and microhaemorrhages in these same conditions. The authors argue that NFC (functional) and microclot assays (structural) are complementary and should be combined with endothelial biomarkers for stronger disease assessment.

In a German online cohort of 1,405 adults ( 910 prior-infected; 495 never-infected), the authors tested cognition and mental health and found a selective deficit in hippocampus-dependent mnemonic discrimination among those with prior COVID-19. On the Mnemonic Similarity Task (MST; N = 151), prior-infected participants showed lower lure discrimination (LDI)—a signature of impaired pattern separation—while item recognition was preserved, and the effect remained after adjusting for age, sex, education, depression, anxiety, and stress. Longer time since infection correlated with worse LDI. A Corsi forward (visuo-spatial working memory) deficit was also observed and correlated with LDI, whereas other attention/executive tasks showed little or no group differences. The authors interpret this as behavioral evidence consistent with hippocampal (DG) vulnerability—potentially via neuroinflammation and disrupted neurogenesis—after SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Between 1990 and 2021, mental disorders in ASEAN countries rose sharply: in 2021 there were ~ 80.4 million cases (a 70% increase from 1990), with age-standardised prevalence ~ 11.9%. The burden measured as DALYs also rose—about 11.2 million DALYs in 2021, an ~ 87% increase since 1990. The burden is especially notable among adolescents (10–14 years) where mental disorders accounted for ~ 16.3% of all DALYs, and among those aged ≥ 70 who saw the greatest relative increase in absolute cases (182.8%).

This study of 76 COVID-19 recovered individuals versus 51 healthy controls used a battery of MRI modalities (T1, diffusion, resting-state fMRI, arterial spin labeling) to probe long-term brain alterations. While overall brain volumes did not differ, focal atrophy was found in right basal ganglia and limbic regions, and cortical volume reductions in paralimbic areas (insula, temporal cortex). Diffusion metrics revealed microstructural damage (lower FA, higher RD) especially in tracts like the uncinate fasciculus and cingulum, with more pronounced changes in those who had been hospitalized. Functional connectivity differences emerged only in the more severe group, whereas cerebral blood flow differences were not observed. The findings support a model in which post-COVID neurological and cognitive symptoms may stem from selective disruption of basal ganglia–limbic–cortical networks, rather than diffuse global injury.

This meta-analysis of 464 autopsy cases of COVID-19 decedents finds recurrent neuropathological features including microvascular injury, activation of microglia, hypoxic-ischemic changes, and microthrombi, suggesting multifactorial pathways of brain damage. The findings emphasize that COVID-19 may damage the brain both via vascular injury and secondary hypoxia, rather than through a single dominant mechanism. The analysis also notes heterogeneity across studies in reporting methods, definitions, and sampling, which complicates drawing definitive mechanistic conclusions.

This longitudinal study of 28 non-vaccinated COVID-19 patients in Portugal and Brazil found that within only 7 days, both CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T-cell populations shifted toward senescent and exhausted phenotypes (CD28⁻CD57⁺KLRG1⁺). These changes occurred in mild, moderate, and severe cases alike. The cytokine milieu revealed strong inflammatory activation, with IFN-γ, IL-6, and TNF initially elevated and partly subsiding by day 7 in the older Portuguese cohort, while younger Brazilian patients continued to show heightened inflammation. The authors suggest that SARS-CoV-2 infection can accelerate immunosenescence—normally a hallmark of aging—within days. This may impair antiviral responses, heighten susceptibility to complications, and contribute to the broader “inflammaging” observed in COVID-19. The effect’s presence across age and severity groups implies that even transient infection episodes can impose long-lasting immunological aging pressure.

This meta-analysis of 125 observational studies (≥ 6 months follow-up, > 4 million patients) quantifies the prevalence of long-term neurological and neuropsychiatric symptoms following COVID-19. The authors report that fatigue affects about 43.3% (CI 36.1–50.9%) of survivors, while memory disorders (27.8%), cognitive impairment (27.1%), sleep disorders (24.4%), concentration impairment (23.8%), headache (20.3%), dizziness (16.0%), stress (15.9%), depression (14.0%), anxiety (13.2%), and migraine (~13.0%) are also common. Subgroup analyses indicate that females and those with higher BMI show elevated prevalence for certain symptoms (e.g. fatigue, stress).

In a cross-sectional comparison of Dutch youth, 106 children with physician-diagnosed Long COVID reported substantially worse Health-related quality of life (HRQoL) than peers with other chronic illnesses and the general population. Eighty-four percent met criteria for impaired HRQoL, corresponding to a 3.67-fold higher risk (95% CI 2.35–5.74) versus the CHC cohort. On PROMIS measures, pediatric Long COVID showed higher anxiety and depressive symptoms and more sleep-related impairment, with mean T-score differences of 2.2–9.8 points (95% CI 0.6–11.7) and severe-symptom prevalences around 17–18%. These effects were observed despite using validated instruments (PedsQL 4.0; PROMIS) and covariate-adjusted analyses.

In 28 adults with ongoing “brain fog” several months after mild COVID-19, researchers combined FDG-PET with EEG to map brain dysfunction. They found eight significant hypometabolic clusters across bilateral frontal, temporal, and parietal cortices (plus left occipital), with the largest in the right frontal lobe (T = 10.49; k = 2,917). EEG showed frontal-predominant slowing—higher delta/theta and lower alpha power—mirroring PET abnormalities. Median MoCA was 25, fatigue was common (FSS 5.64, 53.6% above cut-off), and assessments occurred a mean 5.3 months after infection. These convergent imaging–neurophysiology findings suggest anterior network dysfunction underlies cognitive complaints in post-COVID patients, even after non-severe acute illness.

🧫The authors tested the hypothesis that SARS-CoV-2 infection (or exposure to its spike protein) could promote Alzheimer-type pathology, specifically extracellular aggregation of amyloid-β, using human retinal tissue explants and human retinal organoids. They observed that SARS-CoV-2 exposure leads to increased amyloid-β aggregates in retinal neurons and glial cells in the ex vivo tissues and in organoids. In human donor retinas from individuals who had COVID-19 (but no prior dementia diagnosis), they also found elevated amyloid-β accumulation compared to non–COVID controls, to levels comparable to Alzheimer’s cases. Mechanistically, they showed that blocking the receptor neuropilin-1 (NRP1), which is used by SARS-CoV-2 spike protein for entry, attenuated the amyloid-β deposition induced by spike protein in retinal explants, implicating spike–NRP1 interaction in driving or enhancing amyloid-β aggregation.

In a matched, population-based sample from Portugal (n=698), people infected with SARS-CoV-2 in 2020–2021 had a higher battery-confirmed prevalence of cognitive impairment when tested about two years later. Compared with matched uninfected peers, impairment was 19.1% vs 6.8% in those hospitalized (adjusted OR 5.41) and 10.7% vs 3.2% in those not hospitalized (adjusted OR 3.27). Impairment among hospitalized cases also tended to involve more cognitive domains. Older age, lower education, anxiety, and infection were associated with higher odds of impairment. The study used a two-step method (MoCA screening, then full neuropsychological testing) to mitigate over-reliance on screening tools alone.

This study examined 97 individuals 3 to 17 months post SARS-CoV-2 infection (across mild, severe, and critical cases) and compared them with 64 sepsis patients to assess long-term immune changes and possible influences of Bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG) vaccination or latent viral/parasitic infections. The authors found persistent dysregulation in both myeloid and lymphoid compartments (e.g. altered expression of CD39, CD57, TIGIT, CD64, CD11b), with particularly elevated CD57 on CD8⁺ T cells in formerly critical COVID-19 patients. While seropositivity to BCG or latent infections (CMV, T. gondii) was somewhat less common in the more severe COVID cohorts and showed a non-definitive trend toward better outcomes in sepsis, ex vivo stimulation of monocytes from convalescents or BCG-vaccinated individuals did not show robust differences in cytokine responses. Despite the evidence of immune remodeling long after acute infection, the study did not support the hypothesis that BCG vaccination in childhood confers lasting trained immunity detectable in adult monocyte function.

In 458 post-COVID participants assessed 6–9 months after infection, PASC occurred in 40% (mild) and 57.4% (severe). Broad serologic/virologic/tissue-damage biomarkers—including anti-RBD IgG, cytokines (IL-6, IL-8, IFN-γ, IFN-β1/λ1), and neuro-injury markers (Nf-L, GFAP)—were largely determined by initial disease severity, not specifically by PASC. By contrast, T-cell readouts clearly separated PASC from non-PASC: PASC was associated with altered CD4⁺/CD8⁺ memory composition, higher cytokine-secreting cells, and expanded TEMRA phenotypes, including elevated SARS-CoV-2 N/M-specific TEMRA cells. A random-forest model leveraging these variables plus initial symptom duration classified PASC with >80% accuracy.

A previously healthy 34-year-old woman developed severe psychosis following COVID-19 infection, characterized by auditory hallucinations, intrusive thoughts, hyperreligiosity, and apocalyptic delusions. After inpatient psychiatric treatment, her hallucinations remitted but delusional and hyperreligious beliefs persisted, and she required rehospitalization only eight days after her discharge, failing to achieve full remission.

🐁The authors used K18-hACE2 mice infected with SARS-CoV-2 (1×10² PFU), followed by a 14-day recovery, and then exposed them to alcohol (6 g/kg). They found that the previously infected mice sustained more severe liver injury (elevated ALT, vacuolated hepatocytes) than controls despite having lower blood alcohol levels but higher acetaldehyde accumulation. The data suggest that prior SARS-CoV-2 infection causes persistent upregulation of hepatic cytochrome P450 enzymes (notably CYP1A2 and CYP2E1), which likely enhances conversion of alcohol to acetaldehyde, increasing hepatotoxic stress. Mechanistically, elevated TNF-α expression was linked to upregulation of transcription factors (aryl hydrocarbon receptor and Sp1) which bound to promoters of CYP1A2 and CYP2E1, respectively, driving their increased expression. No significant intestinal damage was observed in the model. The authors conclude that SARS-CoV-2 infection may reprogram hepatic metabolic enzyme states in a way that increases susceptibility to further insults such as alcohol consumption, with potential relevance to long COVID and liver health.

This study tested how wearing an exercise-specific face mask (ESFM) affects physiological, respiratory, perceptual, and performance responses during graded treadmill exercise in 24 aerobically fit individuals. Compared to being unmasked, ESFM use reduced performance (median time to exhaustion decreased by ~150.5 s), lowered arterial oxygen saturation at peak intensity by ~3.7 %, and increased perceptions of air hunger and work of breathing (especially at submaximal intensities). Interestingly, while spirometric measures at termination were similar between conditions, during submaximal intensities some mid-expiratory flows (e.g. FEF 25–75, FEF₅₀) were modestly improved with the mask. An ESFM is protective of the lung, improving within-exercise respiratory function. However, these benefits need to be balanced with the degree of perceptual and physiological burden, elevating multiple sensations of dyspnea and inducing significant reductions in SpO2 at both submaximal and maximal exercise intensities.

🐁This study provides evidence that SARS-CoV-2 infection can provoke a Sjögren’s syndrome-like phenotype. In ACE2 transgenic mice infected with SARS-CoV-2, salivary flow was reduced nearly by half (6.64 vs 13.12 µL/g), mice developed antinuclear antibodies (70% positive), elevated anti-SSB/La, and lymphocytic infiltration plus apoptosis in the salivary and lacrimal glands. In humans recovered from COVID-19, sera showed increased ANA, anti-SSA/Ro52, and anti-SSB/La, and minor salivary gland biopsies of 6 individuals revealed focal lymphocytic infiltrates in 4 and focus scores ≥ 2 in 2, which histologically resemble SjD pathology. Moreover, several monoclonal antibodies derived from convalescent patients blocked ACE2–spike binding but also cross-reacted with nuclear antigens, hinting at potential molecular mimicry.

Romanella et al. review evidence implicating Chlamydia pneumoniae and SARS-CoV-2 as possible contributors to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathogenesis. They argue that both pathogens may access the brain either via the olfactory neuroepithelium or across the blood-brain barrier, using distinct entry mechanisms (Cpn via proteoglycans, SARS-CoV-2 via ACE2 and neuropilin-1). Once in the CNS, they may trigger or sustain neuroinflammation through elevated IL-6 and CCL2, especially in individuals carrying APOE ε4, potentially promoting amyloid and tau pathology.

🐶🐹This experimental study shows that SARS-CoV-2–infected dogs can transmit the virus to hamsters kept in close proximity. Exposed hamsters developed infection confirmed by histopathology along with lung pathology. Notably, the authors report neurological effects in hamsters—blood–brain barrier (BBB) damage, immune activation, and neurodegenerative changes—implicating cross-species transmission as a contributor to CNS pathology.

Gross et al. studied 472 infants/toddlers (0–2 years) and 539 preschool children (3–5 years), comparing SARS-CoV-2–infected versus uninfected participants, to identify long COVID symptom profiles in early childhood. They evaluated up to 75 prolonged symptoms, derived separate symptom indices per age group (with weighted symptom scores), and applied threshold criteria (≥4 pts in infants/toddlers; ≥3 in preschool) to classify probable LC. Among infected children, 14 % of infants/toddlers (40/278) and 15 % of preschoolers (61/399) met the LC threshold. Higher index scores correlated with lower general health, poorer quality of life, and caregiver‐perceived developmental delays. The study’s findings highlight that symptom patterns in very young children differ from older populations, suggesting that screening for long COVID in early childhood should not rely on adult or older-child templates.

In a longitudinal UK Biobank analysis, brain-age models trained on 15,334 adults were applied to 996 repeatedly scanned participants to test for pandemic-related effects on brain ageing. Compared with Controls scanned entirely before COVID-19, those scanned once before and once after the pandemic showed +5.5 months greater brain-age deviation at follow-up, indicating accelerated brain ageing. This pattern held even without documented infection, and the acceleration was stronger in men and in people from more deprived areas. Model performance was strong (r ≈ 0.89–0.91, MAE 2.9–3.09 y; ICC ≈ 0.98), and effect sizes for acceleration were moderate to large (GM d = 0.606; WM d = 0.697). Notably, accelerated ageing related to cognitive decline only among participants who had COVID-19, suggesting infection may couple pandemic-era brain-age changes to cognition.

In this study of 155 individuals, Bendella et al. used AI-based MRI volumetry to compare brain volumes across three groups: mild (n = 51), severe (n = 48) COVID-19 survivors, and healthy controls (n = 56). They found a statistically significant gradient of brain atrophy (severe > mild > control), particularly in supratentorial grey matter, frontal and parietal lobes, and the right thalamus. Multivariate modeling affirmed that severe infection (versus control) was an independent predictor of volume loss, even when ICU cases were excluded, alongside demographic covariates.

The authors followed over 4.6 million Norwegian adults between 2021 and 2023, comparing all-cause mortality among those who received mRNA COVID-19 vaccination and those who remained unvaccinated, adjusting for sex, age, location, and risk factors. They found that vaccinated groups consistently showed lower mortality rates than unvaccinated, with adjusted incidence rate ratios below 1 in almost all age and calendar-year strata.

In breakthrough SARS-CoV-2 infections, stronger activation of both naïve and memory T cells—especially CD8⁺ subsets—correlates with more rapid viral clearance, suggesting that effective T cell immunity is a key factor in resolving infection even in vaccinated individuals. The authors argue that not merely quantity but functional “fitness” of T cells (“happy” rather than exhausted or dysregulated) is central to this process.

COVID-19 is not only a respiratory disease but also a vascular and thromboinflammatory disorder: SARS-CoV-2 infection induces a prothrombotic state via endothelial injury, complement activation, extracellular vesicles bearing tissue factor, platelet overactivation, and neutrophil extracellular traps, among other pathways. In acute COVID-19, pooled evidence shows ~21 % incidence of thrombosis (DVT ~20 %, PE ~8 %, arterial ~5 %) in hospitalized patients, and survivors carry elevated risks (e.g. ~1.2 % incidence of PE, ~2.3 % for DVT post-COVID, HR ~3.16 and ~2.55, respectively). Persistent microclots and procoagulant factors in long COVID may sustain vascular damage, establishing feedback loops of inflammation, coagulation and hypoxia. In terms of prevention and treatment, most trials to date have tested heparin or LMWH in hospitalized patients, with mixed results: therapeutic anticoagulation may improve survival in noncritically ill patients but raises bleeding risk, and in critically ill patients benefits are less clear. Only one trial has included children, and many guideline recommendations remain cautious, advising prophylactic anticoagulation in hospital settings and selective post-discharge use.

In a patient with COVID-19, Verheyden et al. describe relapsing symmetric livedo reticularis affecting the limbs, which coincided with the course of SARS-CoV-2 infection. The authors propose that the skin finding might reflect microvascular involvement, endothelial injury, coagulation disturbances or vasospasm induced by the virus, analogous to other acral or purpura skin manifestations seen in COVID-19.

🐹🧫This preprint describes a mechanism linking transient SARS-CoV-2 infection of olfactory epithelium (targeting sustentacular cells) to a prolonged, localized neuroinflammation in the olfactory bulb, mediated by degeneration of olfactory sensory neurons (OSNs) and subsequent microglial activation. Using a hamster model and supporting human data, the authors show that viral RNA persists in the olfactory epithelium for ~10 days, while viral proteins clear by ~5 days, and that epithelial damage causes progressive OSN loss. Axonal debris accumulates in the olfactory bulb and triggers sustained transcriptional immune responses (e.g. phagocytosis, synaptic remodeling) in microglia, spatially restricted to the projections of the damaged OSNs. Thus, even after viral clearance and without direct infection of the brain, peripheral neuronal injury can lead to a durable glial inflammatory state. This suggests a plausible pathway for neurologic symptoms in long COVID that does not require persistent viral reservoirs in the brain. The model highlights a delayed injury-to-glia axis as a general principle by which transient peripheral insults might cause long-lasting changes in brain function.

🧫This study demonstrates that the SARS-CoV-2 main protease (Mᵖʳᵒ) can directly activate human coagulation. When recombinant Mᵖʳᵒ was added to plasma from 21 donors, the probability of clotting within 1 hour increased ~3-fold (p = 0.003). Using degradomics and N-terminomics (TAILS), the authors showed that Mᵖʳᵒ cleaves and activates FVII at Arg152–Ile153 and FXII at Arg353–Val354, i.e., the canonical activation sites that initiate the extrinsic and intrinsic pathways. They also identify a secondary Arg-at-P1 specificity (~10%) in Mᵖʳᵒ, consistent with zymogen activation chemistry; an inactive Mᵖʳᵒ mutant did not induce clotting. Structural/biochemical support includes HDX-MS mapping of an Arg-containing inhibitor (PPACK, Ki ≈ 160 ± 2 nM) to Mᵖʳᵒ and partial inhibition by Argatroban (~20% activity reduction). Together, the data propose a viral-protease–driven pathway for COVID-19 coagulopathy that complements inflammation-based explanations and positions Mᵖʳᵒ as a mechanistic link to thrombosis—and a potential therapeutic target to explore.

🧫This in vitro biochemical study shows that the SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid (NC) protein can directly bind the forkhead DNA-binding domain of FOXP3, and under DNA-binding conditions, high NC concentrations can displace FOXP3 from its DNA binding. The competition suggests a mechanism by which NC could dysregulate FOXP3 function, which is known to be important for platelet development and regulation, and thus contribute to COVID-associated coagulopathy.

This pragmatic randomized crossover trial evaluated whether use of in-home HEPA air purifiers could reduce blood pressure in adults living near major roadways. In 154 participants (mean age ~41 years, baseline SBP ~118.8 mm Hg), each individual underwent one month of HEPA filtration and one month of sham (filter removed), with a washout period in between. The key finding was that among participants whose baseline systolic blood pressure (SBP) was ≥ 120 mm Hg, HEPA filtration reduced SBP by 2.8 mm Hg while sham increased it by 0.2 mm Hg, leading to a net 3.0 mm Hg benefit (P = 0.04). No significant benefit was observed for diastolic BP or in those with lower baseline SBP. The study suggests that relatively modest improvements in indoor air quality may yield clinically meaningful BP reductions in populations exposed to traffic‐related particulate pollution, even in settings with comparatively low ambient PM₂.₅. However, the effect was limited to those with elevated SBP.

Ben-Ami et al. developed an epigenetic liquid-biopsy approach, analyzing cell-free DNA methylation and histone marks to assign tissue-of-origin signatures, and applied it to COVID-19 patients across a severity spectrum. They found that severe disease is associated with dramatically elevated cfDNA from lung, cardiac, endothelial, and erythroblast lineages, and that immune cell cfDNA (especially monocyte/macrophage) and endothelial cfDNA predict worsening and longer hospital stays. Remarkably, even asymptomatic individuals show increased cfDNA signatures from endothelial and erythroblast origins—suggesting that subclinical vascular turnover and red blood cell lineage dynamics occur widely in SARS-CoV-2 infection, regardless of disease severity.

This medRxiv preprint (Aug 10, 2025) reports that IgG purified from ME/CFS and Long-COVID (PASC) patients alters endothelial-cell mitochondrial structure and energetics and drives distinct cytokine programs in healthy PBMCs. In endothelial cells, ME/CFS IgG induced mitochondrial fragmentation; the effect disappeared when IgG was enzymatically cleaved, yet the Fab fragment alone recapitulated the energetic impact, while the Fc fragment alone produced a hypometabolic pattern with a trend toward lower ATP. Proteomic profiling of IgG-bound immune complexes differed by illness: ME/CFS complexes were enriched for pathways in extracellular-matrix organization, whereas PASC complexes pointed to hemostasis / clot-regulation processes. The authors conclude that patient antibodies may play a causal role in post-infectious disease biology by disrupting endothelial mitochondrial dynamics and modulating immune signaling, highlighting antibody-targeted strategies as potential avenues for therapy.

This study developed a 3D in-vitro human skeletal muscle tissue model and exposed it to patient sera from ME/CFS and Long COVID patients. Within 48 hours exposure the tissues showed a marked drop in contractile strength alongside transcriptomic evidence of up-regulated protein translation, elevated glycolytic enzyme expression, disruption of calcium regulation, and mitochondrial hyperfusion. The early adaptive phase appears to boost metabolic activity and structural changes (hypertrophy) in response to the stress imparted by patient sera. However, upon extended exposure (96-144 hours) the model exhibited a transition to metabolic fragility: contractile strength further declined, myotubes became weakened, mitochondria adopted fragmented “toroidal” morphologies, and the compensatory mechanisms failed. The findings suggest that muscle weakness and fatigue in ME/CFS and Long COVID may reflect a biphasic process: a transient hyper-metabolic adaptation followed by collapse of mitochondrial and contractile resilience. The authors propose this supports a biological basis for fatigue and post-exertional malaise in these conditions.

In this cross-sectional MRI study of 97 individuals with long COVID (persisting neuropsychiatric symptoms) compared to 31 recovered controls, researchers found that the long COVID group exhibited significantly elevated blood-brain barrier (BBB) permeability (PS increase of ~18.6 units; β = 0.28; P = 0.003) after adjustment for age and sex. No differences were seen in cerebral blood flow, extraction fraction, or brain volume. Within the long COVID group, greater BBB leakage correlated with worse motor-function performance but did not correlate with other cognitive domains. The findings suggest that BBB disruption may be a long-lasting consequence of SARS-CoV-2 infection and could contribute to neurological sequelae of long COVID, especially motor dysfunction.

In the article, John M. Eyler examines biomedical science on the eve of and during the 1918-19 influenza pandemic. He shows that the scientific paradigm at the time relied heavily on bacterial theories of influenza (especially the supposed causative role of Haemophilus influenzae / Pfeiffer’s bacillus), and that numerous vaccines were developed and deployed during the pandemic, often in rushed or poorly controlled trials. Many of these vaccines yielded contradictory results, and no consensus existed on standards of efficacy. Eyler argues that the chaotic vaccine efforts and the inability to identify the correct etiologic agent (the influenza virus was unknown until 1933) triggered improvements in trial methodology and public-health practices. The 1918 pandemic thus became a watershed moment in epidemiology, microbiology, and vaccine science — not only because of its enormous mortality, but because it exposed foundational gaps in knowledge and helped shape the future of how epidemics are studied and responded to.

🐁This mouse study (K18-hACE2) inoculated males with 5×10^4 PFU SARS-CoV-2 and examined testes at 5 dpi. The team localized hACE2, spike, and nucleocapsid within Leydig cells, and found increased expression of the viral RNA sensor Rigi along with expansion/activation of testicular macrophage populations (CD68^+ “M1” and CD163^+ “M2”), higher MIF and IL-10 protein, and stronger IL-1β/IL-6/TNF-α signals. Notably, LC cytokine–enzyme colabeling (17β-HSD+IL-6) rose 1.3-fold (p=0.0001). Concurrently, LC steroidogenesis appeared impaired: Sf1 was downregulated, StAR and 17β-HSD immunoreactivity and testosterone staining decreased, while lipid-handling/biogenesis genes Dgat1, Srebp, and Scarb1 increased. Electron microscopy revealed lipid-droplet–rich Leydig cells and viral particles associated with lipid structures, supporting a model where SARS-CoV-2 hijacks steroidogenic/lipid machinery to replicate, at the expense of androgen production—aligning with reports of low testosterone/HDL in severe COVID-19.

In a primary-infection, pre-vaccine cohort (Hong Kong, 2020), 146 children and 85 adults with mild or asymptomatic COVID-19 were followed from 0–14 to 15–206 days post-infection. Acute seropositivity for spike IgG above the cut-off was 37.3% (children) vs 47.5% (adults), and adults had more mild (vs asymptomatic) cases (85.9% vs 56.8%; p < 0.0001). By convalescence, children—despite lower total IgG magnitudes—displayed higher avidity to whole Spike and Nucleocapsid and greater spike Fc-receptor binding (including FcγRIIIa-linked function) than adults. Adults’ responses correlated with OC43 S/S2 measures, consistent with cross-reactive recall, while children mounted de novo, targeted SARS-CoV-2 responses with stronger functional features. Net-net: kids show fewer antibodies, but “better” ones (higher avidity, stronger FcR engagement).

This review (May 2025; 25(5):e294–e306) argues that SARS-CoV-2 may persist for months–years in a subset of people, forming a reservoir that contributes to Long COVID. With no approved therapies and tens of millions affected, the authors urge clinical trials that directly target viral persistence using antivirals and monoclonal antibodies, potentially in combinations. They provide a practical checklist for such trials: match drug mechanism to persistence biology; stratify participants; ensure adequate treatment duration; standardize biomarkers that reflect reservoir activity; and use robust clinical endpoints, including post-hoc analyses for subgroups. Lessons from HIV/HCV reservoir studies and precision oncology can guide design and interpretation.

The study evaluated neutralizing and binding antibody responses in 56 adults following a monovalent mRNA vaccine (KP.2) against emerging SARS-CoV-2 subvariants (LP.8.1, LF.7.1, NB.1.8.1, XFG and BA.3.2). Although neutralization against the vaccine-matched KP.2 and a related JN.1 variant was decent (GMTs ~315 and ~203 respectively), neutralization of the more antigenically divergent variants dropped substantially (e.g., GMT ~60 for LP.8.1, ~29 for XFG) compared to ancestral strain (GMT ~733). Binding antibodies, however, remained high, suggesting maintained potential for protection despite reduced neutralization. Interestingly, participants with only vaccination history (no prior infection) showed broader cross-neutralization than those with hybrid immunity (infection + vaccination), possibly reflecting immune imprinting bias toward prior infecting strains. The antigenic map confirmed that the emerging variants are antigenically distant from KP.2, supporting the idea that current vaccine boosting predominantly amplifies pre-existing responses rather than adapting fully to newly drifted variants. The findings signal that updated vaccine antigens or new delivery strategies may be required to maintain protection as SARS-CoV-2 continues to evolve.

This study assessed how much protection a prior SARS-CoV-2 infection provided against symptomatic reinfection with the Omicron variant (B.1.1.529) and earlier variants in Qatar. They used a test-negative case-control design on national databases, comparing people with prior documented infection vs. no prior infection. They found that prior infection provided about 56.0% (95% CI ~50.0–60.0) protection against symptomatic Omicron reinfection, whereas protection against symptomatic reinfection with earlier variants (e.g., Alpha, Beta, Delta) was much higher (≈90 %) in earlier work.

In a large national cohort of SARS-CoV-2 cases in England between late November 2021 and early January 2022, the Omicron variant (B.1.1.529) was associated with substantially lower risks of hospital attendance (≈44% lower risk), hospital admission (≈59% lower risk) and death (≈69% lower risk) compared with the Delta variant (B.1.617.2). The magnitude of reduction differed by age, with minimal difference in children <10 years, and larger reductions in older age groups (e.g., HR ~0.25 for age 60–69). Prior infection and vaccination (particularly booster mRNA doses) further reduced the risk of severe outcomes. Importantly, the authors interpret that the observed reductions reflect both a lower intrinsic severity of Omicron (in unvaccinated individuals) and reduced vaccine effectiveness (i.e., more breakthrough infections) against Omicron compared to Delta. They emphasise that boosters maintain strong protection with breakthrough infections.

In this large Japanese national registry-based study of 46,291 hospitalized COVID-19 patients aged 20-89, the authors investigated the relationship between BMI and risk of severe disease or death. They found that both underweight (BMI < 18.5) and overweight/obesity (BMI ≥ 25) were associated with significantly increased risk of more intensive treatment or death, compared to a normal weight reference (BMI 20.1-24.9). Notably, the magnitude of risk was highest for the underweight during the Omicron predominance period (ORs around 2.4–3.0), indicating that lean patients may be at particular vulnerability. The findings suggest that clinical risk stratification for COVID-19 should incorporate low BMI alongside the more traditionally recognised high BMI, especially during variant waves like Omicron.

The European Academy of Neurology’s NeuroCOVID-19 Task Force reviews evidence that COVID-19 can leave lasting CNS changes—vascular injury, microthromboses, demyelination, and microglial activation—that may initiate or accelerate neurodegeneration. Although direct CNS infection is debated (CSF RNA detected in <3% of 449 reported neuro-COVID cases), autopsy and imaging data show widespread inflammatory/vascular pathology, with reports of viral persistence for months in brain tissue. Population studies suggest elevated near-term risks of neurodegenerative diagnoses after COVID-19: in Denmark (n≈43k positives), AD risk was 3.5× at 6 months and 3.4× at 12 months; PD risk 2.4× and 2.2×, respectively; a review of >1.5 M cases found ~15% higher 12-month cognitive impairment. The authors call for long-term surveillance via registry linkages and cohort follow-up to detect potential post-COVID increases in AD/PD and related disorders.

In a large UK retrospective cohort of around 624,000 adults with overweight or obesity who had a recent SARS-CoV-2 infection, initiation of metformin within 90 days of infection was associated with about a 36% lower risk of developing post-COVID-19 condition (PCC) at one year. This finding supports earlier clinical trial data (showing a 63% reduction when metformin was started within 3 days of diagnosis) and suggests that metformin may offer a preventive strategy for Long COVID in high-risk individuals.

In a survey of 578 people with self-reported long-COVID, those who reported having POTS (a condition characterised by excessive heart-rate increase on standing) demonstrated substantially worse health status, more severe symptoms and more psychosocial burden than those without POTS. They were younger, reported greater financial difficulties, social isolation and suicidal ideation, and a higher prevalence of orthostatic intolerance symptoms (palpitations, tremor, exercise intolerance, cognitive complaints). The authors highlight that POTS may define a distinct and high-burden subgroup within long-COVID, suggesting the need for targeted attention and possibly autonomic-specific evaluation/treatment.

Using >11,000 RECOVER-Adult participants (infected: 10,211; controls: 1,189) assessed ≥135 days post-infection, the study applied a 41-symptom Long-COVID index (LCRI ≥12) to compare age groups. Odds of meeting the Long-COVID threshold rose through midlife (OR 1.40 at 40–49; 1.31 at 50–59) but fell in adults ≥70 (OR 0.68) relative to ages 18–39. Older adults also showed different symptom patterns: smaller infected–uninfected gaps for hearing loss, fatigue, pain, post-exertional malaise, sleep problems, palpitations, etc., and age-shifted clusters—anosmia/ageusia and GI+cough+palpitations were more common, while brain-fog–dominant and mixed clusters were less common.

In this study of ~6-month post-infection follow-up, individuals with Long COVID (PASC) displayed markedly different immune profiles compared to convalescent individuals without PASC: they had persistently high IgG against SARS-CoV-2 Envelope and Nucleocapsid proteins, but lower IgG to Spike, with a subclass bias toward IgG1/IgG3. Concomitantly, PASC participants exhibited elevated frequencies of cT_FH and MAIT cells and increased levels of cytokines such as LIF, IL-11 and HMGB-1, as well as higher autoantibody burdens.

In a survey of 121 Australian adults who had experienced confirmed Long COVID-19 infection, 86 % (104/121) reported clinically significant disability and participation limitations on the WHODAS 2.0 scale, with mean scores indicating higher disability levels than 98 % of the general population. Quality of life, measured via the SF-36, was reduced across all domains compared to norms—particularly in vitality and social functioning. The study found that worse outcomes in disability/function and quality of life were significantly associated with having more comorbidities, fewer vaccine doses, and poorer self-rated recovery.

COVID-19 increases the risk of acute kidney injury (AKI) in the acute phase and is associated with later chronic kidney disease (CKD), making CKD a plausible renal manifestation of long COVID (long-term effects persisting ≥3 months). Patients with pre-existing CKD are more susceptible to infection, severe outcomes and, potentially, long COVID. Distinct renal entities linked to COVID-19 include COVID-19–associated nephropathy (collapsing focale segmentale glomerulosclerose (FSGS)) and increased reports of vasculitis. While case reports have described new or relapsing glomerular disease after infection or vaccination, large population-based studies have not confirmed consistent causal associations for most glomerulopathies; by contrast, vaccination is safe in CKD, lowers COVID-19 risk, and is associated with reduced long-COVID risk. Mechanistically, pathways that drive AKI during acute infection (direct viral effects, immune-mediated and endothelial injury, hemodynamic stress) may also underlie chronic kidney sequelae.

This review synthesizes evidence that long-term or latent infections alter fundamental cellular and molecular mechanisms associated with aging — for instance, by forcing mitochondria to support pathogen replication, thereby degrading cellular energy and resilience; by engaging pathways like mTOR that tie metabolism, immunity and longevity; by promoting senescent cell accumulation and chronic low-grade inflammation; and by shifting epigenetic regulation and immune cell composition in ways that mirror older physiological states. The authors assert that these pathogen-driven changes may not just accompany aging but actively accelerate it. Secondly, they discuss how this revised perspective could reshape how we model aging and design interventions: recognizing infection history, pathogen persistence and immune‐metabolic disruption as core components of aging biology. They also stress that current diagnostics are insufficient to track these microbial contributions, limiting precision medicine approaches in aging and longevity.

In this study, Yu et al. demonstrate that the histamine H1 receptor (HRH1) can function as an alternative receptor for SARS-CoV-2 by directly binding the spike protein N-terminal domain, and that HRH1 also enhances hACE2-dependent viral entry by interacting with hACE2. By screening a library of 1,280 FDA-approved drugs, they found that H1 receptor antagonists inhibited viral entry in cell culture, with an average IC₅₀ of ~2.4 µM for various SARS-CoV-2 mutants. Further, using authentic virus and humanized mouse challenge models, the study supports that antihistamine drugs can reduce infection in vivo, suggesting a potentially repurposable class of therapeutics for COVID-19.

The authors developed a urinary peptidomic signature, PASC195, from 195 differentially expressed peptides distinguishing long-COVID cases from controls. The signature mainly reflected altered collagen I and III metabolism, as well as fragments from proteins linked to coagulation (fibrinogen α/β), inflammation (calprotectin S100A9), and endothelial integrity (PGBM). The model accurately separated PASC from controls with > 95% sensitivity and specificity. These findings support that urine-based peptide biomarkers can detect systemic changes consistent with endothelial dysfunction and pro-inflammatory, pro-fibrotic processes in long COVID. However, validation in an independent UriCoV cohort three years post-infection did not replicate the signal (p = 0.15), likely due to differences in symptom severity, recruitment criteria, and timing of sampling.

🧫The study shows that iota-carrageenan — an already-used antiviral polymer in nasal sprays — can neutralize SARS-CoV-2 spike-pseudotyped lentivirus with an IC₅₀ around 2.6 µg/mL, and reduces replication of wild-type SARS-CoV-2 in cell culture, as evidenced by reduced viral nucleoprotein and RNA levels. In comparing to other polymers, iota-carrageenan showed better antiviral performance, supporting its further investigation. However, these results are entirely in vitro and do not demonstrate clinical efficacy in humans for SARS-CoV-2. The study is limited by cell-line models (ACE2-HEK293, Vero B4) which may not reflect human airway physiology, absence of in vivo or human trial data, and potential conflicts of interest (some authors affiliated with a company producing the polymer).

In a cohort of 32 vaccinated health-care workers (16 of whom subsequently had breakthrough SARS-CoV-2 infection), the study found that those who developed post-vaccine infection (PVI) exhibited significantly poorer spike-specific CD4⁺ T-cell responses at one month after booster compared to those who remained uninfected, despite similar antibody levels. They also displayed higher LAG-3 expression on T-cells, and a trend toward reduced central-memory CD4⁺ T-cells, suggesting a less effective cellular recall response. After natural infection, these individuals showed enhanced CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T-cell activation and expansion of NKG2C⁺ “memory-like” NK cells, indicating that breakthrough infection can rescue and broaden cellular immunity. The findings suggest that antibody titres alone are insufficient to predict susceptibility to breakthrough infection: the quality and magnitude of the T-cell (particularly CD4⁺) and NK-cell responses matter. Future work is needed to define whether low post-booster T-cell responses can be used to identify individuals at higher risk of breakthrough infection and whether boosting or other immunomodulation can mitigate this risk.

In a cohort of over 10,000 individuals from the UK Biobank infected with COVID-19 (and more than 217,000 matched controls), the study found that COVID-19 was associated with more than a twofold increased long-term risk of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), and nearly a fourfold risk among those hospitalized for COVID-19. The hazard ratio for MACE in all COVID cases was 2.09 (95% CI 1.94–2.25) and 3.85 (95% CI 3.51–4.24) for hospitalized cases. Moreover, COVID-19 hospitalization in people without prior cardiovascular disease conferred a risk equivalent to the risk in people with cardiovascular disease who had not had COVID-19. Additionally, the authors identified a genetic interaction: individuals with non-O blood types who were hospitalized for COVID-19 had a significantly higher risk of thrombotic events (HR 1.65, 95% CI 1.29–2.09) compared to those with blood type O (HR 0.96, 95% CI 0.66–1.39). The authors suggest that prior severe COVID-19 should be considered akin to a cardiovascular risk factor, and that blood-type genetics may modify that risk.

In this pre-print, the authors identify a mechanistic pathway by which the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 induces neuronal cell death. Through a screen of 22 viral proteins they found Orf6 to be highly cytotoxic in human cells. In human primary neurons infected with SARS-CoV-2 (multiplicity of infection (MOI) 0.1) they observed elevated phosphorylation of RIPK3 and MLKL — hallmark necroptosis markers — without significant activation of apoptosis, pyroptosis or autophagy. They further show that Orf6 physically interacts with the mitochondrial carrier homolog 1 (MTCH1) in neurons, leading to mitochondrial permeability transition pore opening, loss of membrane potential, increased mitochondrial ROS, calcium overload, and neuronal death. Knock-down of MTCH1 or pharmacological inhibition of RIPK3 effectively rescued the neurons from necroptosis, supporting a causal role of this pathway. Importantly, they also analysed human hippocampal brain sections from five COVID-19 autopsy cases and found increased pRIPK3 in MAP2+ neurons and more TUNEL+ neuronal death than in controls, corroborating the in vitro findings in human tissue.
